title: Our Perfectly Pretend Plane Romance
excerpt: We‚Äôve been publishing the winners of our True Romance Writing Prize collaboration with Belletrist and actress Emma Roberts these past few weeks. So far, we‚Äôve shared the grand prize‚Äìwinning essay in the shortread category, by Maggie Hart, and the longform winning story, by Oli‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I met someone mid-flight and we immediately hit it off. Rather than try to keep in touch, we imagined what our lives would have been like if we were together. It was almost as good.

We‚Äôve been publishing the winners of our True Romance Writing Prize collaboration with Belletrist and actress Emma Roberts these past few weeks. So far, we‚Äôve shared the grand prize‚Äìwinning essay in the shortread category, by Maggie Hart, and the longform winning story, by Olivia Shaffett. We‚Äôre elated to be bringing you the first shortread finalist this week, a banger of a piece from Katharine Coldiron. This is what Katharine had to say about how the piece came together: ‚ÄúThis was the first piece I‚Äôd written on a prompt in years. I read the call for entries and thought immediately of this tale. I worked it through in the shower and put it down in a rush. I polished it a little, et voila.‚Äù A great reminder to follow a spark and go for it!

I was 19 or 20, a smoker, on a plane from New England to New Orleans. Next to me sat a man, around 19 or 20, a smoker. We looked at each other and liked what we saw; we talked to each other and liked what we heard; we, simply, hit it off.

And not as friends. In that way that enlivens your whole body. Chemistry, pheromones, attraction. Whatever you call that, when the person is someone whose skin you badly want to touch from the first moments of meeting them.

As we talked, we realized there was no way we‚Äôd ever meet again. I was visiting my mother for the summer in a place I would never live permanently. He was laying over in New Orleans on the way back to Wyoming or Oklahoma or North Texas, I don‚Äôt remember. I don‚Äôt even remember his name. I know he came from a place I‚Äôd never been and seemed unlikely to visit: a landlocked place. All my experiences had been coastal, due to my Navy father ‚Äî I never lived anywhere you couldn‚Äôt park a 40,000-ton ship near.

We told the truth. We made each other laugh.

There was no social media then, and we both had precisely the quantity of life experience that advised us not to persist or pursue this connection. A little less and our romantic sides would have tried to build faith in a long-distance something; a little more and we would have recognized that such an instant, holistic connection is too rare to waste.

Instead, we had the plane ride, and that was all.

How will I remember you? I asked, or something less obvious that posed the same question.

He dug in his pocket. I just bought this, he said. It was a rectangular Bic lighter with a picture of a cowboy on it, either at dusk or sunrise.

I unzipped the front pocket of my backpack and pulled out an oval Bic lighter. It was a paisley design with a lot of purple in it. I‚Äôd chosen it because it was eye-catching and pretty without any pink.

We traded.

As we taxied, he said to me, I wish I could kiss you.

Silence for a minute.

Let‚Äôs pretend to be together, I said. As we‚Äôre getting off the plane, let‚Äôs pretend that we‚Äôre boyfriend and girlfriend. We‚Äôll hold hands and talk about where to go for dinner. Then you‚Äôll go to your gate and I‚Äôll go to baggage claim.

Yeah, he said.

And you could kiss me then, I said. But not, like, really dramatically, like in the movies. Just like you do it all the time.

He nodded.

That was right. That was the right thing.

I tried not to be sad.

I still have that lighter. I find it in boxes of old stuff I go through from time to time, trying to discard what I no longer need. It‚Äôs been 15 years since I smoked, but I will not throw away that lighter.

Secret Life of the Professor Who Lives with Nazis

Sociologist Peter Simi has spent 20 years embedding with skinheads. As hate crimes spike across America, his intimate insights are more crucial than ever.

This thrilling story by Erika Hayasaki is a fascinating look at a man who has dedicated his life to a very unorthodox and dangerous mission. Unfortunately, even as Peter Simi‚Äôs work becomes more and more relevant, the Trump administration recently shut down his funding and banned his books. If you haven‚Äôt had a chance to read this story yet, it‚Äôs one not to miss. And if you want to learn how to write hard-hitting profiles like this one, we‚Äôre extremely lucky to have the writer, Erika Hayasaki joining us for an Open Book live video over at Narratively Academy this week.

The partygoers with swastikas and Iron Cross tattoos began to arrive at the ranch-style home in Costa Mesa, California, one summer evening in 2000. Pete Simi looked around the crammed living room as it quickly filled with around 50 racists clapping and swaying to the guitar and drum music of a white-power band, Hate Train, which belted out lyrics about ‚ÄúAryan pride.‚Äù The color of Simi‚Äôs skin allowed him to blend in. He‚Äôs a husky guy, with sand-colored hair, who can down beer after beer without losing his faculties, a practice that gives him cred with this crowd. He caught eyes with an intoxicated skinhead, who stared at him suspiciously and then said to a friend next to him: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the guy who wants to study us.‚Äù

title: The Unexpected Challenges of Dating After Cancer
excerpt: It was such a joy to collaborate with Emma Roberts, Karah Preiss and the whole Belletrist team on the True Romance Writing Prize this year. After announcing the winners a few weeks ago, we‚Äôre excited to finally share the first piece of the bunch, the grand prize‚Äìwinning essay ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The chemo had miraculously worked, but Maggie Hart wanted to make sure 'this whole cancer thing' had not rendered her 'sexless and unlovable.' There was just one thing she needed to figure out first.

It was such a joy to collaborate with Emma Roberts, Karah Preiss and the whole Belletrist team on the True Romance Writing Prize this year. After announcing the winners a few weeks ago, we‚Äôre excited to finally share the first piece of the bunch, the grand prize‚Äìwinning essay in the shortread category, which comes to us from Maggie Hart. Maggie opened up a bit about writing this piece and others like it: ‚ÄúAfter I completed my chemo treatments, I felt awkward and ugly in my baldness, convinced I‚Äôd never be able to exist normally again, much less date. But finding small moments of humor and lightness helped me get through. I think lots of people view serious illness as something that only happens later in life, which just isn‚Äôt true ‚Äî so I like sharing my stories about navigating the weirdness of cancer survival and young adulthood all at once.‚Äù Congratulations again, Maggie! And readers ‚Äî you‚Äôre in for a treat.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù I said to Nick, who stood staring at me in the dim light, his bare chest rising and falling with quickened breaths, his lips swollen from my kissing them. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just that‚Ä¶well, I‚Äôve been really racking my brain here, and I just don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a sexy way to do this.‚Äù

My fingers lingered at my forehead, on my hairline. My wig gripped my scalp like a barnacle on a boat, the scratchy fibers relentlessly digging into my skin, one of many small, manageable pains I had in those days. It had to come off for what was about to happen, I knew that. There was really no way around it. Leaving it on was impossible ‚Äî I had a profoundly humbling vision of the wig abandoning ship mid-action, slipping loose and tumbling onto the floor in a sad, sweaty heap. It had also been quite an investment ‚Äî although I still do not understand why a bunch of fake hair costs multiple hundreds of dollars ‚Äî so I didn‚Äôt want it to get hopelessly matted. And what if, in the throes of passion, he forgot that the hair was fake and tried to pull it‚Ä¶

No. No! Obviously, it had to come off. But how, exactly? I wished he‚Äôd look away, spare me, if only partially, from the humiliation of my baldification, the world‚Äôs least seductive strip tease.

Nick smiled at me encouragingly. He was kind and tattooed and had long dark hair that was beginning to streak with gray. I‚Äôd never been with a man who had hair longer than mine, although, that winter, any man with any hair at all had hair longer than mine.

Four months after my last round of chemotherapy, I decided that it was time I put myself out there, that I date. Why not? The chemo had, miraculously, worked. My blood counts were relatively normal, I hadn‚Äôt needed a platelet transfusion in weeks and my oncologists gave me the all-clear, so it was time that I shifted my attention away from my no-longer-imminent death to something much more invigorating: the pursuit of reassurance. I needed to know that my body worked, that I still knew how to have a conversation that was not about being sick, that this whole cancer thing had not rendered me sexless and unlovable at just 25 years old. So, I went where every woman in her 20s goes when she needs reassurance: the apps.

title: Castor Oil and Rosemary Oil for Hair Recipe
excerpt: Hair care shelves are packed with big promises‚Ä¶ and even bigger ingredient lists that often do more harm than good. We‚Äôre talking harsh chemicals, synthetic fragrances, and irritating additives your hair definitely doesn‚Äôt need.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Hair care shelves are packed with big promises‚Ä¶ and even bigger ingredient lists that often do more harm than good. We‚Äôre talking harsh chemicals, synthetic fragrances, and irritating additives your hair definitely doesn‚Äôt need.

We believe nature knows best when it comes to beauty. Natural ingredients aren‚Äôt just safer and gentler on your hair, they actually work.

Take rosemary oils, for example. It‚Äôs all-natur√©l and does wonders for your hair and scalp. Pair it with castor oil, a tried-and-true remedy that‚Äôs been used for generations on everything from skin to hair, and you‚Äôve got a powerful combo for long, shiny locks.

Today, we‚Äôre sharing a simple DIY natural hair treatment using both rosemary and castor oil. It‚Äôs easy to make at home and perfect for nourishing, strengthening, and encouraging thicker, healthier hair.

Castor Oil and Rosemary Oil for Hair Recipe

We‚Äôre big fans of castor oil, and for good reason. You can use castor oil for lymph nodes, to make your brows thicker, fuller, and longer, and, as an overnight detox‚Äîcheck out our post ‚ÄúBenefits of Castor Oil Patches‚Äù for more information on that.

After realizing how powerful of an oil it is, we had to try it on our scalp and hair, too. And as we looked into the idea further, we found that rosemary oil pairs perfectly with castor oil to boost hair growth totally naturally.

Here‚Äôs how you can make your own castor and rosemary oil hair treatment:

Is Castor and Rosemary Oil Good for Hair?

Yes! There are so many rosemary and castor oil benefits for your hair. The nutrients in the oil can increase blood circulation to the scalp, promoting hair growth. At the same time, castor oil‚Äôs antimicrobial properties can keep your scalp healthy, reducing dandruff and scalp infections.¬†

Beyond stimulating hair growth, the combination of rosemary and castor oils can also strengthen and moisturize brittle and dry hair. Their rich, hydrating consistency helps add shine and reduce frizz by smoothing those hair cuticles.

Basically, castor oil + rosemary oil = all your hair goals.

What Does Rosemary and Castor Oil Do for Hair?

Promotes hair growth

Improves scalp health

Moisturizes hair

Strengthens hair strands

Protects hair from damage

Reduces hair shedding

Prevents dandruff and dry scalp

Reduces scalp inflammation

Improves hair thinning

How to Make Rosemary and Castor Oil for Hair Growth

2 tablespoons cold-pressed castor oil

1 tablespoon jojoba oil, coconut oil, or other carrier oil¬†

5-10 drops rosemary essential oil

In a small glass or ceramic bowl, combine the castor oil, carrier oil, and rosemary essential oil.

Fill the sink with a few inches of warm water. Then, place the bowl in the warm water (don‚Äôt let any spill over the top). Let it sit for a few minutes to warm the oils.

The warmth from the mixture helps your pores open up and absorb more of the oil. Make sure you don‚Äôt microwave it though, because it can reduce the potency and degrade the beneficial nutrients.

Wet your scalp and then use your fingertips to apply the oil blend directly onto your scalp, section by section. Massage the oil gently into your skin with your fingers or a scalp massager for 3-5 minutes. (Use code TSC25 for 25% off the Pellequr scalp massager.)


Then, pour a dime-sized amount of oil into your palm and rub your hands together to warm it up. Starting from the mid-lengths, work your way down to the ends, smoothing the oil evenly through your hair. Repeat until all strands are lightly coated.

Let the oil sit on your hair for 30 minutes to 2 hours. You could even let it sit overnight for a deep treatment, too. Just make sure to use a shower cap to protect your bedding.

Make sure to shampoo thoroughly‚Äîwe even recommend shampooing twice to remove all the oil and buildup. Then, condition your hair as usual for soft, refreshed strands.

title: How to Block Cell Phone Radiation + What You NEED to Know About EMF
excerpt: Believe it or not, we encounter radiation every day. We‚Äôre not just talking about the electromagnetic and corpuscular radiation from the sun, though. We‚Äôre also exposed to it from artificial things like cell phones, Wi-Fi routers, radio broadcasts, smart meters, and even home ‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Believe it or not, we encounter radiation every day. We‚Äôre not just talking about the electromagnetic and corpuscular radiation from the sun, though. We‚Äôre also exposed to it from artificial things like cell phones, Wi-Fi routers, radio broadcasts, smart meters, and even home appliances.

Here‚Äôs the thing: you need to protect yourself from all kinds of radiation. We put on SPF to protect our skin from the sun, right? But what about when it comes to protecting ourselves from our phones and other Bluetooth devices?

The good news is that there are ways to block this artificial radiation, too. That way, you can keep your family safe from any potential harmful effects without unplugging from the modern world.

Here‚Äôs how you can stay connected and protected:

How to Block Cell Phone Radiation + What You NEED to Know About EMF

The sun showers us with ultraviolet (UV) radiation, while our everyday devices emit electromagnetic field (EMF) radiation.

Just like UV rays, this type of radiation is totally invisible. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important to know exactly what it is, where it‚Äôs coming from, the potential risks, and, most importantly, how you can protect yourself.

Before we jump into things, it‚Äôs important to note that not all EMFs are bad! Take electromagnetic therapy, for example, that uses electric fields to stimulate the body‚Äôs natural healing process. Sometimes they can do pretty amazing things‚Ä¶ when they‚Äôre necessary.¬†

Just check out the Gary Brecka episode of The Him & Her Show to learn more.

What Is EMF Radiation?

Electromagnetic field (EMF) radiation is made up of electric and magnetic fields working together. As a result, this is the invisible energy that‚Äôs all around us. It exists across the entire electromagnetic spectrum, which includes everything from the low-frequency waves from power lines to the higher-frequency RF radiation used by cell phones and Wi-Fi.

Essentially, electromagnetic fields (EMFs) include lots of different frequencies. Some are so low we can‚Äôt see or feel them, like those from household appliances. Others, like visible light, are easily detectable by the naked eye. All of these are types of electromagnetic radiation, just at different energy levels.

As we mentioned earlier, not all types of radiation deserve a red-flag warning. Just like spending time in the sun has its benefits, certain frequencies of EMFs can be helpful, too. You can learn more about that from longevity expert Gary Brecka in our post What is the Superhuman Protocol?

Is EMF Radiation Harmful?

There‚Äôs a lot of debate about whether EMF radiation causes adverse health effects, but there is NOT a debate over whether it impacts our bodies. Even the World Health Organization acknowledges EMFs absolutely have biological effects.

Sometimes, exposure to EMF radiation can bring on headaches, fatigue, dizziness, brain fog, or even skin sensitivity. For some, it‚Äôs because of too much exposure, but others are just naturally more sensitive to these fields.

Over time, as our body‚Äôs repair systems and immune defenses weaken, abnormal cells may not get cleared out properly. This, in turn, can lead to an increased risk of cancerous tumor growth.

DNA damage caused by ongoing oxidative stress can actually accelerate biological aging. This means your tissues, organs, and skin cells lose their ability to repair and regenerate effectively, making your body more vulnerable to wear and tear.

Chris Hillman, a founding member of The Byrds, described Westwood Music as ‚Äú‚Äòthe hardware store‚Äô of the L.A. music scene.‚Äù

Check this out: the three-word portal into the Fred Walecki Experience.Check this out, andhe‚Äôd hand John Entwistle his first-ever Alembic bass, a brand he would go on to use for many years with the Who.Check this out, and he‚Äôd pull out a guitar by Mark Whitebook or David Russell Young, luthiers he‚Äôd discovered in the mountains of Topanga Canyon, and whose instruments he sold to James Taylor and Gram Parsons. Glyn Johns bought a David Russell Young so he‚Äôd have a good acoustic guitar for the rock bands he worked with. (Johns showed me that guitar when I visited him at home last fall; he apologized for all the scratch marks. ‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs played this,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEric has played it; Jeff Beck‚Äôs played it; Jimmy Page has played it.‚Äù)

Early in her career, Bonnie Raitt was playing in little clubs and ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt even expecting to do this for a living. It was kind of a hobby for me,‚Äù she told me. But Dad, she says, ‚Äúshowed me around and showed me the whole world of things that I could have.‚Äù He explained how different amplifiers could change her sound, and he took her to a trade show where he introduced her to the genteel, rather ancient chairman of Martin Guitar, C. F. Martin III.

Raitt has a mischievous, bawdy sense of humor. (As a kid, I understood I was never to repeat a Bonnie Raitt joke.) Dad told C. F. Martin that Raitt was a rising star and may be in need of a custom-made guitar. ‚ÄúWhat I really need is a custom-made IUD,‚Äù she said. Martin had no idea what she was talking about, so Dad jumped in: ‚ÄúUh, it‚Äôs a lot like a Martin D-35.‚Äù

body:
A. Kendra Greene beautifully reflects on the generations of families growing up in California, our changing climate and way of life, and the experiences and memories that shape us and which we carry within our bodies, wherever we go.

A few years before I had nieces at all, I remember thinking that I felt a shift coming, a kind of tipping point, that already, even in terms of technology, so much had changed so fast that there was about to be too much to explain to someone new to all of it, a child or an alien, and I meant just the part I‚Äôd lived through. Even just that, a few decades, was about to be impossible, all of it still recent memory, but simply too much.

It was last summer I first noticed the people I knew in Salt Lake talking about wildfires in the tongue of my West Coast childhood. It happened with locals and transplants alike, in canyons and coffee shops, at a friend‚Äôs house in the hills looking across the sweep of the valley. Not only the language, the fact of air quality and containment and evacuation route and how much longer can we stay, but something in the tone, what I can only name a familiarness, the sound of understanding.

title: The Man in the New Boots
excerpt: As Chandler Fritz makes his way to the bucking chute in his grandfather‚Äôs boots and a DIY cup, he turns over the forces that have moved him to ride a bull. In his telescopic essay, Fritz moves between Paleolithic cave paintings and gas-station epiphanies, the roots of early No‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
As Chandler Fritz makes his way to the bucking chute in his grandfather‚Äôs boots and a DIY cup, he turns over the forces that have moved him to ride a bull. In his telescopic essay, Fritz moves between Paleolithic cave paintings and gas-station epiphanies, the roots of early North American bull-riding events and a short list of the beef he‚Äôs consumed in the days before his fated meeting with Babyface, his steer. ‚ÄúA perversion,‚Äù he writes, ‚Äúis a turn from a previous path to meaning. It is the betrayal of an exact course.‚Äù But I‚Äôd take a true course over an exact one any day.

I can‚Äôt tell you why I wanted to do this, but I can tell you exactly when I made the decision to do it. I was filling up my mother-in-law‚Äôs Hummer at the Shell right off the Piestewa Highway a few days after the ocotillos bloomed. My wife and I had just decided we were going to try to have kids. I know what you‚Äôre thinking, but that‚Äôs not exactly it. I don‚Äôt want to ride a bull before I have a kid. I want to make a bunch of money and buy a house and a Subaru before I have a kid.

But I was standing there pumping midgrade octane into the H3 and staring at the McDowells and thinking about how I knew the pump number where I was standing, knew the name of the mountains I was looking at, knew the hard smell of the gasoline and the flaming blue of a passing attendant‚Äôs uniform‚Äîknew these things

exactly, the way I had always determined to know the world‚Äîand suddenly I thought I should probably ride a bull. Or, more accurately, I suddenly found that I was going to ride a bull, as I had already reached for my phone and called Buffalo Chip and got my name on the list before any normative notion of whether Ishoulddo this crossed my mind. It was a kind of fait accompli accomplished by my unconscious, the type of action one associates with creatures of lesser intelligence. It cost forty dollars, and I signed a waiver‚Äîanyone can do it. At least, anyone can try.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
For Switchboard, Celia Aniskovich goes to Hot Dog University at Vienna Beef Headquarters in Chicago to learn about what it takes to run a hot dog cart. There she profiles seven hopefuls from all walks of life who still relish the American dream: running a successful small business.

There‚Äôs something quietly radical about that. In a country where ‚Äúentrepreneur‚Äù has become a buzzword for tech bros and hustlers, the students at Hot Dog U are a different breed. They‚Äôre working-class dreamers. Retired couples. First-generation families. People who don‚Äôt want to disrupt the industry. They just want a patch of sidewalk, a roll of napkins, and a line of hungry customers.

Bill is the head of Hot Dog University. He‚Äôs your professor of encased meats, your guide through everything from cart etiquette to bulk ordering logistics. Bill makes you feel like you‚Äôre the most important person in the room. Like you could sell a thousand hot dogs by sheer charm and will. When you step off the elevator, you‚Äôre greeted by Bill and by the start of the Vienna Beef Hall of Fame: posters, trinkets, and sausage-themed memorabilia spanning more than a century. It‚Äôs like a hot dog museum married a high school hallway. At some point, it starts to feel a little mythic ‚Äî like the yellow brick road, if Oz were made of mustard and meat.

body:
For The Paris Review, Grace Byron recounts how her obsession with horseshoe crabs began with a visit to the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge to spot birds. Her interest veers from curiosity into conservation when she and a couple of friends volunteer for a horseshoe monitoring session with the NYC Bird Alliance. There, they helped log and tag horseshoe crabs emerging from the water at high tide to mate on Plumb Beach.

Agnes and Ashe waited behind, picking up trash as Ann gave us the outline of our night. She kept checking her watch, waiting for the precise moment of high tide: 7:29 P.M. Using two white pipes connected into a square, we prepared to survey the number of horseshoe crabs present that night at random. Meanwhile, two volunteers carried clipboards to note the number of horseshoe crabs in the sample field. I looked around. So far there weren‚Äôt so many. As requested, we looked around and grabbed the numbers of those already tagged.

excerpt: ‚ÄúStandard of Fear,‚Äù a project led by Lauren Caruba and Marin Wolf of The Dallas Morning News , details the consequences of recent laws restricting abortions in Texas, which now has ‚Äúone of the country‚Äôs most strict and punitive abortion bans.‚Äù In this story, Caruba and Wolf, w‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‚ÄúStandard of Fear,‚Äù a project led by Lauren Caruba and Marin Wolf of The Dallas Morning News, details the consequences of recent laws restricting abortions in Texas, which now has ‚Äúone of the country‚Äôs most strict and punitive abortion bans.‚Äù In this story, Caruba and Wolf, with Mar√≠a Ramos Pacheco, illustrate the final hours of Porsha Ngumezi and Brenda Yolani Arzu Ramirez, two women who died following delays in care. The Morning News team does admirable work to demonstrate the loss of medical expertise, confidence, and data following the Texas bans. The depth of the team‚Äôs reporting is most clear, however, in the stark, harrowing narratives of Ngumezi and Ramirez.

At the outset of Texas‚Äô abortion ban, medical experts worried women like Porsha and Brenda would die from delays in care.

It may never be known exactly how many Texas women have died as a result of the state‚Äôs abortion restrictions. It‚Äôs not always possible to determine to what degree the bans, and the fear around them, influenced a patient‚Äôs care.

And the state

is not trying to find out. The Texas Maternal Mortality and Morbidity Review Committee, the body responsible for investigating maternal deaths, has announced it is not investigating cases from 2022 and 2023, including the immediate aftermath of the state‚Äôs almost-total abortion ban.

To help fill that gap,

The Dallas Morning Newsgathered hundreds of pages of autopsies and death records of maternal deaths that have occurred since Texas restricted abortion in late 2021.The Newsthen asked obstetricians, including those specialized in abortion procedures, to review cases where abortion care might have been lifesaving.

In the cases of Brenda and Porsha, those experts agreed. They both died after hospitals chose not to provide abortion procedures.

The Smithsonian American Art Museum (SAAM) and its Renwick Gallery invite applications to its¬†premier fellowship program, the oldest and largest in American art. Scholars from any discipline whose research engages the art, craft, and visual culture of the United States are encouraged to apply, as are those who foreground new perspectives, materials, and methodologies. There, they have access to the museum‚Äôs collection of over 46,500 works, specialized study collections and databases, the Smithsonian‚Äôs Archives of American Art, and an 180,000-volume branch library specializing in American art. title: Africa Wants a More Accurate World Map
excerpt: The African Union, an intergovernmental organization of 55 African countries, endorsed a version of the world map that more accurately reflects the continent‚Äôs scale earlier this month, as first reported by Reuters .
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The African Union, an intergovernmental organization of 55 African countries, endorsed a version of the world map that more accurately reflects the continent‚Äôs scale earlier this month, as first reported by Reuters.

The union said it would back the Correct the Map campaign to pressure governments and global organizations to phase out the widely used Mercator map in favor of the Equal Earth projection first proposed in 2018. The former distorts the Earth‚Äôs poles, making landmasses like Greenland and Antarctica appear disproportionately large. Advocates for the change argue that the map misrepresents and diminishes the world‚Äôs perception of the African continent. The Equal Earth map, on the other hand, enlarges the continent to more accurately reflect its relative size.

First devised in 1569 by Flemish cartographer Gerardus Mercator, the ubiquitous Mercator projection features longitude lines that are equally spaced vertically across the globe. Latitude lines, however, are unevenly spaced, with the gaps between them growing wider the further out they are from the equator. This scaling creates a distorted, stretched-out effect at the top and bottom of the Earth. As a result, Greenland appears about equal in size to the entire African continent, when in reality the latter is about 14 times larger, according to some estimates.

Hyperallergic)

‚ÄúThe current size of the map of Africa is wrong,‚Äù Moky Makura, executive director of the nonprofit organization Africa No Filter, told Reuters in an interview about the Mercator map projection. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the world‚Äôs longest misinformation and disinformation campaign, and it just simply has to stop.‚Äù

In the Equal Earth map projection, continents appear to more closely match their real relative sizes. Unlike the Mercator map, in which latitude and longitude lines meet at 90-degree angles, its lines are curved to reflect the earth‚Äôs spherical shape, leading to a more accurate portrayal of the African continent‚Äôs scale.

Some technology companies allow users to switch between map projections, but the Mercator remains the default on many services. A Google spokesperson told Hyperallergic that users can choose between it and globe views of the Earth on its desktop Google Maps interface. The Google Maps mobile app, however, uses the Mercator map, according to Reuters.

The Correct the Map campaign launched a petition calling for the United Nations and the British Broadcasting Company (BCC) to adopt the Equal Earth map, encouraging other organizations to follow suit. The petition had garnered nearly 7,000 signatures as of the time of publication.

‚ÄúThis distortion isn‚Äôt just a cartographic error ‚Äî it‚Äôs a narrative failure,‚Äù Correct the Map‚Äôs petition text reads. ‚ÄúIn a world where size is often equated with power, misrepresenting Africa‚Äôs true scale reinforces harmful misconceptions about its geopolitical and economic significance.‚Äù

title: Landmark Raphael Retrospective Is Coming to The Met
excerpt: ‚ÄúHow generous and kind Heaven sometimes proves to be,‚Äù mused Italian Renaissance artist and historian Giorgio Vasari, ‚Äúwhen it brings together in a single person the boundless riches of its treasures and all those graces and rare gifts that over a period of time are usually di‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‚ÄúHow generous and kind Heaven sometimes proves to be,‚Äù mused Italian Renaissance artist and historian Giorgio Vasari, ‚Äúwhen it brings together in a single person the boundless riches of its treasures and all those graces and rare gifts that over a period of time are usually divided among many individuals.‚Äù Writing in his foundational 1550 Lives of the Artists, Vasari was describing none other than Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino ‚Äî known as Raphael ‚Äî the High Renaissance titan who was, in his words, among our ‚Äúmortal gods.‚Äù

Though centuries have passed since this text was written, Raphael‚Äôs masterful synthesis of clarity, beauty, and harmony remains resonant, as evinced by the announcement of a major upcoming exhibition of the artist‚Äôs work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Raphael: Sublime Poetry, opening in the spring, will feature more than 200 drawings, paintings, tapestries, and decorative works by the illustrious artist in the first comprehensive international loan exhibition in the United States dedicated to his oeuvre.¬†

The show is set to include works from more than 20 private and public collections around the world, including the Vatican Museums, which holds Raphael‚Äôs iconic frescoes like ‚ÄúThe School of Athens‚Äù (1509‚Äì11); the Louvre in Paris; Uffizi Galleries in Florence; the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC; and Museo del Prado in Madrid. Seven years in the making, the show is curated by Carmen C. Bambach, an Italian Renaissance art scholar in the museum‚Äôs Department of Drawings and Prints who previously worked on The Met‚Äôs blockbuster exhibitions Leonardo da Vinci: Master Draftsman (2003) and

(2017‚Äì18).

Michelangelo: Divine Draftsman and Designer

Many of these pieces, The Met‚Äôs Director Max Hollein said in a statement, have never before been shown together ‚Äî making the exhibition an ‚Äúexceptionally rare opportunity‚Äù to explore the depth of Raphael‚Äôs artistry.

Raphael: Sublime Poetry will span the artist‚Äôs early years in Urbino to his untimely death at the age of 37 in Rome, tracing the development of his ideas and creative process across his lifetime in a roughly chronological order. Thematic presentations ‚Äî including recent scientific research, preparatory drawings, and a focus on his approach to portraying women ‚Äî will aim to contextualize Raphael‚Äôs practice in a new light.

Among the masterpieces on display will be Raphael‚Äôs oil portrait ‚ÄúPortrait of Baldassare Castiglione‚Äù (1514‚Äì16), which depicts the eponymous Italian diplomat in an intimate, soft lighting and striking, realistic detail, and his tender ‚ÄúVirgin and Child with Infant Saint John the Baptist in a Landscape (The Alba Madonna)‚Äù (1510), which showcases the artist‚Äôs expertise in color and balance.

Sublime Poetry will notably examine Raphael‚Äôs work through the lens of his ‚Äúunique artistic personality.‚Äù Vasari, in his extensive chapter on Raphael‚Äôs short but prolific life, praised not only the painter‚Äôs embodiment of Renaissance virtues but also his enviable social ease, which earned him friends, patrons, and the admiration of artists and assistants in his workshop.

‚ÄúNature created him as a gift to the world,‚Äù Vasari wrote. ‚ÄúAfter having been vanquished by art in the work of Michelangelo Buonarroti, it wished to be vanquished through Raphael by both art and moral habits as well.‚Äù

The show is slated to open on March 29 and run through June 28.

title: Amy Sherald Speaks Out on Cancelling Her Smithsonian Show
excerpt: Amy Sherald, the painter most widely known for her portrait of former First Lady Michelle Obama, detailed her decision to withdraw her exhibition from the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Portrait Gallery (NPG) amid concerns over censorship at the institution in a new opinion piece .
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Amy Sherald, the painter most widely known for her portrait of former First Lady Michelle Obama, detailed her decision to withdraw her exhibition from the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Portrait Gallery (NPG) amid concerns over censorship at the institution in a new opinion piece.

On MSNBC‚Äôs opinion blog last Sunday, August 24, Sherald condemned the Trump administration‚Äôs ongoing efforts to reshape the Smithsonian Institution, cautioning that it could ‚Äúrewrite‚Äù history.

‚ÄúWhen governments police museums, they are not simply policing exhibitions. They are policing imagination itself,‚Äù Sherald wrote in her opinion, titled ‚ÄúCensorship has taken hold at the Smithsonian. I refused to play along.‚Äù

The artist cancelled the NPG‚Äôs planned exhibition of her touring show, Amy Sherald: American Sublime, in July, claiming that she learned the institution was considering removing her painting ‚ÄúTrans Forming Liberty‚Äù (2024). The work envisions the Statue of Liberty as a Black trans woman, modeled after drag performer and musician Arew√† Basit, and graced the cover of the New Yorker earlier this month.

Hyperallergic)

Last week, the painting appeared in a 26-item list of artworks and exhibitions posted by the White House shortly after the administration demanded the Smithsonian hand over materials so that it could make ‚Äúcontent corrections.‚Äù In her essay, Sherald reiterated that she made the decision to pull her show from the NPG because of the institution‚Äôs ‚Äúattempted censorship of [her] painting.‚Äù (The institution has publicly¬†denied that it censored ‚ÄúTrans Forming Liberty,‚Äù and¬†told Hyperallergic in a statement that it ‚Äúcould not come to an agreement with the artist.‚Äù)

‚ÄúWhile no single person is to blame, it‚Äôs clear that institutional fear shaped by a broader climate of political hostility toward trans lives played a role,‚Äù Sherald wrote. ‚ÄúThis painting exists to hold space for someone whose humanity has been politicized and disregarded. I cannot in good conscience comply with a culture of censorship, especially when it targets vulnerable communities.‚Äù

Sherald also cited other moments of political interference in the Smithsonian‚Äôs history in her essay, including former President Woodrow Wilson‚Äôs insistence that the institution implement Jim Crow racial segregation during his presidency in line with his segregation of the federal government when he took office in 1913. Because the institution operates in a public-private arrangement, receiving funding from both federal and corporate sources, the Smithsonian resisted pressure from the White House.

But Sherald cautions that there have since been successful efforts to influence the content of the institution‚Äôs museums. A 2010 campaign by the right-wing Catholic League led the National Portrait Gallery to remove a video work by David Wojnarowicz depicting Jesus being eaten by ants, a commentary on the federal government‚Äôs homophobia and failure to take action during the HIV/AIDS epidemic.

In her essay, the artist invoked a quote by former Metropolitan Museum of Art Director Philippe de Montebello: ‚ÄúA museum is the memory of mankind.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf that is true, then to manipulate museums is to manipulate who we believe we are,‚Äù she wrote of the quote. ‚ÄúControl the memory and you control the future.‚Äù

title: The Artist Freeing Museums‚Äô Captive Instruments
excerpt: HAMBURG, Germany ‚Äî ‚ÄúOk, stop the cameras,‚Äù the head conservator commanded from the belly of the storage department. ‚ÄúI want to hear what these instruments sound like without Satch wearing the gloves.‚Äù The other assembled staff, seated in a scatter of folding chairs beneath the‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
HAMBURG, Germany ‚Äî ‚ÄúOk, stop the cameras,‚Äù the head conservator commanded from the belly of the storage department. ‚ÄúI want to hear what these instruments sound like without Satch wearing the gloves.‚Äù The other assembled staff, seated in a scatter of folding chairs beneath the MARKK ethnographic museum in Hamburg, lowered their phones and tucked them away.

These museum workers had gathered in the MARKK‚Äôs basement to oversee and document artist and musician Satch Hoyt ‚Äúun-mute‚Äù the African instrument collection, as he calls it. A masterful player of wind and percussion alike, Hoyt has been working to gain access to African instrument collections in colonial and ethnographic museums so that they may be played again. Within certain African diasporic traditions, some of these instruments are understood as tools to communicate with the creator and ancestors. Thus, this un-muting is not a mere symbolic act protesting the enforced dormancy of museum storage, but an affirmation of fluid continuity between the living and ancestral realms.

Surrounded by masks and statues in the dimly lit storage den, who seemed to be watching, Hoyt dispensed with the white archival gloves he had previously been instructed to wear. He then began, gently, to play a sanza.

‚ÄúAnd then,‚Äù Hoyt recalls, ‚ÄúIt was ‚Äî Pffuuumm, you could just feel the energy all of a sudden in the room.‚Äù Touching the instrument with bare skin invited a rush that the gloves had shielded. ‚ÄúThere was a feeling of gratitude,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúof ‚ÄòOh, cool ‚Äî somebody‚Äôs reactivating this instrument.‚Äô Somebody‚Äôs actually, finally returning it to its proper use.‚Äù Hoyt grinned. ‚ÄúIt was like they were going, ‚ÄòYeah, we needed to hear this‚Äô‚Äù ‚Äî¬†‚Äúthey,‚Äù in this case, referring not to the MARKK staff watching as he acquainted himself with the museum‚Äôs African instruments, but to the audience of masks and statues overhead.¬†‚ÄúIf it happens, you just feel it,‚Äù he said, referring to the rush of presence he feels when an instrument has been successfully ‚Äúun-muted.‚Äù As soon as you put your lips on the embouchure, a certain feeling happens‚Ä¶.‚Äù

Born in London in 1957 to an English mother and a Jamaican father, Hoyt‚Äôs early acculturation came at a time when the British Empire was in free fall, as many of its colonies, including Ghana, Nigeria, Kenya, and Uganda, had recently won their independence. Artists, intellectuals, and musicians of the African diaspora converged on the fallen and swinging capital, forging a new era of Pan-African thought. Hoyt‚Äôs early mentors were of this milieu, including the Trini filmmaker Horace Ov√© and the exiled South African jazz trumpeter and flautist Mongezi Feza. In Australia, he was embraced by the First Nations painters Clifford Possum, Turkey Tolson Tjupurrula, and Johnny Warangkula Tjupurrula. Later on in New York, he ran with the pioneering Afrofuturist MC and visual artist Rammellzee, as well as cultural critic and musician Greg Tate and the band Burnt Sugar the Arkestra Chamber. In Paris, he accompanied Louise Bourgeois on recordings of her poetry and composed for Grace Jones. His list of friends and collaborators is long and illustrious, but nowadays, Hoyt is increasingly focused on ancestral ties, and is coordinating recording dates in museum basements instead of commercial studios.¬†

The process of ‚Äúun-muting‚Äù first occurred to Hoyt in 2017 at the Berlin phonographic archive, while he was studying the wax cylinders that archaeologist Leo Frobenius recorded in the Congo a century before. Wax cylinder recordings typically feature a bed of unruly static, through which distant intimations of highs can be heard. The rest ‚Äî overtones, textural detail, any semblance of bass or mid-range frequencies ‚Äî is left to the imagination. Unsatisfied with daydreaming, Hoyt decided to cut a new path.

‚ÄúWith the phonographic recordings that Frobenius did, afterwards, he acquired the instruments that people had been playing. So, I thought, ‚ÄòWell, we‚Äôve got all of these instruments, which are in these ethnographic museums. I can play them. I‚Äôve collected them over years, and they should be sounded.‚Äô‚Äù

title: 5 Simple Ways to Be a Really Good Gift Giver
excerpt: There are people in my life who are the most wonderful gift givers‚Äîalways thoughtful, always unique, always spot-on. I‚Äôve learned some lessons from these friends and family members on how to be a really excellent gift giver, and I‚Äôm sharing them with you today. These gift-givi‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
There are people in my life who are the most wonderful gift givers‚Äîalways thoughtful, always unique, always spot-on. I‚Äôve learned some lessons from these friends and family members on how to be a really excellent gift giver, and I‚Äôm sharing them with you today. These gift-giving ideas apply to any occasion‚Äîfrom holidays to birthdays and every little celebration in between. Here‚Äôs to sharing meaningful gifts with the people we love.

People tell you what they love, and thoughtful gift-giving starts with listening in those moments. With everyone in my life, I‚Äôve been listening to what they say and tuning into what excites them. I keep an ear out for gift ideas all year round so I‚Äôm not rushing when the holidays (or birthdays) arrive.
Have they started a new hobby? Ask how it‚Äôs going and glean inspiration from there. Are they making a big transition into retirement or moving across the country? Listen for ways to help out, celebrate, or honor the milestone. The best gifts are the ones that show someone you notice the little things they‚Äôre loving or pursuing.¬†

Don‚Äôt count on yourself to remember the ideas you pick up through all of your listening. Figure out a way to collect the information and organize it. I mainly use the iPhone Notes app. Joe and I have a shared note with a list of the birthdays of people in our lives. Underneath each name, I‚Äôll write down thought starters for gifts and things I know they enjoy. I also save some ideas verbally in the Voice Memos app, which is an easy way to get ideas out of my head in the moment so I can revisit them later.

If you‚Äôre stuck, don‚Äôt be afraid to ask the person for a short list of exactly what they want. Some people shy away from being this direct or think it takes the magic out of gifting. I think it‚Äôs a perfectly reasonable way to ensure you‚Äôre giving a gift that will be used and enjoyed. When I ask for a list, I find the gifting experience just as enjoyable as when I think of gift ideas on my own. This leads me to my next point‚Ä¶

Don‚Äôt worry about coming up with the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù gift idea. You don‚Äôt have to surprise them with something unexpected either! Choosing a gift from their wish list is a wonderful way to delight them and get them something they really want. I got Joe a specific pair of shoes he asked for on his birthday, and his reaction was as if it was a total surprise. He was so excited!! It reminded me that true surprises are overrated sometimes.¬†

Watch out for the temptation to overcompensate, especially when you‚Äôre not sure what your giftee wants. When it comes to gift-giving, we often end up spending too much, which makes everyone uncomfortable. I think of the episode of The Office where Michael gave a video iPod in the group exchange when the spending limit was $20.¬†
Often, sentimental gifts mean as much (if not more) than costly items. For Joe‚Äôs birthday this year, I recorded a video about why I love him and the kids did too. It was a unique way to capture this moment in time and it didn‚Äôt cost a thing. If overcompensating is a pattern of yours, hopefully the ideas in this post will help you avoid it!¬†
For more gift-giving inspiration, I‚Äôll be sharing my holiday gift guide on Wit & Delight this month! Until then, browse last year‚Äôs gift guide to get the gift ideas flowing.

title: 7 of the Best Books I‚Äôve Read and Loved Lately
excerpt: Swapping favorite reads is my favorite form of social currency. I devoured some really special books this year and felt it was the right time to compile a list of the ones that stayed on my mind long after I read the last page. My criteria for what makes a read share-worthy ex‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Swapping favorite reads is my favorite form of social currency. I devoured some really special books this year and felt it was the right time to compile a list of the ones that stayed on my mind long after I read the last page. My criteria for what makes a read share-worthy extends beyond just liking the book. Many of these authors made me feel uncomfortable and squeamish, and that‚Äôs how I like it‚Äîbut that‚Äôs not to say I don‚Äôt enjoy an escapist book.
Today I‚Äôm sharing a short and incomplete list of the books I couldn‚Äôt stop talking about this year.

Ever heard of a ‚ÄúMessy Perfectionist‚Äù before? Katherine Morgan Schafler‚Äôs The Perfectionist‚Äôs Guide to Losing Control resonated with me deeply because it delves into the origins and complexities of perfectionism, offering a 360-degree perspective on the many ways it manifests itself. I found Schafler‚Äôs insights and personal anecdotes refreshing. She suggests we discard the label ‚Äúrecovering perfectionist‚Äù (one I have subscribed to) and instead look at perfectionism as a superpower to be harnessed for good rather than hold us back.¬†
I read this book twice this year and plan to pick it up again over the holiday break.

In Bittersweet, Susan Cain explores the concept of bittersweetness and how embracing both positive and negative emotions can lead to a richer and more fulfilling life. Through beautiful personal stories and research, Cain argues bittersweetness is an essential part of the human experience and that it can help us appreciate the beauty and fragility of life.
This book touched parts of myself I had long shuttered away as weird, sensitive, and something I should never express in public. Yet they‚Äôre so core to who I am. Susan Cain continues to be a champion for sensitive, quiet, deep thinkers.

Slowing is a guide to living a slower, more intentional life. It offers practical strategies for reducing stress, increasing mindfulness, and finding more joy in the present moment. This book is organized around the process of learning to slow down, which I found incredibly helpful. We can‚Äôt run before we can walk, and slowing down in adulthood is most definitely a learned skill.

A time-travel love story meets workplace comedy with the twists and turns of a spy thriller. This book defies genres and delighted me with its whip-smart prose and deeply human characters.

Everyone has an opinion about this book. I love it like I do a flawed but well-intentioned friend. I admire the creative choices July makes in all her work. Her willingness to leave things unapologetically messy and self-serving made her the perfect artist to crash into the public domain, shouting about the indignities of being a woman of a certain age. Post-childbearing deserves to take center stage and be seen. There‚Äôs something about that feeling of wildness that precisely captures the awakening I‚Äôve just started to experience, and I know I‚Äôm not alone.¬†
It is interesting to hear what people under the age of forty think about the book. They‚Äôre often wide-eyed, terrified, and turned off by its barbaric and messy nature. To them, I say, you‚Äôll get it when you‚Äôre ready.

This book is essential for anyone brave enough to take their creative expressions seriously. Turn to any page and find a reason to keep pursuing that nagging urge to make something meaningful from the mystery of intuition.

Like so many of you, the poem that made Maggie Smith famous came at the exact time I needed it most. This is the story of what happened to her marriage and career afterward.

title: How to Slow Down: 7 Ways I‚Äôm Slowing Down in a Busy Season of Life
excerpt: Your mind does interesting math as you get older. I get persistent nausea thinking about how fast the past twenty years flew by. Months before my 40th birthday last year, I kept doing the calculation: If the next twenty years go as fast as the last, then I‚Äôm already sixty‚Äîwhic‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Your mind does interesting math as you get older. I get persistent nausea thinking about how fast the past twenty years flew by. Months before my 40th birthday last year, I kept doing the calculation:¬†
If the next twenty years go as fast as the last, then I‚Äôm already sixty‚Äîwhich means I‚Äôm basically already eighty.
Time x Speed = Life
I felt like a life-sized cardboard cutout of the new millennial midlife crisis.¬†
To my horror, I continued to write through my disorientation. I felt like a woman walking the plank. Everyone told me life was just beginning, but I couldn‚Äôt shake the feeling it was slipping through my fingers each day‚Äîand I was powerless to stop it.¬†

We were told we could be anyone and anything we wanted.¬†
But the options are endless, and time is limited.
It‚Äôll never add up to enough.

Facing what my math revealed about myself, and the truth of time and speed, I saw my crisis was telling me how I wanted to spend the rest of my life. So I put on my big girl pants, turned toward the secrets I had tucked neatly under my pillow at night, and let them into the light.

You have everything you need within you.
You are whole. You are enough.
I was not in despair over a decline into obscurity. I craved an experience I had denied myself. Life wasn‚Äôt about surviving and becoming. It was about being whole and feeling human and making room for joy, desire, delight, pleasure, connection, love, and wonderment.¬†
Life was just beginning‚Äîand I was learning to slow down and enjoy it.¬†

Amid this call for slowness, my life is speeding up. There will never be a busier season of life than this one. My kids are blossoming into themselves, and with this comes friends, hobbies, sports, and memories to be made as a family. Joe is stepping into a season of his career where he wants to test his limits, grow into himself, and see what‚Äôs possible when he taps into his talent.¬†
And me. I find myself today overflowing with energy to put into the world.¬†
What does one do when the fullness of life threatens to sweep away the ability to savor life itself?¬†
I‚Äôve been making strides to slow down daily, even when everything is swirling around me. I‚Äôve started small, with the tiniest adjustments. Today, I‚Äôm writing about why slowing down matters so much to me and how I‚Äôm practicing slowness in this busy season of life.

I‚Äôm tired. That was one of the big secrets I had tucked under my pillow. Life is busy and I don‚Äôt have the energy to puff myself up and cheerlead anymore. What I can do, however, is slow down enough to notice when I need rest.¬†
The dichotomy of being bone tired and having a renewed sense of purpose in life is fascinating. It‚Äôs like learning to tame a new kind of beast, one that responds to tenderness rather than domineering, alpha-like control. Life is busy, getting things done matters, and enjoyment matters, too. So what does the balance look like? How is slowing down even possible in a busy season of life?
I don‚Äôt have a perfect system. But I am not willing to go back to ‚Äúkeeping up‚Äù or feeling a pervasive sense of lack. Instead, I have a values-based approach, a willingness to keep practicing these habits, and a lot of forgiveness for myself. Because I‚Äôm tired. And I‚Äôm alive.¬†

When I‚Äôm rushing through life, I‚Äôve noticed my pace is reflected through physical cues in my body. A few examples include:

In practicing slowness, the most important thing for me is to notice and gently redirect these physical responses. I unclench my jaw, take a few slow, deep breaths, loosen my grip on the wheel, and sit up straight with relaxed shoulders. Keep in mind that your physical responses to busyness may look different than mine. Tune into what they are for you and slowly begin to redirect them.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
40th reunion. 40. How did she get so old so fast? She was popular and had plans. A ‚Äúmost likely to‚Ä¶‚Äù type. Succeed. Be on TV. Own a beach house in La Jolla. She did none of that and didn‚Äôt want any of that, but the party at Penmar Golf Course ‚Äî $100 for hors d‚Äôoeuvres with an open bar ‚Äî has her feeling jittery, thinking about what might have been. Most likely to become a clich√© is more like it. She kept the yearbook, Venice High 1985, and opens it periodically to reconcile it with what she sees in the mirror. She‚Äôs not entirely unhappy. Her hair is still blonde, no bangs glued straight with gel! Her blue eyes look tired now but mascara helps. And she‚Äôs bigger, like everyone else. But her tits look good, even better than back when she survived on diet coke and Marlboro lights. She will not take Ozempic, at least just yet, like her friends. No Botox either but she knows it‚Äôs just a matter of time. Everything is just a matter of time.

She looks at the scrawl on the back page ‚Äî ‚ÄúMy one regret: not asking you out‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî from the skinny kid with the big nose and curly mop, the one who became a writer. She probably would have said no but as the years go by, she‚Äôs developed an abstract crush on him. She‚Äôs followed his career, read a story here and there, a blog where he talks about his divorce. Divorce! When she read that, she got a tingle. She‚Äôs married and living a perfectly fine, decent, good life. But knowing he‚Äôs free out there is fun, harmless; she smiles mischievously when she sees his name on the rsvp list. She knows her husband would have no interest so she buys one ticket.

What will she wear? A teal linen dress, tan flats, simple; she remembers he was short so she doesn‚Äôt want to tower over him but she does wear a push up bra so a little cleavage shows, casually, like she didn‚Äôt mean it, her boobs are so big she can‚Äôt help it kind of thing. She puts the yearbook in the large leather bag she inherited from her recently dead mother. She is hoping that maybe, after a cocktail, she could get him to sign it again, let him know that she‚Äôs followed his career, hint that it‚Äôs not too late though for what she doesn‚Äôt know. She feels reckless. Giddy.

He looks different, bald now, a graying overgrown goatee; they all have changed, but she recognizes him from his author photos so she walks up, tipsy, and says, ‚ÄúHey Nathan!‚Äù and he says, ‚ÄúHi!‚Äù as he squints at the name tag pinned to her chest with a picture from high school on it. She says, ‚ÄúMallory. We went to high school together!‚Äù and he says, ‚ÄúI think all of us here did!‚Äù And they laugh, she can feel her face reddening from the tequila, she‚Äôs half a margarita in. He says he doesn‚Äôt remember her and she pauses. It‚Äôs too late to run away so she pulls out the yearbook, flips to the back, points at the exact words he wrote. ‚ÄúYou wanted to ask me out but never did!‚Äù and he says, ‚ÄúHuh, that sounds about right.‚Äù And she says, ‚ÄúWhy not? Why didn‚Äôt you Nathan?‚Äù thinking that using his name will create some intimacy and he says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù but he is charming enough now to say, ‚ÄúI was an asshole for not trying‚Äù in a tone that is more polite than flirtatious.

title: SCARCITY ‚Ä¢ Ian Mahm
excerpt: My prehistoric grandmother, exemplar of Generation W (W for Waste), shamelessly threw away new, unopened packets of Tico‚Äôs Tacos ‚Äúsizzlin‚Äô hot‚Äù salsa.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
My prehistoric grandmother, exemplar of Generation W (W for Waste), shamelessly threw away new, unopened packets of Tico‚Äôs Tacos ‚Äúsizzlin‚Äô hot‚Äù salsa.

Decades later I‚Äôm haggling with squatters to excavate Tico‚Äôs Tacos ‚Äúsizzlin‚Äô hot‚Äù salsa packets from garbage dumps. I showcase the packets alongside similarly excavated fast food detritus‚Äîstyrofoam packaging, plastic cups and lids, faded wax-paper wrappers‚Äîall lovingly collected in a gallery behind glass. We‚Äôre rabidly nostalgic for these sorts of things because the Tico‚Äôs Tacos chain, like every fast food chain, no longer exists. Some of its architecture survives, such as dilapidated sombrero rooftops once neon-lit, and Tico the Cat statues waving hola from atop tumbledown signage. But mostly, reminders of the before times have vanished.

I curate Portals to the Past on Mission St, inside the protected Zone. The gallery is three blocks east of the checkpoint, a razor-wire interface between us and the hungry world. Lately the hungry have been trying to breach our razor-wire. My contact, Zook, the squatter who led the most recent excavation for me‚Äîhe claims the hungry are planning to attack again in three nights, the same goddamned night as my Tico‚Äôs Tacos exhibition opening.

‚ÄúYou should delay your party,‚Äù old Zook says, smelling of urine. We‚Äôre just outside the checkpoint.

‚ÄúWhy are you telling me about this?‚Äù

‚ÄúTelling you about what.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe attack.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause, young lady, I like you. You give me work.‚Äù His toothless grin seems lecherous. I ignore it.

We finish our transaction: one box of ancient and interesting restaurant condiments in exchange for one box of jackets and boots. Then Zook‚Äôs limping off into the smoky urban wilds beyond the checkpoint.

It‚Äôll be sundown soon. Portable flood lights flicker on. Security sentries inspect my ID, rush me back through the gate to safety, and I traipse down an empty Mission St sidewalk towards the gallery, eager to examine my box of treasure. But Zook‚Äôs claim about the attack irritates me. If he‚Äôs correct, my soir√©e will be a bust. People will be too afraid to come.

Dean phones as I pass the old California Shakes coffee shop. ‚ÄúDid Zook get anything good?‚Äù he says.

‚ÄúWe have a problem. He insisted there‚Äôs going to be‚Ä¶.‚Äù I stop myself, realizing I‚Äôm likely the only one in the Zone who‚Äôs aware of this supposed attack. Saying nothing will guarantee that people can attend the soir√©e. ‚ÄúActually, never mind.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever mind what.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúUm, okay, so about the Ranger Rick cups, I wasn‚Äôt able to fully clean them. There‚Äôs smoke damage‚Ä¶.‚Äù Dean updates me on this and more, but I‚Äôm distracted, conflicted about whether I should alert Security. It‚Äôd be the right thing to do. However, I‚Äôve been working on this exhibition for months, putting so much care into it. And I really need the business. And further, Zook could be mistaken; maybe the attack is mere rumor.

‚ÄúGotta go, Dean.‚Äù I disconnect the call.

The gallery is wedged between a dental clinic and a market. To the east loom unoccupied green-glass skyscrapers‚Äîstilled giants, generals without wars. As always there‚Äôs not much traffic on the once-busy thoroughfare; the absence of activity creates vacuous silence and loneliness, but I‚Äôm used to it. Earlier in the day I‚Äôd unlocked and raised the gallery‚Äôs steel shielding, hoping that rare passersby might pause and admire my window display. Presently I‚Äôm touched to see an attractive young man viewing the display, a menagerie of plastic rainbow straws, remnants of a Bloopee franchise. Above the straws hangs a neat hand-lettered sign advertising my Tico‚Äôs Tacos opening.

‚ÄúYou should come!‚Äù I place Zook‚Äôs box on the sidewalk, then gesture up at the sign.

The attractive young man smiles a gleaming smile, stares at my breasts, says, ‚ÄúLooks interesting,‚Äù which pisses me off, not because of his ogling but rather because I remember the supposed attack and its repercussions for my soir√©e. ‚ÄúYes, it will be interesting,‚Äù I say, flirtatiously nibbling my lower lip, concluding that old Zook is full of shit, that the attack is indeed rumor and nothing more.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In this excerpt of her new book, Greyhound: A Memoir, Joanna Pocock reflects on bus travel as a communal and environmentally friendly option over personal vehicles, one that, in a small way, defies an America that is designed for and prizes the privacy and freedom of cars and trucks above public transportation.

Greyhound buses feel like part of an overlooked ecosystem. One that uses less fuel and spews less CO2 into the air than individual cars. The space they create is a rare one: an environment where strangers are connected by the simple need to get somewhere. You can‚Äôt buy anything on a bus (like you can on a plane or train), you can‚Äôt upgrade either ‚Äì you‚Äôre all in it together. As more and more public places become privatized, I feel there is a fragility to this sort of space. The Greyhound is more library than shopping mall, more community centre than curated retail space. In our post-Covid world, these vehicles also remind us of a before-time when we could sit maskless in our Greyhound bubbles, rubbing shoulders with strangers, safely breathing alongside each other without fear. They might yet become symbols for a way we once lived in each other‚Äôs presence.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
At Disney World, the magic doesn‚Äôt unfold the same way for everyone. In his essay, Daniel Currell places two families in sharp relief: one stumbling through a gauntlet of 6 a.m. wake-up calls, app alerts, and frantic booking scrambles; the other drifting effortlessly from ride to ride, their day smoothed by money. The contrast is stark and telling. A park once imagined as a democratic playground for American families has hardened into a stratified experience, a theme-park parable of the country‚Äôs widening inequality. The fairy tale endures‚Äîbut only for those who can afford it.

When you are at a Disney park, you will inevitably hear ‚ÄúWhen You Wish Upon a Star,‚Äù Disney‚Äôs unofficial anthem. Disney adopted that song in the 1940s; its second line, ‚Äúmakes no difference who you are,‚Äù encapsulated its egalitarian ethos. Now the song reads to me like nostalgic, middle-class cosplay that helps us relive the Disney that Walt created. The roughly $90 to get your family cut-the-line access to a premier ride (on top of what, for a family of four, could easily be over $700 dropped on tickets already) is the real Disney, the one the market created.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When Laurie Abraham was diagnosed with colon cancer 14 months ago, she realized just how taboo pooping is as a topic of conversation. In particular, women pooping. As she went through treatment, Abraham navigated an array of awkward conversations and personal revelations, which she details in a witty, illuminating essay for The Cut:

How deep did my own aversion to the scatological run? I think back: When other moms got their toddlers the classic

Everyone Poops,I was like, ‚ÄúDo we have to?‚Äù (We didn‚Äôt.) As an 8-year-old, my younger daughter, Tess, liked to lope around the house yelling, ‚ÄúPoop, poop in your face!‚Äù I laughed when, at 3, she‚Äôd begun riding her rocking horse full tilt, clad only in a little black cowboy hat. I laughed when, at the same age, Edie, her older sister, told her father to ‚Äúclose the fucking window‚Äù during a drive. It‚Äôs not like I couldn‚Äôt handle taboo subjects. Yet every timepooptripped off Tess‚Äôs tongue, I‚Äôd exclaim, ‚ÄúStop! Tess!‚Äù My face would contort. It contorts as I‚Äôm writing this.

It may be partly a generational difference; my now 21- and 25-year-old daughters still will announce their specific bathroom plans‚Äî

ladies, please.But the location of my cancer must be part of its befoulment. Susan Sontag is famous for exposing the negative cultural stories that cling to cancer, but what is the lowest of the low? ‚ÄúIn the hierarchy of the body‚Äôs organs, lung cancer is felt to be less shameful than rectal cancer,‚Äù she asserted inIllness As Metaphor.I also felt a shock of recognition at her observation that while tuberculosis, the other focus of her book, is linked to ‚Äúdelicacy, sensitivity ‚Ä¶ and powerlessness,‚Äù cancer represents ‚Äúwhatever seem[s] ruthless, implacable, predatory.‚Äù

See, colon cancer is unfeminine! (Yes, she was talking cancer in general, but the point stands.) Even the medical Establishment has spread that message. Two of the younger female patients I interviewed said doctors explicitly told them colon cancer is an ‚Äúold white man‚Äôs disease,‚Äù even though it‚Äôs only slightly more prevalent in men than in women.

More broadly, colons and what comes out of them are the permitted playground of men. Delightfully, there is a whole body of research that backs this up. Bathroom graffiti is more plentiful and crap-filled in men‚Äôs toilet stalls than in women‚Äôs, according to a psychology professor named Nick Haslam. The author of

Psychology in the Bathroom,he cites a study in which a ‚Äúfemale experimenter who excused herself to use the bathroom was evaluated more negatively than one who excused herself to get some paperwork.‚Äù When a male experimenter repeated the exercise, the judginess vanished. A college student surveyed for a journal article titled ‚ÄúFecal Matters: Habitus, Embodiments, and Deviance‚Äù summed up the situation: ‚ÄúWomen are supposed to be non-poopers.‚Äù

Resurfacing from the¬†Aeon¬†archive, Katherine Harvey‚Äôs 2018 essay marked her first in-depth exploration of medieval sex‚Äîa journey that later blossomed into her book, ‚ÄúThe Fires of Lust.‚Äù This upfront piece studies medieval Europe‚Äôs startlingly frank approach to the dangers of sex. Too much sex was dangerous, and too little sex could outright kill you. Quite the ride!

Medieval physicians saw too much sex as a real medical concern. Conventional wisdom held that several noblemen died of sexual excess. John of Gaunt, the 14th-century first duke of Lancaster, allegedly ‚Äòdied of putrefaction of his genitals and body, caused by the frequenting of women, for he was a great fornicator‚Äô. Today, his symptoms would suggest venereal disease, but his contemporaries would probably have seen parallels with the case of Ralph, count of Vermandois. This 12th-century French nobleman had recently married his third wife when he fell seriously ill. During his convalescence, he was advised by his physician that he must abstain from intercourse, but disregarded this warning. When the doctor detected from Ralph‚Äôs urine that he had done so, he advised him to set his house in order, for he would be dead within three days ‚Äì a prognosis that proved to be accurate.

excerpt: In New Zealand, there‚Äôs a candy assortment of gangs. Most often, they ride on motorcycles, deal in narcotics, prostitution, illegal guns and fear. Recruitment‚Äôs booming as New Zealand‚Äôs underpaid police scarper to Australia, and dysfunctional kids clamber up the criminal caree‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In New Zealand, there‚Äôs a candy assortment of gangs. Most often, they ride on motorcycles, deal in narcotics, prostitution, illegal guns and fear. Recruitment‚Äôs booming as New Zealand‚Äôs underpaid police scarper to Australia, and dysfunctional kids clamber up the criminal career ladder.

As a court bailiff, John Brady thought he‚Äôd seen them all: Mongrel Mob, Head Hunters, Tribesmen, Killer Beez, Black Power, you name it. But these days there was a new gang hitting the courts with increasing regularity: Grey Power.

Today, he was in charge of Edith Smith, aged eighty-five. She was on so much medication it was hard to keep track of; pills for rheumatoid arthritis, underactive thyroid, high blood pressure, fluid retention, probiotics, magnesium (‚Äúkeeps your stools soft‚Äù), and so much more. It takes her an age to swallow them all. She has to use a walker to get into court and John helps her to the dock.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a good boy, John,‚Äù she says, looking at him with rheumy eyes. She reminds John of his grandma. Yet this little ol‚Äô lady is apparently in charge of the most notorious gang in the country.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll be right, Edith,‚Äù he says and gives her a small smile.

‚ÄúAll rise for His Honourable Judge Adams.‚Äù

‚ÄúEdith, you‚Äôre meant to stand,‚Äù whispers John.

‚ÄúStand? I‚Äôve only just sat down. Bugger that.‚Äù

‚ÄúCourt is in session, Crown versus Edith Smith.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a first appearance, and Edith is facing a raft of charges. The prosecution alleges that Edith is the mastermind behind some of the most infamous crimes reported in New Zealand. The ‚Äúheadless chicken‚Äù where a known paedophile was mangled by a pensioner‚Äôs mobility scooter. The ‚Äúrolled-over-Rowan‚Äù, a repeat rapist out on a technicality who met his demise under a pensioner‚Äôs Rolls Royce. And the ‚Äúupsa-Daisy‚Äù where a woman who had scammed millions out of the elderly was found dead, floating upside down in a pensioner‚Äôs duck pond. In each case, the pensioners involved claimed, ‚ÄúIt was an accident‚Äù, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have my glasses on‚Äù, ‚ÄúMy hearing aids weren‚Äôt plugged in‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got dementia, dear‚Äù and all were let off the hook.

Edith lets out a little chuckle as each one is mentioned. ‚ÄúOOhh, that was a good one,‚Äù she says at the upsa-Daisy. ‚ÄúI remember that one.‚Äù

John sighs. This is not boding well.

‚ÄúDoes the defendant have counsel?‚Äù asks the Judge.

‚ÄúEdith, he‚Äôs speaking to you,‚Äù whispers John.

‚ÄúWhat?! Speak up, young man.‚Äù

The Judge shouts across the courtroom, ‚ÄúI SAID, DO YOU HAVE COUNSEL?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo need to yell. I‚Äôm not deaf. You just need to enunciate your words better.‚Äù

John had never seen Judge Adams do an eye roll before today.

‚ÄúYour Honour, we understand Ms Smith has declined counsel,‚Äù says the prosecution trying to be helpful.

‚ÄúMs Smith, is that true?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre talking about that pimple-faced boy, fresh out of law school, I thought I might do a better job myself.‚Äù

‚ÄúMs Smith, these are serious charges you‚Äôre facing, and the prosecution has already indicated they‚Äôre opposed to bail. It‚Äôs in your best interests to have counsel represent you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said all along, I‚Äôve done nothing wrong. All I do is operate a Garden Club for like-minded pensioners. We like to do a bit of collective weeding.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour Honour, I must interject. A search of Ms Smith‚Äôs home produced copious evidence pointing to the Garden Club being a front for illegal activities where Ms Smith and her associates seem to have taken it upon themselves to mete out their own form of justice.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike I said, we do a spot of weeding.‚Äù

‚ÄúMs Smith, I‚Äôm going to take a half-hour break. During that time I urge you to instruct counsel. Court‚Äôs adjourned.‚Äù The Judge slams down his gavel, a tad too enthusiastically.

‚ÄúA bit tetchy, isn‚Äôt he, John?‚Äù says Edith.

‚ÄúEdith, let me help you find a lawyer.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you worry, pet. It‚Äôll be all right. Anyone would think our Garden Club was doing something wrong with all the fuss.‚Äù

John couldn‚Äôt believe what he was hearing.

‚ÄúEdith, it is wrong. You can‚Äôt‚Ä¶‚Äù

title: IRREPLACEABLE ‚Ä¢ Fiona Murray
excerpt: After our boss quit the senior executives replaced him with a coffee machine. They said that the consultant had delivered his report and that the replacement was appropriate and cost effective.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
After our boss quit the senior executives replaced him with a coffee machine. They said that the consultant had delivered his report and that the replacement was appropriate and cost effective.

Each morning we gathered around the shiny appliance and said good morning. We even gave it a name which someone printed out from the label maker and pressed tenderly against the metal: ‚ÄúSean.‚Äù

We poured in the beans lovingly and caressed the button and smiled as Sean internally alchemized them into the fragrant liquor that poured lusciously from the vents. Motivation improved. Team morale was at an all-time high.

Sean brought the team together in ways that we hadn‚Äôt experienced before. In those soft moments just before he ground the beans sometimes someone would be compelled to share something from deep within their private self.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I love my second child.‚Äù Said Linda, who usually only spoke about payroll.

‚ÄúI think my erectile dysfunction is somehow linked to being jealous of my wife.‚Äù Said Brad, from IT, who usually never responded to people‚Äôs emails.

At the end of financial year staff evaluation survey we all gave Sean the highest appraisal. He was an irreplaceable part of the office ‚Äì able to inspire us to the highest level of performance, help us realize our potential and foster consistent outputs.

We kept gathering around him every morning, collaborating and ideating freely.

Someone even worked out how to put little electronic inspirational messages on his display:

‚ÄúBe the change you want to see in the office.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour attitude is determined by your altitude.‚Äù

But after a while one of the executives grew suspicious of Sean and felt he was going outside his scope. The executive decided to put him back in his place and one sad morning we arrived to find Sean had been redeployed to the building manager‚Äôs office.

We were bereft and aimless for a time, until the boss told us a new addition would be arriving soon to bring the team culture back to an optimum level. He said he had recently read a book about how to foster collegiality for productivity and was keen to implement his learnings.

Then she arrived ‚Äì shiny and new looking like a picture of perfection. She was a sparkling new toasted sandwich maker. Her name was Sharon.

As we pressed her lever down gently, the ripples of satisfaction were palpable through the team. Morale was having an uptick. Sitting around eating the toasted sandwiches, we all basked in the sensation of a hug from a mother that we never had.

We were sluggish with carbs, too contented to complain about anything, so after nodding to each other cordially we went methodically back to our tasks.

Fiona Murray is a writer and social worker living in the Blue Mountains, west of Sydney.

If you want to keep EDF around, Patreon is the answer.
