After four months alcohol-free, I started my ‚Äúsoberish‚Äù chapter in early March. It began as unceremoniously as it ended‚Äîno dramatic moment, just a quiet shift. Since then, it‚Äôs been going well: a drink or two a week. Dinner parties now wrap up with one glass of wine, a feat I never thought possible.

What‚Äôs made this shift feel manageable is knowing why I want a drink when I do‚Äîand finding something else that gives me exactly what I was looking for. That part surprised me. Because I‚Äôve realized, not drinking is actually easier than only sometimes drinking. Gray areas are squishy. And what I‚Äôve learned in the squish is this: What I want when I crave a drink usually isn‚Äôt alcohol. It‚Äôs a moment to unwind. To relax. To savor something lovingly prepared.
Now, my favorite nonalcoholic drinks are staples in my house. I reach for them more often than wine. Going dry for four months taught me that the desire to drink was almost always a desire to treat myself, soften the day, and feel a little bit held. And it turns out, I can do all of that‚Äîwithout alcohol.

If you are craving a cocktail, this is the best alternative I‚Äôve found out there! I drank these through holiday parties and didn‚Äôt miss my beloved martinis once I found them.

Oh, my other beloved drink! I love all flavors of Ghia, but my favorites are the Sumac & Chili and Lime & Salt.

My friend Peder co-founded this NA brand, and it‚Äôs a gorgeous bottle worthy of dinner parties or special occasions. The main ingredient is pine tea (made from local white pine)‚Äîit‚Äôs spunky, fresh, and perfect in warm weather.

A genuinely delicious beer. I like the Upside Dawn Golden and Free Wave Hazy IPA.¬†

I recently tried a sampler pack of these Minneapolis NA craft beers and would highly recommend it for hosting a party. There is something for everyone!

This is a solid light and fresh beer that is sold pretty much everywhere these days. It‚Äôs great with food and on a hot summer day.

I drink these when I crave sparkling water; they‚Äôre so good! I‚Äôm not big on sweet drinks, so this earthy, fizzy drink is a real thirst quencher. It also feels special, which is really what I‚Äôm looking for when I want a drink. Something that feels like a treat, a little break in the day-to-day.

This is the drink I mix up for friends and family who aren‚Äôt into beer. It‚Äôs also what I make for myself when I want a drink after a long day and an NA beer just isn‚Äôt calling to me. I‚Äôve shared my desire to be a better gift giver over the years, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs an ongoing process. Mother‚Äôs Day is on Sunday, May 11, and I‚Äôve found that 90% of being a better gift giver is planning well ahead of time. So today I‚Äôm reminding you to get those gifts squared away, and offering my personal favorite Mother‚Äôs Day gift ideas (including a few that don‚Äôt cost a thing).
If you want to get extra personal, ask mom for her own wish list‚Äîor ask her best friend to spill the details on what products she‚Äôs been talking about lately. You can never go wrong with a personalized gift picked just for her.

I have a note from Bennett‚Äôs preschool teacher I‚Äôve been meaning to frame for five years now!¬†Framing can feel like a chore because of all the decisions that have to be made, from selecting what to frame to figuring out the best way to display it.
Framebridge is my favorite place for creative inspiration, and they can frame just about anything. One way to hit it out of the park with any mom is to frame a memento she‚Äôs saved and cherishes but hasn‚Äôt done anything with yet.

I don‚Äôt know one mother who isn‚Äôt thinking about environmental health these days. Give the gift of safe cookware, especially if mom has a particular pot or pan she‚Äôs been wanting to replace. It‚Äôs an upgrade she‚Äôll appreciate.

Putting a Lunya silk sleep mask on signals ‚Äúoff duty‚Äù mode. I have one of these masks, and I immediately exhale once it hits my eyes. It‚Äôs a hit with Joe too‚Äîwe often have to trade off who gets to wear it at night.

Book a sitter (or be the sitter yourself) and block off a day on her calendar to do whatever she wants, wherever she wants. Feel like a hero.

As my kids get older, I associate their uniqueness with what lights them up. A bracelet with icons and symbols that represent the whole family would be a really special way to celebrate the family you‚Äôve created together. Etsy has a ton of create-your-own options.

These are such great, high-quality tees‚Äîthe perfect basic clothing item. They‚Äôre structured enough to hold their shape over time but still feel perfectly relaxed. If the mom you are buying for is practical and discerning, Kule will be a hit.

When I was at Esalen last month, I tried an amazing body oil I can‚Äôt stop thinking about. I would rarely treat myself to it, but it would make such a luxurious gift.

I love the idea of a creative gift that kids and dad can make together. One idea: Have each kid make a portrait of mom to display when she wakes up. Another: Write little messages to mom on colorful paper, roll them into little scrolls, and place them in a hand-painted wooden chest.¬†

Indoor plants are a great gift for anyone who loves to exercise their green thumb. If she loves to garden, get her a perennial plant. Even better, make it a ritual that grows over time, each year adding something new to the garden. Don‚Äôt be shy in asking her what plants she loves the most.¬†

Removing some of her mental load is an amazing gift to give mom. I have the Hearth Display‚Äîit‚Äôs an incredible way to keep track of everything our family has going on, all in one place. If you get a gift like this, be sure to own the initial set-up process too, so it‚Äôs not one more thing that has to be on mom‚Äôs plate!

Any luxurious upgrade to an everyday staple will be a winner. Cashmere socks are the ultimate little luxury. You can find a wide range of pricing, from Comme Si (with amazing colors) to J.Crew, which has pretty good sale prices on their cashmere-blend socks.¬†

title: Next Level Dialogue: How to Make Your Characters Speak With Power & Purpose
excerpt: The purpose of dialogue is consistently underestimated by writers. This in turn saps its power in many spec screenplays and unpublished novels.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
NEWSFLASH: Dialogue Needs Power & Purpose!

The purpose of dialogue is consistently underestimated by writers. This in turn saps its power in many spec screenplays and unpublished novels.

Yet dialogue is one of the most powerful tools in a writer‚Äôs arsenal when done right. But too often it‚Äôs done wrong ‚Ä¶ This means dialogue may end up feeling cheesy, expositional or even downright cringey.

So, how to avoid this on our novels and screenplays? I‚Äôve dug deep to put dialogue under the microscope ‚Ä¶ ready? Let‚Äôs go!

1) Understand The Purpose Of Dialogue

Many authors and screenwriters misunderstand the purpose of dialogue. They may believe that good dialogue is about ‚Äòquoteability‚Äô (especially in movies), or that it‚Äôs just supposed to make characters ‚Äòsound different‚Äô.

These are a good start, but surface-level. Good dialogue helps tell the story. But what does this mean, especially if we don‚Äôt want our scripts and novels to be dialogue-led? Well, we need to realise the purpose of dialogue is four-fold:

  • It should help advance the plot.Many writers are so afraid of #4 on this list they go out of their way NOT to have any plot stuff in dialogue at all. As a result, it‚Äôs hard to understand the significance of various moments of dialogue. Oops! Never forget that. You will need some to tell the story!exposition is JUST the background information needed to understand what is going on
  • Plus it should reveal character.There‚Äôs nothing wrong with having characters speak in ways unique to them. However, if your supporting characters are speaking too much and taking over, that‚Äôs a problem. Equally, if your protagonist or antagonist has nothing ‚Äòabout them‚Äô, they will fade into the background. Dialogue can be a great tool here.
  • Dialogue should also convey emotion. Again, emotions are important and there‚Äôs nothing wrong with having characters be emotional this way. Plus don‚Äôt forget some genres (such as romance) or audiences (such as young adults) will WANT more emotional dialogue.
  • It should deliver the necessary exposition. This is where many writers fall down. When dialogue becomes too literal, too on-the-nose, or spoon-feeds the audience, it turns into the dreaded ‚Äòexpositional dialogue.‚Äô

B2W TAKEWAY: Dialogue is never ‚Äòjust‚Äô talking. It helps build the characters and tell the story.

2) Exposition: Use Sparingly and Strategically!

As mentioned above, expositional dialogue isn‚Äôt inherently bad. Sometimes it‚Äôs necessary, especially for big reveals or clarifying ambiguity. It‚Äôs an over-reliance on expositional dialogue in your screenplay or novel that is the red flag!

Chains of explanatory lines or filler conversations kill momentum. A good way of spotting this in your spec screenplay or novel is when you‚Äôre writing very, very little description.

B2W TAKEAWAY: If your characters are only talking to inform the audience, you‚Äôre doing it wrong. Instead, blend information into action, character behaviour or conflict.

3) Naturalistic vs Stylised Dialogue

This is one predominantly for screenwriters, though novelists may need to make a decision too. While this element may follow ‚Äòfashions‚Äô (we‚Äôre currently in a space that values naturalistic dialogue), writers still need to decide where their script or novel sits on the spectrum ‚Ä¶

  • Naturalistic Dialoguemimics real-life speech patterns. It‚Äôs grounded and often subtle.
  • Stylised Dialogueis heightened, deliberate, and often reflects the writer‚Äôs unique voice. Think Joss Whedon, Stephen King or Diablo Cody here.

B2W TAKEAWAY: Both have their place. The key is consistency and intention. Choose what serves the story, not what sounds cool.

4) Subtext and Foreshadowing

Great dialogue isn‚Äôt just about what‚Äôs said ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs about what‚Äôs unsaid. Subtext allows characters to talk about one thing while really addressing something deeper. This adds richness and realism, tying into both plot and character arcs.

A good example of subtext in a famous movie would be Miles‚Äô monologue about Pinot in the award-winning drama . He is not talking about wine at all, but himself and how he is fundamentally misunderstood.¬†

Sideways

Similarly, foreshadowing through dialogue hints at what‚Äôs to come. When done well, it builds tension and anticipation. Combine this with set up/pay off techniques for maximum narrative impact.

title: Happy Pride Month! Top 10 Queer Women In Movies And TV
excerpt: It‚Äôs Pride month, which means queer representation is on the menu here at Bang2write. My Top 10 female character rundowns are super-popular on this site, yet I realised I don‚Äôt have any about queer women.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Top 10 Queer Women

It‚Äôs Pride month, which means queer representation is on the menu here at Bang2write. My Top 10 female character rundowns are super-popular on this site, yet I realised I don‚Äôt have any about queer women.

Oops! Consider my wrist slapped for this massive oversight. But before I share my faves, a disclaimer of sorts.

‚ÄúiT‚Äôs gAy NoT qUeEr!!‚Äù

Okay, let‚Äôs get one thing straight (arf). Yes, some older members of the LGBTQ+ community still find the word ‚Äòqueer‚Äô painful. For them, it brings back memories of the word being weaponised in the ‚Äô80s.

That hurt is real and valid. That hurt matters. You won‚Äôt find me saying otherwise, because words are powerful.

But here‚Äôs the thing: it was also reclaimed back then. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre here, we‚Äôre queer, get used to it!‚Äù wasn‚Äôt just a slogan; it was a statement of defiance. A turning point.

But today, ‚Äòqueer‚Äô is how many younger LGBTQ+ people choose to identify. It‚Äôs broad. It‚Äôs flexible. It fits.

If you still don‚Äôt like the word, that‚Äôs totally your prerogative. But this article is probably not for you. (That‚Äôs okay, not every single article on a blog will be. Catch you next time!).

Still here? Great! Here‚Äôs ten queer women in the spotlight this Pride Month. Ready? Let‚Äôs go ‚Ä¶

Set 500 years in the future, See imagines a world where nearly all humans are blind. Society has adapted, including in war and survival. When sighted twins Haniwa and Kofun are born, they‚Äôre hunted as witches.¬†

A young, out gay woman in this AppleTV series, Haniwa sees her vision as a gift. She chooses the bow as her weapon. But to survive, she must hide in plain sight, knowing her abilities make her a target. MORE: 8 Powerful Reminders From AppleTV‚Äôs SEE

2) Villanelle, Killing Eve

Villanelle is ruthless, skilled, and flamboyant, with a chilling sense of playfulness. She‚Äôs as petulant as she is deadly, making her unforgettable.

As a modern antiheroine, she‚Äôs dangerously magnetic. Her obsession with Eve only adds to her unpredictability. We absolutely shouldn‚Äôt root for her and yet, somehow we do.

3) Lexa, The 100

Lexa is a warrior and a leader who stays true to her values. She‚Äôs fair, even when it costs her dearly. Though feelings exist between her and the series‚Äô protagonist Clarke, Lexa chooses her people over personal attachments. Her decisions may hurt, but they are never selfish. That‚Äôs what makes her a standout leader.

4) Rosa Diaz, Brooklyn 99

Rosa Diaz is the precinct‚Äôs badass: stoic, sharp, and fiercely private. She‚Äôs the detective you want in your corner. Her coming out as bisexual was handled with emotional weight and humour. Loving Rosa isn‚Äôt always easy, but it‚Äôs definitely inevitable. Beneath the gruff exterior is loyalty and care.

5) Katniss Everdeen, The Hunger Games

Many fans interpret Katniss as asexual.¬†Compared to Lucy Gray (A Ballad Of Songbirds And Snakes), who uses charm and romance to survive, Katniss struggles with performance. Her loyalty lies in platonic bonds and responsibility. Though Katniss ultimately chooses Peeta, love for her is about stability; not passion. She‚Äôs never an ‚Äòice queen‚Äô, just focused on survival and what truly matters.

MORE: 4 Ways The Hunger Games Subverts Expectations¬†

6) Karen, Will & Grace

Karen is a gloriously awful caricature of the rich elite ‚Äì and she owns it! She‚Äôs literally THE WORST, both hilarious and unexpectedly tender. Her relationships with Stan and Rosario hint at a hidden heart.

In the reboot, Karen somehow gets even worse (and as far as I‚Äôm concerned, even better). She‚Äôs offensive, outrageous, and endlessly watchable. Throughout the eleven series run, she plays around with her sexuality. The writers even hint Karen may be transgender, though this is never confirmed.

7) Carol Danvers, Captain Marvel

Carol is a loyal, no-nonsense badass who finally gave Marvel its first female-led superhero film. She‚Äôs dry, powerful, and competent ‚Äì just like a million male heroes before her. Yet, cue internet backlash labelling her ‚Äúunlikeable‚Äù!

title: How To Write A Synopsis For Your Screenplay Or Novel
excerpt: Let‚Äôs get one thing straight upfront, Bang2writers ‚Ä¶ When it comes to submissions, the traditional synopsis is still very much a thing. It‚Äôs true, I‚Äôve advocated for one page pitches A LOT on this site (you can grab a free reference guide, HERE ) ‚Ä¶ But sometimes you just can‚Äôt‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Why Writers Still Need The Traditional Synopsis (Yes, Really!)

Let‚Äôs get one thing straight upfront, Bang2writers ‚Ä¶ When it comes to submissions, the traditional synopsis is still very much a thing. It‚Äôs true, I‚Äôve advocated for one page pitches A LOT on this site (you can grab a free reference guide, HERE) ‚Ä¶ But ¬†sometimes you just can‚Äôt beat a good old-fashioned traditional synopsis.

I know, I know. You‚Äôd rather chew glass than try and summarise your 90,000-word novel or your 120-page screenplay in just one or two pages.

But here‚Äôs the kicker: agents, publishers, and producers EXPECT it. Like it or not, the traditional synopsis is non-negotiable in many parts of the industry.

Why Do Industry Pros Want a Synopsis Anyway?

It‚Äôs not because they want to torture you (though it may feel that way). It‚Äôs because they‚Äôre overwhelmed.

Script readers and assistants often use the synopsis as a first sift, deciding whether your project is even worth reading. That means if your synopsis doesn‚Äôt land? Your manuscript or script might never get read.

Let that sink in for a moment. Think of your synopsis as your ticket to getting READ!

By the way ‚Ä¶ script readers also need to write synopses too!

If you do (or want to do) this work, chances are you will need to summarise screenplays (or novels, for book coverage) for your boss.

The script readers who get hired again and again write GREAT synopses. This is because producers, agents, film financiers and investors etc don‚Äôt have time to read every single submission.

This means industry pros rely on their script readers‚Äô reports. A key element of the report is the synopsis, as it helps them make important decisions. If they can‚Äôt make those decisions because your reader‚Äôs report synopsis SUCKS? Then guess what, you‚Äôre fired. Yikes!

What Actually *Is* a Traditional Synopsis?

Unlike the newer and often preferred one page pitch, a traditional synopsis does include the entire plot in detail. I frequently call it a ‚Äòblow-by-blow‚Äô account of your story. You‚Äôre expected to show the full arc of your story (yes, even the ending!).

Here‚Äôs what a solid synopsis needs to cover:

  • The Set Up and Pay Off (aka beginning and ending)
  • Your main character‚Äôs arc (especially your protagonist‚Äôs, though maybe your antagonist‚Äôs too)
  • A sense of the storyworld
  • A feel for the tone and genre
  • Dynamic language that keeps the reader engaged (never lapse into the dreaded ‚Äòand then‚Ä¶ and then ‚Ä¶!).

Sounds simple enough, right? But anyone who‚Äôs attempted one knows, it‚Äôs NOT. It‚Äôs one of the hardest documents to write, even for seasoned pros. My tips on how to do this, after the pic.

Enter: The Hamburger Method

When I‚Äôm working 1:1 with writers, I frequently recommend thinking of your traditional synopsis like a hamburger (or a veggie burger, if you prefer). Here‚Äôs what you need:

  • BREAD 1 (Top Bun):This is your Set Up: introduce your protagonist, what they want, and what‚Äôs standing in their way. Give a sense of the genre and tone here too, but don‚Äôt go wild.
  • MEAT (The Juicy Middle):This is the main bulk of your story. Pull from your novel or script‚Äôs scenes and chapters to summarise the journey. Don‚Äôt include every twist and turn, just the key beats and arcs that reveal character and push the story forward.
  • BREAD 2 (Bottom Bun):The Pay Off. Yes, reveal the ending!!! Holding it back doesn‚Äôt make your story more intriguing. In fact, it actively frustrates readers.

Remember, this is NOT a blurb, it‚Äôs a tool for industry professionals to assess the shape and execution of your story.

But Can‚Äôt I Just Write a One Page Pitch?

One page pitches are fantastic. I use and teach them all the time. It‚Äôs a great idea to have one pagers ready, especially if you;re a screenwriter. You should be ready to ‚Äòsell the sizzle, not the steak‚Äô on your scripts.

title: 5 Reasons Your Writing SUCKS (Plus How To Fix It)
excerpt: So, the bad news: your writing sucks and you need to fix it. Every single day Google brings writers to this blog using the search phrase ‚Äòmy writing sucks‚Äô. Supersadface.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Newsflash: Your Writing SUCKS

So, the bad news: your writing sucks and you need to fix it. Every single day Google brings writers to this blog using the search phrase ‚Äòmy writing sucks‚Äô. Supersadface.

Look, it‚Äôs not unusual to believe your writing sucks. It may even be true. While I am the first one to say writers need to believe in themselves, it‚Äôs also a good idea to be realistic. It‚Äôs not possible to write a perfect draft straight out the gate, plus writing craft is HARD. It takes a lot of practice!

So, here‚Äôs the good news: if you think your writing sucks, you‚Äôve come to the right place to fix it. Ready? Let‚Äôs go ‚Ä¶

1) You have a love/hate relationship with your draft

Whether it‚Äôs a messy novel or a bloated screenplay, clinging to that first version will kill your story. I get it, you love your story. That‚Äôs great! But you also have to temper that with the knowledge your first idea is rarely your best one. You‚Äôre unlikely to hit the nail on the head the first time you write something ‚Ä¶ whether that‚Äôs a draft or even a whole project!

What‚Äôs that: you HATE your draft? That‚Äôs normal too. Look, writing gets romanticised online and by pro writers. You thought it would be a lot easier than this. But you‚Äôre not the worst writer in the universe. Writing is just DIFFICULT.

HOW TO FIX IT: Rewrite with purpose. Cut the filler. No one cares about your clever lines if they‚Äôre slowing the pace. And remember to LET GO. You ‚Äì and your story ‚Äì will not develop if you are resistant to the process.

MORE: ‚ÄòI Trust The Process‚Äô ‚Äì And 9 More Powerful Affirmations For Writers

2) You‚Äôre playing it safe

Writers tell me all the time about their ideas. But so often they will follow it up with ‚Ä¶

  • ‚ÄòBut am I ALLOWED to tell this story?‚Äô
  • ‚ÄòYes, but I could NEVER write XYZ.‚Äô
  • ‚ÄòBut I‚Äôm SCARED of writing that.‚Äô

This might be about a particular character or trope; storyworld or genre; tone or style; even something they‚Äôve lived through themselves.

In other words, absolutely ANYTHING. Writers will find every excuse in the book NOT to write something. ¬†The most common these days is ‚ÄòTwitter might yell at me.‚Äô¬†

But in fiction or film, safe = forgettable. Your novel ends up reading like everything else on Kindle. Your screenplay feels like a rejected Netflix pitch.

HOW TO FIX IT: Be braver. Go darker, weirder, funnier, messier. Whatever takes it up a notch. I double dare you!¬†

3) You‚Äôre telling, not showing

Visual writing is at a MEGA premium in the spec pile, whether novels or screenplays.

Unpublished novel manuscripts are awash with non-stop thoughts and feelings.

Screenplays are chains of dialogue, flashbacks and voice-overs.

Both will ‚Äòinfo-dump‚Äô, laying out facts and figures believing that‚Äôs how exposition works.

Spoiler: it DOESN‚ÄôT!

Whether we‚Äôre reading or viewing, never forget: we learn about a character from what they DO.

HOW TO FIX IT: Whether it‚Äôs prose or script, DRAMATISE it. Think about the physical realm. Make the reader *see* it. Let action and character behaviour do the heavy lifting.

MORE: Writing Adages Explained: ‚ÄòShow, Don‚Äôt Tell‚Äô

4) Your characters are cardboard¬†

If your protagonist is a clich√© or your villain is just ‚Äúbad,‚Äù readers and viewers will check out. Modern readers and audiences LIKE shades of grey.

Real people are complex. LET your characters make bad decisions. They‚Äôre not meant to be perfect. So what if @internethandle4Millionand1 might have a problem with it in a review?? That hasn‚Äôt happened yet.¬†

HOW TO FIX IT: Let them surprise you. That‚Äôs where the magic is. And learn about tropes!

5) You don‚Äôt have the GUTS to finish!

This one is frequently connected to 1 and 2 on this list. Writers end up going in circles, making zero progress because they can‚Äôt LET GO.

Half a novel? An act one and a dream? Not enough. Finishing something ‚Äì however flawed ‚Äì is the only way to get better. I know it‚Äôs scary. No one said it was easy. But it‚Äôs gotta be done.

title: DICK TRIES TO DIE ‚Ä¢ Jake Stein
excerpt: If Richard was going to commit suicide‚Äîand this time, he really was‚Äîhe wasn‚Äôt about to make some elaborate production of it. He refused to leave behind a situation which needed cleaning up. That meant not hanging himself, not slitting his wrists, and definitely not shooting hi‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
If Richard was going to commit suicide‚Äîand this time, he really was‚Äîhe wasn‚Äôt about to make some elaborate production of it. He refused to leave behind a situation which needed cleaning up. That meant not hanging himself, not slitting his wrists, and definitely not shooting himself. Sleeping pills were the obvious choice, but Richard‚Äôs brother had died of an overdose, and he just couldn‚Äôt bring himself to go in a related fashion.

Which was why, today, he‚Äôd decided on carbon monoxide poisoning.

It‚Äôll be painless, he told himself, flicking the light switch in the garage. Like falling asleep. He got into his ancient Nissan and turned the key for what he planned to be the last time. He hadn‚Äôt bothered to write a note; there was nobody to address it to. Breathing his vehicle‚Äôs exhaust, he took in his final surroundings. A dim, cluttered room. Stuff in boxes. Stuff in bags. Two fold-up chairs, a lawnmower, a spattering of camping gear, a neglected set of weights. The detritus of a life that filled Richard with dread each time he remembered having lived it.

He smiled to himself. (Who else would he be smiling for?) How unspectacular, to go out like this. Alone, in an old car he‚Äôd never liked, encircled by crap. How fitting. How perfectly Richard.

The tang of gas riled his nerves. It occurred to him: what if this didn‚Äôt work? What if he only succeeded in becoming mush for someone to take care of?

Detecting a headache‚Äîa sign the fumes were working‚Äîhe turned on the radio. He was encouraged to find himself hallucinating when the radio referred to him by name.

‚ÄúHello? Richard?‚Äù An elderly woman‚Äôs voice crackled through the car‚Äôs antiquated sound-system. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for Richard.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is him,‚Äù Richard answered out of habit, immediately feeling ridiculous about it.

‚ÄúI have bad news, Richard. You can‚Äôt die today.‚Äù

Choosing not to engage with the sputters of his dying brain, Richard didn‚Äôt reply.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre straying from the authorized flow of events,‚Äù said the scratchy voice. ‚ÄúNormally I‚Äôd allow a deviation, but with the holidays‚Ä¶‚Äù A sigh through the speakers; a gust of static. ‚ÄúRichard, we‚Äôre simply overcrowded. You think the population crisis is bad on this material plane, where people only exist for the blink of an eye? Imagine eternity. So I‚Äôm sorry, I can‚Äôt make any exceptions‚Äîyou‚Äôll have to wait until your time, young man.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not young.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre alive. That‚Äôs young.‚Äù

Richard shifted in the driver‚Äôs seat, unable to get comfortable. A numbness spread through him‚Äîa hollow feeling, like hunger cramps. He couldn‚Äôt piece together the logic behind what his car was telling him, but he supposed he shouldn‚Äôt expect a talking car to make sense. All a dream, anyway.

Falling asleep, painless‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a dream,‚Äù said the car radio, the old woman, the hallucination. ‚ÄúSnap out of it, sad guy.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho are you, the grim reaper?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one thing people call me. Listen, you‚Äôll wake up from this. You just have to decide whether massive brain damage sounds appealing.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause I‚Äôm not meant to kill myself?‚Äù

‚ÄúVery few people are meant to kill themselves. And wouldn‚Äôt you know it, the few who are meant to, those are the ones who never get around to it. Anyway, you‚Äôre not one of those few.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo away, Death.‚Äù He considered his words, and quickly added, ‚ÄúJust take me with you.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if I said you had a child you didn‚Äôt know about?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôd say you‚Äôre lying.‚Äù During those rare periods in Richard‚Äôs life when he‚Äôd been sexually active, he‚Äôd also been obsessively careful. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no use. I don‚Äôt care anymore. I just don‚Äôt care.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf that were true, you wouldn‚Äôt mind making a mess on your way out. You‚Äôd just shoot yourself and be done with it, Dick. Is it fine if I call you Dick?‚Äù

Richard sensed, far away, a note of anger inside him. ‚ÄúIf you stop me, I‚Äôm just going to try again. If not today, tomorrow.‚Äù

title: WHERE DREAMS WANDERED ‚Ä¢ Andrew M Jaromin
excerpt: When I was nine, my dad warned me about the dangers of dreaming.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When I was nine, my dad warned me about the dangers of dreaming.

‚ÄúYou know, it‚Äôs like if you drink too much water, it shuts down the electrical connections and you just keel on over,‚Äù he‚Äôd said in his woodchip voice as we sat at the kitchen table.

‚ÄúYour body forgets how to breathe. Same with dreaming‚Äîyou get too high in them dreams, there ain‚Äôt enough oxygen.‚Äù

I had made the mistake of telling him I wanted to be an explorer that day, after Mrs. Hastings showed us a National Geographic article about the Galapagos Islands. I was too young to know about brain synapses and what electricity had to do with any of it so I‚Äôd just nodded. My father had cupped my cheeks in his dry, cracked hands, and left to tend the chickens.

I didn‚Äôt blame him. He‚Äôd wanted to be a mechanic as a young boy. But his mom got sick, bills came due, and his dreams lost the oxygen needed to keep on. Perhaps the electricity too.

Maybe that was why he‚Äôd never been able to see the valley of dreams.

I lay in that valley now, amused by the flowing and frolicking nature of these benign aberrations.

I‚Äôd known it forever, this expanse of long, swaying grass, sprawling for miles until being taken in by the Catskills. It was a sight to behold‚Äînature as it was designed, free from humans save for the touch of a barn and a withering fence in the distance.

The barn was of course not a barn at all, but a home. It was where I had grown up, except for a short stint at Binghamton University. It was my parent‚Äôs farm, but its day to day operations were mine now.

I could see the dreams drifting along the valley‚Äìgusts of green and squalls of scarlet scheming to take me away. If only for just a short while.

It‚Äôs possible I‚Äôm crazy. I‚Äôve considered this before.

I did bring an old girlfriend once‚Äîhad her sit under the gnarled weeping beech tree with me. But Madeline did not see the colorful clouds that meandered around me with scenes of game-winning shots and yuletide festivities‚Äîshe saw nothing but a normal field. A beautiful field she had assured me, but nothing strange.

I had thought she might see her dreams, and I can never be sure she didn‚Äôt I suppose, but, like my father, her eyes didn‚Äôt seem to light up like you would imagine when witnessing your desires as figments and flashes floating in the air. If she did see anything, she never told me, and then we broke up, and she never told me anything after that.

But unlike Madeline, I saw the dreams and the dreams seemed to see me.

Now I was thirty-eight, still single, and I knew the rhythm of a day. It was Wednesday, which meant by sunrise I‚Äôd completed all farm tasks in need of my attention.

Free for a spell, I‚Äôd come to the valley where dreams wandered.

With the wind mellow and lazy, it allowed the dreams that drifted my way to linger, letting me settle into them before they moved on to wherever else they had to be.

I saw a particularly large one drifting‚Äîa cloud the color of an ocean sunset. Pink and puffy, and gliding down a draft of air like a child on a waterslide. It slid along before engulfing me in its mist.

This was a road-not-traveled dream. Well, they all were really. I witnessed a scene of myself and Ella Feldman, sitting on a couch, watching TV together. It looked vaguely like my parent‚Äôs house but with slight alterations‚Äîmany horse statues abound and lace curtains. This was of course because when I had had a crush on Ella, back in third grade, she had a major obsession with horses. She probably still did, but I wouldn‚Äôt know because we had drifted apart freshman year of high school. She‚Äôd stuck around the area, but she was married now and had two children.

title: These 3 Paradise Islands Named Must-Visit Destinations This Fall
excerpt: PSLs are sure to be tasty, but you don't have to give in to the idea that the only way to enjoy the fall season is by reaching into the back of your closet for your finest checkered flannel to hit up apple orchards and tree-lined mountain roadways.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
PSLs are sure to be tasty, but you don't have to give in to the idea that the only way to enjoy the fall season is by reaching into the back of your closet for your finest checkered flannel to hit up apple orchards and tree-lined mountain roadways.

There are still stunning beaches awaiting all across the globe.

While some popular U.S. beach towns don't quite have the same appeal as sunny summers, that's what passports are here for.

The travel experts at FlightHub have mixed personal insight and data to craft a list of must-visit fall destinations.

While icons like New York, LA, and Orlando make the cut time and time again, there were some real surprises for more adventurous travelers seeking to escape axe-throwing at pumpkin patches in favor of paradisal sun-drenched shores.

These 3 international paradise islands were named must-visit destinations this fall:

3) San Blas, Panama

Panama may not have been on your Bingo card for a Caribbean escape this fall, but as a recent visitor to this highly underrated and diverse utopia of wildlife, pristine beaches, and cultural delights, it earned my stamp of approval right away.

While I didn't have the chance to visit the cluster of islands making up San Blas, I did visit another practically untouched seaside oasis (Portobelo) on the other side of the country, and it was definitely worth the adventure.

Though San Blas is where locals send tourists for an ideal picture-perfect beach vacation, as it's more suited for flawless getaways, while Portobelo is a small town still making its way onto travelers' itineraries.

In San Blas, you'll find immense beauty and a rich indigenous culture. As beautiful as this region may be, don't quite expect Cancun-level resorts.

Flying into Panama City is the easy part, then you'll need to tap into your sense of wanderlust as the trek ahead is a doozy, so many hire a professional guide.

Upon arrival, expect a rustic, off-grid experience with gleaming white-sand beaches, crystal-clear waters, and a lack of large-scale tourism infrastructure, which is all part of the appeal.

From there, island-hop, snorkel, swim, lounge beachside, and learn all about Guna culture at your leisure.

2) Vis, Croatia

We at Travel Off Path already recently revealed another awesome Croatian destination (Zagreb) taking this Mediterranean hotspot by storm, so if you thought Dubrovnik was the only way to experience this trendy country, we've got news for you!

Honestly, now is a great time to start planning your trip anywhere in Croatia for more elbow room on the beach, but the little island of Vis is a year-round tight-lipped secret.

Boasting a Mediterranean climate, you know the weather is just as nice (if not better) than summer, and given the lack of crowds here anyway, it makes it even more enjoyable for a relaxing escape, wining and dining with tranquil beaches and picturesque villages wrapping the island, but don't skip the hidden cove of Stiniva (see first photo).

Sample local Vugava and Plavac Mali wines, hike to Mount Hum, and always grab a patio seat when possible, especially in the town of the same name (Vis), along with Komi≈æa.

Don't expect flashy resorts cramping your space on a dreamy beach. Instead, it's much easier to find boutique hotels in town.

To get here, your best bet is flying into Split and hopping on a ferry, where you'll bypass Hvar, a more popular island overshadowing Vis, even for¬†mainstream travelers like me.

1) Boracay, Philippines

If you had to guess the top destination Americans have their eyes on in the Philippines, what would you guess?

Manila? Cebu? Palawan? nope!

Surprise, surprise. It's Boracay, according to our last feature on this surging island.

The irony is that Boracay limits the number of daily visitors to minimize environmental impact and provide more enjoyment for beachgoers.

Even with its diminutive size, this island packs a punch with powdery white-sand beaches, transparent waters, and a plethora of aquatic thrills, ranging from sailing, snorkeling, and banana boat rides, and for the ultimate relaxation, expect to be offered massages by beach vendors.

Whether they're properly vetted or not is a different story‚Ä¶

title: Smithsonian Latino Gallery Quietly Closes for Nine Months
excerpt: On Friday morning, August 22, illustrator Felipe Galindo G√≥mez opened his email to find a note from his friend. ‚ÄúHave you seen this?‚Äù the message read, and linked to the White House‚Äôs bullet-pointed list targeting Smithsonian artworks and exhibitions . There it was: an image o‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
On Friday morning, August 22, illustrator Felipe Galindo G√≥mez opened his email to find a note from his friend. ‚ÄúHave you seen this?‚Äù the message read, and linked to the White House‚Äôs bullet-pointed list targeting Smithsonian artworks and exhibitions. There it was: an image of his 1999 illustration ‚Äú4th of July from the south border.‚Äù

Since 2022, Galindo‚Äôs work had been reproduced on a label about anti-immigrant prejudice as part of ¬°Presente! A Latino History of the United States in the National Museum of American History‚Äôs (NMAH) Molina Family Latino Gallery. Over the last three years, the gallery space has served as the temporary location of the nascent National Museum of the American Latino, which is currently facing an uncertain future under the Trump administration. Now, the Molina gallery has quietly closed for the next nine months,

Hyperallergicconfirmed.

After the White House featured his work in its hit list, Galindo, who also goes by the name ‚ÄúFeggo,‚Äù said he traveled from New York City to Washington, DC, to see whether it was still up. When he arrived at the museum on Tuesday, he found the exhibition closed. A sign said it would reopen in spring 2026. According to the Smithsonian‚Äôs website, ¬°Presente! was scheduled to close at the end of November, in preparation for programming marking the United States‚Äôs 250th birthday. But the exhibition was shuttered on July 20, four months sooner than expected. The decision notably follows Trump‚Äôs March executive order targeting the Smithsonian Institution and the release of his Fiscal Year 2026 budget, which excluded funding for the NMAL.

The Molina Family Latino Gallery‚Äôs early closure means it will remain shuttered throughout Hispanic Heritage Month this fall, and marks a lengthy period of inactivity for the fledgling National Museum of the American Latino‚Äôs only current physical gallery, which the museum‚Äôs director, Jorge Zamanillo, has referred to as the institution‚Äôs ‚Äúfirst iteration.‚Äù¬†

Reached by Hyperallergic, a spokesperson for the institution cited preparations for the Smithsonian‚Äôs Our Shared Future: 250 programming as the reason for the exhibition‚Äôs premature closure.¬†

‚ÄúThe National Museum of the American Latino is participating in the Smithsonian‚Äôs celebration of the nation‚Äôs 250th anniversary and wanted to meet the spring 2026 deadline for opening the Puro Ritmo exhibition in support of the Smithsonian‚Äôs institution-wide plans,‚Äù the spokesperson said, referring to the upcoming show ¬°Puro Ritmo! The Musical Journey of Salsa at the Molina gallery.¬†‚ÄúThe Molina Family Latino Gallery is closed to visitors because museum staff need the space to safely de-install

Presenteand then transition the exhibition space into a staging area to prepare for the renovation and installation of

Puro Ritmo.‚Äù

The institution reportedly adopted the salsa-themed exhibition as a softer alternative to a planned exhibition on Latino youth movements that garnered significant conservative backlash. Before Trump‚Äôs crackdown on the Smithsonian began, that exhibition was widely criticized by conservatives who disagreed with its focus on colonization and threatened to withhold federal funding for the forthcoming museum in 2023.¬†

The Smithsonian spokesperson did not directly answer a question about whether Trump‚Äôs museum reviews or executive action influenced the decision to close the Molina Gallery in July. Trump has repeatedly pushed the Smithsonian to promote ‚Äúunity, progress, and enduring values‚Äù in time for the country‚Äôs 250th anniversary next year. Earlier this month, the administration demanded that Smithsonian museums submit their 250th anniversary plans to ‚Äúalign messaging‚Äù with the White House Salute to America 250 Task Force.

Three of the works named on last week‚Äôs White House list were created by living artists who were born in Mexico, including Galindo, raising questions about how the institution will protect its Latino artists under pressure from the federal government.

When Galindo learned from a staff member that the museum was ‚Äúrotating‚Äù the exhibition, he told Hyperallergic he remembers thinking, ‚ÄúIs that a new word for censoring?‚Äù¬†

The administration has already launched a review of exhibitions planned for the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence as part of its larger probe. Trump‚Äôs government referenced the US‚Äôs 250th anniversary nine times in its letter to the Smithsonian announcing its review and forthcoming ‚Äúcontent corrections.‚Äù¬†

title: Adrift in Betye Saar‚Äôs Crepuscular Dreamscape
excerpt: SAN MARINO, Calif. ‚Äî Standing in the gallery of Betye Saar: Drifting Toward Twilight , you are bathed in oceanic, cobalt blue light. The buzz of neon lights drones in the background. It‚Äôs hard to say if the temperature has truly dropped, or if it‚Äôs psychosomatic, that the atmo‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
SAN MARINO, Calif. ‚Äî¬†Standing in the gallery of Betye Saar: Drifting Toward Twilight, you are bathed in oceanic, cobalt blue light. The buzz of neon lights drones in the background. It‚Äôs hard to say if the temperature has truly dropped, or if it‚Äôs psychosomatic, that the atmosphere has cooled your skin just by the power of suggestion. You‚Äôre floating in space, or suspended underwater ‚Äî gravity works differently here.

The phases of the moon are painted on the wall in a matte metallic silver, and a small poem by Saar is draped across the wall: ‚ÄúThe moon keeps vigil as a lone canoe drifts into a sea of tranquility seeking serenity in the twilight.‚Äù In the middle of the room, a long canoe, 17 feet across, sits atop a bed of branches, bramble, and sheets of jagged wood. At either tip of the ship is a watchful eye guiding the raft in both directions. Two sentinels ‚Äî antiques affixed with antlers ‚Äî keep watch at each end. Saar has crafted a fantastical scene; you can envision the boat careening upriver, striding forth.

The vessel is occupied by bird cages confining animal antlers and seated upon miniature chairs fit only for a toddler ‚Äî or, perhaps, spirits who scarcely need a physical seat, just an invitation to rest. These scavenged items are characteristic of Saar‚Äôs found object assemblage; she hunts for her materials, whether in nature or at flea markets.

‚ÄúI like combining manufactured objects with natural objects,‚Äù says the 98-year-old artist in a video at the back of the gallery. She started collecting at four or five, she explains, but the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. was a catalyzing moment. She was so overwhelmed with emotion that she could do nothing but create art, leading her to assemble one of her most famed sculptures, ‚ÄúThe Liberation of Aunt Jemima‚Äù (1972), which empowers and equips a ‚Äúmammy‚Äù figurine with defensive weaponry.

Saar is a famed Angeleno, a fixture in the city‚Äôs art scene, but she was raised in Pasadena, which neighbors the Huntington Gardens, where this site-specific commission went up in 2023. In the short directed by Kyle Provencio Reingold, the camera follows her through the massive campus, where she first wandered at 12 or 13 alongside her mother and neighbor. We forage the gardens with her as she instructs the Huntington employees of her artistic intentions; you can hear the giddiness in her voice as she remembers her childhood traversing its grounds, selecting fallen branches and trimmings. ‚ÄúEven in death, those things can be really beautiful,‚Äù she muses.

The gallery lighting shifts from daylight to dusk as time creeps along. Drifting Into Twilight is an encapsulated, self-sustaining environment of its own, like a display exhibit at a natural history museum with a surrealistic twist. The room is as relaxing as it is disorienting; it feels like you‚Äôve been plunged into a misty and peculiar other world. You are sinking, descending, drifting into twilight.¬†

Betye Saar: Drifting Toward Twilight continues at Virginia Steele Scott Galleries of American Art at the Huntington (1151 Oxford Road, San Marino, California) through November 30, 2027. The exhibition was curated by Yinshi Lerman-Tan and Sola Saar Agustsson.

title: World‚Äôs Largest Van Gogh Collection Faces Uncertain Future
excerpt: Since 1973, Vincent van Gogh masterpieces including his beloved sunflowers, wistful wheatfields, and self-portraits have been housed in Amsterdam‚Äôs Van Gogh Museum. The institution was established via a historic 1962 agreement between the painter‚Äôs nephew and the Dutch governm‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Since 1973, Vincent van Gogh masterpieces including his beloved sunflowers, wistful wheatfields, and self-portraits have been housed in Amsterdam‚Äôs Van Gogh Museum. The institution was established via a historic 1962 agreement between the painter‚Äôs nephew and the Dutch government to ensure the long-term preservation of hundreds of paintings, drawings, and letters comprising van Gogh‚Äôs oeuvre.
Now, the museum says that the collection‚Äôs future is uncertain, citing a dispute with the Dutch Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (OCW) over the funding for costly maintenance repairs and sustainability efforts mandated by the state. In a legal complaint, the institution claims that the Dutch government is violating its decades-old agreement by refusing to provide sufficient subsidies to cover the cost of the three-year, ‚Ç¨104 million (~$121 million) project.

Under the Dutch Heritage Act, national museums, including the Van Gogh Museum, the Rijksmuseum, and the Kr√∂ller-M√ºller Museum, receive annual housing subsidies to help them maintain and preserve their collections. But the Van Gogh Museum says that this yearly government funding ‚Äî currently ‚Ç¨8,428,300 (~$9.8 million) ‚Äî falls short of the more than ‚Ç¨11 million (~$12.8 million) needed to help it finance much-needed renovations to its fire and security alarms, climate control system, and internal elevators leading to storage facilities, plus the sustainability upgrades required for all Dutch public buildings as of 2024.

‚ÄúSo far, the state of the museum has not directly affected the programming and operations,‚Äù a Van Gogh Museum spokesperson told Hyperallergic. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs just a matter of time before it will become a major issue.‚Äù¬†

A spokesperson for OCW said that the ministry ‚Äúmaintains that the allocated housing subsidy is sufficient to cover the necessary maintenance cost.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis position is based on comprehensive research conducted by independent experts commissioned by the Ministry,‚Äù the spokesperson told Hyperallergic, noting that the subsidy is a ‚Äúfixed amount‚Äù that is annually adjusted for inflation.

The museum did not disclose how the subsidy is calculated, but the OCW representative said that the same methodology is used for other national museums, citing the Rijksmuseum, which receives ‚Ç¨37 million (~$43 million), and the Kr√∂ller-M√ºller Museum, which receives ‚Ç¨9.8 (~$11.4 million).

For the past two years, the Van Gogh Museum has been negotiating with the government to increase this annual subsidy by ‚Ç¨2.5 million (~$2.9 million) to no avail.

If the institution does not come to a resolution soon, the museum says it may need to close its doors. The Van Gogh Foundation, established by the painter‚Äôs nephew, has also echoed concerns about the institution‚Äôs future and urged the Dutch government to abide by its obligations to protect the artist‚Äôs works as stipulated by the founding 1962 agreement.

The Van Gogh Museum houses the largest collection of works by the artist in the world, comprising over 200 paintings, 500 drawings, and 900 letters, as well as other works by the Dutch artist‚Äôs contemporaries and influences. Over the course of five decades, nearly 57 million people have visited the museum, with annual attendance reaching a peak of 2.6 million in 2017. Last year, the institution hosted five exhibitions, including a retrospective exploring van Gogh‚Äôs influence on the late Chinese-Canadian artist Matthew Wong and a show paying homage to French Impressionism.

The case is scheduled to be heard in court on February 19, the OCW spokesperson told Hyperallergic.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
‚Ä£¬†Design is a minefield of ethical dilemmas, incentivizing companies to work with exploitative clients and making it difficult for employees to say no. Elizabeth Goodspeed spoke with a few designers, writing in It‚Äôs Nice That:

Questions about client ethics are tricky enough when you know exactly who you‚Äôre working for. Things get even murkier when work is licensed, resold, or embedded with no direct link between creator and end user. For type designers, this is the norm. Once a font is released, it can surface almost anywhere, often without warning. Jesse Ragan, cofounder of XYZ Type, says custom projects feel relatively straightforward to assess ideologically: if he doesn‚Äôt believe in a client, he can simply turn down the work. Retail fonts are a different story. A typeface is made in isolation long before it‚Äôs used, and can be licensed anonymously or simply pulled from Adobe Fonts without the designer‚Äôs knowledge. Jesse has seen his work turn up in porn, conservative Christian campaigns, and even materials for a far-right Texas militia. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always a shock to see,‚Äù he says, especially given his left-leaning politics. He describes designing a typeface as a slow, intimate process ‚Äì ‚Äúevery little letterform, it‚Äôs like, ‚Äòhello, friend‚Äô, when I see them‚Äù ‚Äì which makes it all the more jarring when it gets into the wrong hands. Rutherford Craze, founder of foundry Mass Driver, shares this feeling. ‚ÄúSome type designers feel that once they release a typeface, where it ends up is no longer their concern. I strongly disagree,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not feasible to make a living and keep a spotless conscience, but it‚Äôs our responsibility to find the most equitable balance we can, whether that‚Äôs through [dis]incentivising certain usage, or turning down work for clients we disagree with.‚Äù

‚Ä£¬†Noguchi Museum Rights, an anonymous group of workers at the New York institution, penned an essay flagging longstanding allegations of racism and artwashing at the museum. They write in Everything is Political:

Given that the keffiyeh is a cultural garment, meaning it is protected under city and state laws, and is the only thing ever explicitly targeted by this policy, how does the selective enforcement of this policy not discriminate against individuals who would wear a keffiyeh as a cultural item? What is the distinction between cultural and political in this context, and how is that dealt with by museum leadership?

Why were board Co-Chairs Spencer Bailey and Susan Kessler so involved in enforcing the keffiyeh ban, and in what ways does enforcing the ban relate to their responsibilities?

The leadership is not for the community, despite running a community museum founded by an activist artist who would be appalled by the current conditions. While people and organizations have stopped partnering with the museum, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission complaints have been filed, the staff has unionized, and the museum has received terrible press, those in leadership positions have simply crossed their fingers in the hope that the public will forget about it all. The Noguchi Museum is a community non-profit, and as a member of the community, you deserve answers.

title: Seeing New Mexico Through the Looking Glass
excerpt: SANTA FE ‚Äî In 1998, science fiction writer Ted Chiang published ‚ÄúStory of Your Life,‚Äù in which aliens come to Earth in ‚Äúlooking glasses,‚Äù mirrored spaceships that act as communication devices. The central character, linguist Dr. Louise Banks, is tasked with deciphering the ali‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
SANTA FE ‚Äî In 1998, science fiction writer Ted Chiang published ‚ÄúStory of Your Life,‚Äù in which aliens come to Earth in ‚Äúlooking glasses,‚Äù mirrored spaceships that act as communication devices. The central character, linguist Dr. Louise Banks, is tasked with deciphering the aliens‚Äô language. In turn, she begins to see time like they do ‚Äî as simultaneous events ‚Äî and ultimately glimpses her own future.

A reference to ‚ÄúStory of Your Life‚Äù is tucked into the exhibition guidebook for Once Within a Time, SITE Santa Fe‚Äôs 12th International. Curator Cecilia Alemani identified Chiang as one of the exhibition‚Äôs 27 ‚Äúfigures of interest‚Äù ‚Äî catalysts for the 71

participating artists and more than two dozen writers. What struck me about Alemani‚Äôs inclusion of Chiang‚Äôs writing was not the reference to extraterrestrial life (many readers will be familiar with the accounts of UFO sightings in New Mexico), but the surreal, endlessly fascinating phenomenon of the looking glass.

Once Within a Time takes reflection as a major cue. Within each curated theme, such as ‚ÄúThe Wheel of Telling‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Secret Life of Puppets,‚Äù are mirror images, doubles, reversals, and echoes, along with symmetries of place, histories, peoples, and legends ‚Äî offering exhibition visitors concurrent rather than sequential events, in which multiple perspectives and timelines unfold. Even the treatment of the exhibition title, in which ‚ÄúTime‚Äù is printed upside down, gestures to alternative ways of experiencing the temporal, reflective nature of both art and language.¬†

Among the many echoing narratives are works by Nora Turato and Will Rawls. Turato‚Äôs mural ‚ÄúI WANT OUT!‚Äù (2025), a red vinyl triptych with one panel per word, is installed on the exterior of SITE Santa Fe, the main venue; inside the museum, Rawls‚Äôs Amphigory (2022), a series of inky, glitchy screen prints, seems to respond to Turato‚Äôs plea with the barely legible phrase ‚ÄúU Can‚Äôt Escape Alive.‚Äù¬†

In the gallery with Rawls is a suite of 72 computer drawings from 1969 by hard-edge abstract painter Frederick Hammersley, who died in 2009 at age 90. He hit an artistic dry spell in the late ‚Äô60s, saying, ‚ÄúI painted myself out,‚Äù a condition of exhaustion, liberation, or perhaps both. To shake things up, he enrolled in a computer class for artists at the University of New Mexico. He used the program ART 1 to create multiple printouts of the individual ‚Äúdrawings‚Äù that comprise the suite on view, visually undulating abstract compositions of gray monochrome letters, numbers, and punctuation marks. With additional presentations of Chester Nez and the ‚ÄúOriginal 29‚Äù Navajo Code Talkers, Autumn Chacon‚Äôs radio frequency installation, and others, visitors may experience some seriously surreal data-driven reverberations. ¬†

In SITE‚Äôs central gallery space, color-rich reverse paintings on glass ‚Äî a vase of flowers, a snake, a dreamlike landscape ‚Äî by Rebecca Salsbury James, born in 1891, were just odd enough to make me linger and consider her time in Taos, New Mexico, with Mabel Dodge Luhan, Georgia O‚ÄôKeeffe, and other New York-to-Taos transplants. A selection from James‚Äôs collection of miniatures, including figurines, mirrors, and devotional objects, is also on view, many of which are in pairs or otherwise doubled. One tells a story, but two hold a conversation.

Elsewhere in the gallery, I felt like I was in a funhouse or hall of mirrors. Louise Bonnet‚Äôs fleshy, misshapen, iridescent-skinned figures had me reflecting on my own pale, bony frame as equally warped and grotesque, alien to New Mexico‚Äôs desert environment. Katja Seib‚Äôs large-scale portrait paintings present the concept of reflection in literal and metaphysical terms. For example, ‚ÄúCornucopia‚Äù (2025) depicts a fortune teller revealing her cards to the viewer; in the background, a framed image of another woman doing the same creates an infinity mirror effect. Nearby, a travel chest that belonged to Do√±a Tules, dubbed the ‚ÄúQueen of Sin‚Äù for her business activities (gambling and possibly a brothel), sits in the corner lit by a red light bulb, which I read as a heavy-handed reference to the stigma applied to other fiercely independent women who‚Äôve come to the region.¬†

title: Edward Burra‚Äôs Satirical Surrealism
excerpt: LONDON ‚Äî Edwards Burra was a chronically ill English painter, suffering from debilitating arthritis and asthma throughout much of his life. Hailing from the upper classes of southern England, with regularized, side-parted, tamped-down hair, he spent much of his life in headlon‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
LONDON ‚Äî Edwards Burra was a chronically ill English painter, suffering from debilitating arthritis and asthma throughout much of his life. Hailing from the upper classes of southern England, with regularized, side-parted, tamped-down hair, he spent much of his life in headlong flight from his upbringing.

Burra wanted to experience the shock of strangeness, to embrace the allure of the louche, the forbidden, the disapproved of. He sometimes left home for months at a time without even saying goodbye. Where has Edward gone? Nobody knew. Will he ever come back? Perhaps.

First it was to Paris, and then to Spain, the United States, and Mexico. As you walk around his carefully curated, chronologically organized exhibition at Tate Britain of the best of a lifetime‚Äôs work, you can hear the drift of music in the air, the music Edward loved, the visceral excitement of jazz and how that excitement fed into the work of the Harlem years. You can even see a row of black vinyl discs along the wall. These were Edward‚Äôs records.¬†

Edward Burraat Tate Britain, London (photo Michael Glover/

Hyperallergic)

It is riddling, foot-stomping, 1920s stuff, with all its wildness. You may feel an urge to put your arm around someone nearby and swerve them out onto the dance floor. There‚Äôs plenty of space in these galleries to make your mark.

Burra‚Äôs paintings, like him, are motoring away, at speed, from convention or respectability. Most are crowded with figures ‚Äî you can almost smell the sweet sweat. You can almost feel the heady excitement of all those twists and turns and crazy swerves, the pushes and the pulls.

The figures‚Äô limbs are often inclined to bend pneumatically, as if they might be nothing but inflatables. Fingers get stretched and rubberized. Features get squeezed into inhuman, mask-like shapes. Their faces are so clarted with makeup that it‚Äôs hard to tell where the fantasy of all this posing and posturing begins or ends.

Hyperallergic)

These beings, afloat on the fantasies of the Englishman wielding the brush, thrive in sexy, late-night environments where booze often topples from the trays on which it is transported. Who lives inside all these dangerously pouty cravings? This is erotic provocation on speed, surrealism lightly peppered with satire, and Burra records it all, relishing the particularity of his people and scenes. (It is he, of course, who has twisted things so out of shape.) Take a good, hard look at the weird grimaces of ‚ÄúThe Two Sisters‚Äù (1929) or the parodic mistrust on display in ‚ÄúBalcony Toulon‚Äù (1929). In New York, he falls instantly for the appeal of Harlem‚Äôs nightlife ‚Äî such gorgeous clinches to be savored in ‚ÄúSavoy Ballroom, Harlem‚Äù (1934)!

Then, once in Spain, amid the death and the turmoil and confusion of the Spanish Civil War, the mood and the palette darken, and the human figure begins to incline toward the anonymous and mechanized. War looms over these paintings. We stare into open graves to admire the skeletons.

At the end he returns to England and tries to work up some response to the puff-smoke of industry and the grit of working-class street life. Rude boys kick out in unison, like stiff performers on a stage. These paintings don‚Äôt quite convince ‚Äî the old energy has left him. Burra can no longer dig deep enough.

Edward Burra continues at Tate Britain (Millbank, London, England) through October 19. The exhibition was curated by¬†Thomas Kennedy with Eliza Spindel.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When it comes to the organization systems in my home, no room is more dialed in than my kitchen. This is especially important to me since I love cooking in this space and do it nearly every single day. Over time, I‚Äôve developed a kitchen organization system that isn‚Äôt necessarily pretty but that works really well for me.

Every single ingredient and piece of cookware in our kitchen has a dedicated place. This includes small appliances, pots and pans, lids, food storage containers, and more. I don‚Äôt focus on perfection or making sure every single cabinet and drawer is perfectly organized‚ÄîI simply make sure everything fits and goes back to its spot once I‚Äôm done using it. Things do get a bit unorganized after a couple of months (partially because I‚Äôm not the only one using this space), but it takes less than half an hour to fix. In my mind, that means this is a winning organization solution for our family.

This rule is most noticeable in our kitchen‚Äôs large pantry cabinet. Here, I organize every ingredient we have by how I cook. Similar items stay together, such as beans and rice, noodles, cooking oils, and baking ingredients. I also store almost everything in clear containers that allow me to easily see what we have on hand (and know when it‚Äôs time to refill ingredients). These containers are my favorite! I like to cook through most of what we have in the pantry before restocking, which means every month or two I wipe down the containers, refill them, and clean out whatever has expired.¬†

We don‚Äôt have a perfect track record of completing all of these things every single night‚Äîand that‚Äôs okay. But I know from experience that if we get at least two or three of them done, it makes a huge difference the next morning when we‚Äôre getting out the door for school dropoff.

title: Our Prince Edward Island Itinerary: Where We Stayed, Ate, and Wandered
excerpt: I spent last week in Prince Edward Island with family, and this wasn‚Äôt the kind of trip I could have planned on my own. Prince Edward Island has a way of looking simple on the surface (think red roads, green fields, lighthouses), but without insider knowledge, it takes some he‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I spent last week in Prince Edward Island with family, and this wasn‚Äôt the kind of trip I could have planned on my own. Prince Edward Island has a way of looking simple on the surface (think red roads, green fields, lighthouses), but without insider knowledge, it takes some help to know how to move through it. And for that, I owe a big thank you to my sister (and many of you).
She handled most of the research‚Äîdigging through maps, blogs, and follower DMs to build out a route that balanced exploration and ease. We traveled with my daughter, tried to avoid overscheduling, and somehow ended up with a weeklong Prince Edward Island itinerary that felt‚Ä¶ effortless. I owe that all to my sister!
We stayed in a mix of spots across the island. Charlottetown, Cavendish, and back again, which gave us access to beaches, national parks, and towns without spending hours in the car. Lodging in PEI can be tricky during peak season, but we booked in April/May and stayed flexible. We looked into everything from old inns to seaside cottages to slightly chaotic multi-bedroom Airbnbs.

I‚Äôm sharing what we did, what we loved, and what we‚Äôd recommend if you‚Äôre planning your own quiet, snack-filled, slow-moving week on the island. You can also reference this map to find the locations and addresses.

Lodging: Rodd CharlottetownLocation: CharlottetownVibe: Historic hotel downtown, convenient for walking and adjusting to the slower pace.
We flew in and met up with my sister, who arrived the day before! We stayed downtown for one night to get our bearings and reset before heading toward the coast. This gave us a chance to explore Charlottetown without needing a rental car right away. We did a short walking loop through the city (into some bookstores, of course)‚Äîjust enough to stretch after travel and see what Charlottetown feels like: a bit coastal, a bit quiet, very charming, and very into lobster.
We tried The Chip Shack lobster roll, which wasn‚Äôt worth writing home about, to be honest. Then we found a table at Peakes Quay that had a good kids‚Äô menu, and Bennett ate two plates of chicken strips while we played Sleeping Queens. The area was really fun and full of people on vacation. We stood in a long line to get ice cream at COWS (which was worth it and soon became a nightly ritual for the entirety of the trip).¬†

Lodging: Red Island Getaway VRBO¬†Locations: Charlottetown, Avonlea Village, and CavendishDrive Time: ~45 minutes from Charlottetown to CavendishVibe: A day of puttering, small finds, and rain that felt kind of cinematic.
We started the day with breakfast at The Cork and Cast on Victoria Row, where I had my first of many delicious Caesars (Canada‚Äôs version of a Bloody Mary but with a salty, briny twist). Get the breakfast sandwich and the fish cakes.
Then we wandered. The city had a little craft fair set up, so we walked through that, hit a couple of used bookstores, and found one of our favorite trip souvenirs: a hand-carved rabbit driving a carrot-shaped car, handmade by a local brand called Woodypix. My sister got a cat driving a rainbow trout. We were extremely into it. I bought a fish bracelet that I am very into at Mrs Peakes Fancy Goods, which was my favorite gift shop in that area.¬†

title: 7 Thrift and Antique Shopping Tips to Help You Find Items You Love
excerpt: I‚Äôve long been a lover of thrifting and antiquing‚Äîfor home decor, furniture, clothing, kids‚Äô toys, and more. While the process may take a little longer, I think it‚Äôs well worth the extra time and energy. There are so many high-quality, unique pieces to be found secondhand .
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I‚Äôve long been a lover of thrifting and antiquing‚Äîfor home decor, furniture, clothing, kids‚Äô toys, and more. While the process may take a little longer, I think it‚Äôs well worth the extra time and energy. There are so many high-quality, unique pieces to be found secondhand.

Over time, I‚Äôve developed a go-to process that helps me navigate the world of thrifting and antiquing with more ease and intention.

It‚Äôs so helpful to have a list written down before you step foot in a thrift or antique store. This will help you stay focused on the things that will actually add value to your life, and not get distracted by things that will only become extra clutter. In my most recent thrifting trip, I was specifically searching for a new pair of jeans and a white button-up shirt, which helped me hone in my search in the store. I consider a Pinterest board a ‚Äúlist‚Äù as well, so if you‚Äôre a visual person, that might work for you too.

Take a quick lap around the sections where you‚Äôre most likely to find what‚Äôs on your list. Add things to your cart that catch your attention. Then go back to certain aisles where you think you might find something really specific and want to dig a little deeper. Take a little more time on this second look, because sometimes you might miss things on the first lap.

Once you‚Äôve made your way through the store, edit down your cart and return anything to the shelves that you don‚Äôt truly need/want. Ask yourself a couple of questions and get specific in your answers.

I‚Äôve come across so many great things while thrifting and antiquing, but many of them were items I didn‚Äôt actually need at the moment. While the lower price points at many of these stores may be tempting, the reality is that if you don‚Äôt edit down what goes in your cart, you‚Äôll probably end up with some things you don‚Äôt actually use.

The more regularly you go thrifting or antiquing, the better you‚Äôll become at navigating each store and narrowing in on the pieces you really want to bring home. I often like to go to a few stores in one afternoon to make the most of my time. On other occasions, I only have fifteen minutes to spare, so I‚Äôll bop through a store and quickly browse one specific section. Either way, consistency is important when it comes to thrift and antique shopping.

Sometimes when I go to a thrift or antique store, I don‚Äôt find anything to bring home. That‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôll find the items on your list when you find them‚Äîyou can‚Äôt rush the process. Thrifting and antiquing are about the hunt. For me, it‚Äôs about finding unique pieces that will bring personality and character to my home or wardrobe. And when I find something I love, it‚Äôs well worth the time and effort that may have gone into the search.

If you‚Äôre going to a thrift store that accepts donations, make the most of your trip and bring something (or a couple of things) to donate when you go.

Last but certainly not least: If you can help it, never go thrifting or antiquing on an empty stomach (or thirsty, for that matter). Sifting through aisles and aisles of goods requires energy, and it will be a much more enjoyable experience if you‚Äôre satiated beforehand. Trust me on this.

title: 7 Short, Meaningful Books to Read This Summer
excerpt: I read every chance I possibly get. Multiple books at a time, often just a few pages when I have a couple of minutes to spare. This is not an endorsement of fragmented consumption; it‚Äôs just how I sneak in some sustenance at this point in my life. I am delighted that my kids l‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I read every chance I possibly get. Multiple books at a time, often just a few pages when I have a couple of minutes to spare. This is not an endorsement of fragmented consumption; it‚Äôs just how I sneak in some sustenance at this point in my life. I am delighted that my kids love to read too, so we sometimes all sit down and read together at home. It‚Äôs become one of those rituals that grounds us. Not without effort, but we‚Äôre all more settled into ourselves after we do.
I find a lot of my reading inspiration from people I follow on Instagram, like my sister @alliearends, @elementstyle, and @brittanychaffee. Other recs come from Substacks by great writers (like Pulling the Thread by Elise Loehnen) and writers who teach writing (highly recommend book(ish) by the brilliant Josh Cook). I look for books that help me see something differently‚Äîespecially the ones that are quiet, a little strange, or written so beautifully it makes you want to reread a sentence three times.Today I‚Äôm sharing a handful of meaningful reads (around 200 pages or less) that leave you with the quiet sense of, Oh, this is what life is about. They‚Äôre lovely books to read this summer, or any time of year, for that matter.

Summary: A lyrical meditation on the color blue, grief, desire, and memory.Why I Love It: It‚Äôs a book you don‚Äôt read so much as absorb. Her fragments feel like pieces of a mosaic that, together, make something bigger than the sum of their parts. I return to it when I feel too much or not enough. She says what I am sometimes too afraid to admit to myself.

Summary: Thirty-nine women are imprisoned underground with no explanation. One girl, the youngest of them all, begins to question what else might be possible.Why I Love It: It‚Äôs eerie and haunting and profound. It made me question everything I thought I knew about identity, freedom, and what it means to be human. I read it twice in one week.

Summary: Set in 1980s Ireland, a coal merchant discovers unsettling truths about a local convent and must decide what kind of man he wants to be.Why I Love It: It‚Äôs short, sparse, and deeply moving. The kind of book that leaves you with a lump in your throat and a new understanding of quiet courage.

Summary: A raw and intimate diary chronicling the author‚Äôs obsessive affair with a younger man.Why I Love It: Ernaux doesn‚Äôt flinch. The diary is unedited and beautifully written. A portrait of her late 40s, unraveling and itching to self-detonate without apology. She shows you the hunger, the madness, the waiting‚Äîand somehow makes it all feel universal.

Summary: A woman refuses to get out of the swimming pool, and in the process, all of the secrets hidden beneath her marriage come out.Why I Love It: It‚Äôs surreal and sharp, with a thread of humor running through the tension. Reads like a short film. Totally unexpected and totally brilliant.

Summary: A shepherd boy sets out on a journey to find treasure and discovers his personal legend along the way.Why I Love It: It‚Äôs simple but powerful. A reminder that the answers are often within us‚Äîand that the detours are part of the path.

Summary: A dreamlike collection of stories set in a mythical version of the author‚Äôs hometown, filled with surreal imagery and poetic prose.Why I Love It: Schulz writes like no one else. His stories feel like memories from another life‚Äîstrange, rich, and a little bit enchanted.

title: Why Adult Friendships Matter and 17 Simple Ways to Connect With Friends
excerpt: I‚Äôve been thinking about how Joe and I, at our core, share a really deep friendship. Admiration, delight, shorthand jokes, the shebang. But it‚Äôs changed over time, as marriages and friendships do. Our kids‚Äîwhom we love more than words can encapsulate‚Äîhave become a wedge in som‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I‚Äôve been thinking about how Joe and I, at our core, share a really deep friendship. Admiration, delight, shorthand jokes, the shebang. But it‚Äôs changed over time, as marriages and friendships do. Our kids‚Äîwhom we love more than words can encapsulate‚Äîhave become a wedge in some ways. It‚Äôs like‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre co-leads on this high-stakes group project, and we both really don‚Äôt want to screw it up. (Spoken as someone with a combined fourteen years of therapy under her belt.)
Pressure and structure aren‚Äôt ideal conditions for friendship. In this kind of scenario, the sense of lightness, the seeing and being seen, can quietly shrink. We‚Äôre in a different phase, one built on resilience, communication, and clarity. But it leaves an opening for closeness that can feel like loss.¬†We don‚Äôt talk about adult friendships like we talk about romantic relationships, but we should.
Because adult friendships can be just as formative and necessary. In many ways, they offer a kind of freedom our romantic or work partnerships can‚Äôt. Our friends are not usually directly affected by our decisions, so they can tell us the truth. And if we‚Äôre lucky, they delight in us for who we are, not for what we do.

Lately, I‚Äôve been reaching outside of my marriage for the kinds of friendships that fill in the gaps. I‚Äôve encouraged Joe to do the same. Not in a dramatic or betraying way. We‚Äôre just reaching for a connection that nourishes what this busy season of life seems to starve: joy. Spontaneous conversation. Shared curiosity. The kind of love that says, I care about you with no strings attached.
That last part is important.‚ÄúNo strings attached‚Äù means:

And let‚Äôs be honest: A lot of us are so caught up in our own unresolved shit that we‚Äôre not even available to be the friend we want.
Friendship, real friendship, is a mirror. But not the shiny kind you hang on the wall. It‚Äôs the kind that reflects you back to yourself with love, holding your contradictions without flinching; that reminds you who you are when you forget.
You don‚Äôt have to do a lot to keep a friendship alive. You just have to delight in the other person. That‚Äôs the key. That‚Äôs what we all want. Someone who says, ‚ÄúI see you, and it brings me joy.‚Äù
And we can‚Äôt just want that‚Äîwe have to offer it. It doesn‚Äôt take big sweeping acts of commitment or even lavish ‚Äúcatch-up‚Äù lunches. It takes showing up IN life, rather than sitting on the periphery.

You don‚Äôt have to do a lot to keep a friendship alive. You just have to delight in the other person. That‚Äôs the key. That‚Äôs what we all want. Someone who says, ‚ÄúI see you, and it brings me joy.‚Äù

Cultivating friendships in adulthood doesn‚Äôt come naturally to me. It‚Äôs something I‚Äôve had to learn slowly, sometimes awkwardly, because it‚Äôs also something I‚Äôve deeply longed for. For a lot of my life, I didn‚Äôt feel like I had it. Not in the way I craved: mutual, safe, delight-filled. I always felt like I needed to sing and dance my way to connection and safety.¬†
So now, I try to be intentional. I mess up and don‚Äôt show up sometimes. But I keep trying. I keep trying to be the friend I want in life. These are a few ways I keep connections alive with friends:

Sometimes? Friendships change and people drift. Misunderstandings happen. Sometimes things are broken beyond repair. I used to see that as failure. Now I see it as part of being human. When it feels right, I try to repair‚Äîreach out, name the hurt, stay open. And when it doesn‚Äôt? I let go with love and wish them the best.¬†Not every friendship lasts forever, but each one teaches you something about who you are and how you love.
You don‚Äôt need a big group, perfectly coordinated schedules, or elaborate plans.¬†You just need a few people who make you feel good in your body. Safe in your nervous system. Seen and accepted for who you are.
