No matter your hair type, everyone can struggle with thinning hair. As someone with afro-textured hair, the first time I straightened it, I expected it to look as thick and full as it did in its natural curls. Reader, it did not. Since then, I‚Äôve learned all the tricks of the trade to get naturally fuller, thicker hair. From extensions to hair thickening serums to rice water treatments and more, I‚Äôve tried it all. But to truly understand the science behind hair volume and density, I sought expert guidance to help me find the best hair thickening products.

I spoke with Devin Graciano, hair stylist and Head of Product Development at Goldie Locks. Graciano enlightened me about the difference between hair density and hair thickness. Density is the number of strands on your head, while thickness is the width of each strand. Collectively, both create the appearance of your hair volume. So, to achieve thicker hair, it‚Äôs key to understand your hair type, as well as what‚Äôs causing your hair‚Äôs thinness.

Featured image from our interview with Babba Rivera by Belath√©e Photography.

How to Actually Get Thicker Hair, According to an Expert

Hair thickness is largely determined by genetics‚Äîbut that doesn‚Äôt mean you can‚Äôt give your strands a boost. For naturally thinner hair, nourishing it inside and out is essential to keeping it healthy and full. If your hair is losing density, it could be due to aging (slower growth is normal over time), stress, childbirth, nutritional deficiencies, or genetic conditions like alopecia. Sometimes, a clogged scalp can also be the culprit‚Äîin which case, adding a scalp scrub to your routine can help stimulate circulation and encourage growth.

With all these contributing factors to hair loss or thinning, many of us will likely ask ourselves: can you fake it until you make it? When it comes to creating texture and volume, you‚Äôre in luck. Read on for Graciano‚Äôs insights on the best hair thickening products to give your tresses a more voluminous look.

As we get older, slower hair growth is normal and might result in thinning. Some people also experience hair loss from stress, childbirth, or nutritional deficiencies, as well as genetic conditions like alopecia.

Is there anything proven to thicken hair?

Countless studies have explored ways to achieve thicker hair‚Äîfrom boosting density to temporarily plumping each strand. While DIY methods abound, there are also proven ingredients worth seeking out when thicker, fuller hair is the goal.

Ingredients That Can Help Thicken Hair

Ingredients that show a great improvement in hair thickness include:

  • Saw palmetto
  • Rosemary
  • Scutellaria baicalensis
  • Soy
  • Wheat

Boosting hair density involves looking at both internal and external factors. Hair is made of sulfur, iron, oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen, so getting enough of these key minerals is essential for new growth. Deficiencies, along with factors like inflammation, poor diet, sleep, and hydration, can all show up in the health of your hair.

Do thickening products damage hair?

Generally speaking, no. Hair thickeners typically consist of either hair fibers that attach to the hair or water-soluble polymers that can‚Äôt overtake your hair‚Äôs overall integrity.

How long does it take for a hair thickener to work?

For styling products, results can be seen in minutes. These formulas coat the hair shaft, creating the appearance of thicker strands almost instantly. Ingredients like hydroxyethylcellulose can plump each hair fiber within a few minutes.

When using supplements or treatments that target new growth, allow for a full hair growth cycle (around three months) before expecting visible results.

Daily Routines That Can Help Prevent Thinning

Consistency is key when it comes to thicker hair. In addition to using hair thickening products, try:

  • Taking a balanced hair supplementto support growth from within.
  • Eating a nutrient-rich dietand staying hydrated.
  • Managing stress, which can have a direct impact on hair shedding.
  • Doing a daily scalp massage. Just four minutes can boost circulation and stimulate follicles.

Bottom line: While genetics play a big role, the right combination of nutrition, lifestyle habits, and hair thickening products can help you achieve fuller, healthier-looking hair.

title: Why a Writing Ritual Is the Ultimate Creativity Boost‚ÄîHow to Design One for Yourself
excerpt: I‚Äôve long believed that a happy, healthy life is built on rituals. From your morning routine to your evening wind-down, our days flow with more ease when we anchor them with supportive habits . Rituals cut through decision fatigue and help us weave intention into the everyday.‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I‚Äôve long believed that a happy, healthy life is built on rituals. From your morning routine to your evening wind-down, our days flow with more ease when we anchor them with supportive habits. Rituals cut through decision fatigue and help us weave intention into the everyday. By committing to practices that help us feel our best, we strengthen self-trust‚Äîand that reliability becomes a fixture of our days. As a writer, that truth shows itself most in my daily writing rituals.

Writing is a strange career‚Äîpart craft, part inspiration. On good days, words spill easily. On others, even a single sentence feels impossible. But my writing ritual is what steadies me. It‚Äôs the structure I lean on to move past the blank page and into flow.

Featured image from our interview with Remi Ishizuka by Michelle Nash.

What are writing rituals?

Writing rituals are the consistent set of steps we take to prepare ourselves before putting pen to paper. While they look different for everyone, writing rituals all serve the same purpose: to feel energized, grounded, and inspired before diving into the work. Sometimes they‚Äôre simple; sometimes they‚Äôre deeply idiosyncratic. What matters most is that they put us in a headspace with greater freedom to create.

Think of them as a way to bypass hesitation. When you‚Äôve set the stage‚Äîyour environment, your mindset, your tools‚Äîyou can step into writing without overthinking. With fewer variables to wrestle with, you open the door for creative flow.

History is full of proof that rituals work:

  • wrote standing at his typewriter, believing the posture helped him stay alert.Ernest Hemingway
  • rented a small hotel room for months at a time, bringing only yellow pads, a dictionary, and a Bible. She needed the quiet separation from home to write.Maya Angelou
  • wrote before dawn, explaining she wanted to ‚Äúget up before the sun‚Äù so the world hadn‚Äôt yet placed demands on her.Toni Morrison
  • ended her writing days with a ritual glass of scotch, followed by rereading everything she had written so she could step back in the next morning with confidence.Joan Didion

Each practice is unique, but the principle is the same: consistency creates momentum.

Reflection Prompt

Before you dive into designing your own writing ritual, pause and ask yourself:

  • When in the day do I feel most energized?
  • What spaces or environments make me feel most alive?
  • What small comforts (music, candle, tea, movement) help me focus?

These questions help you design a ritual that feels natural and inspiring‚Äîone you‚Äôll actually want to return to.

Writing Rituals to Cultivate for Everyday Inspiration

1. Put Yourself in the Path of Inspiration

Many call this ‚Äúpre-writing,‚Äù and while creativity is often thought of as an inherent trait, I believe it‚Äôs an orientation and approach to life. It‚Äôs a way of looking at the world with hope and optimism, understanding that every day is an opportunity to amplify the inputs you take in. The best writing doesn‚Äôt come from staring at the page‚Äîit comes from what you notice and absorb before you sit down.

Try experimenting with simple inspiration rituals like:

  • Carrying a notebook (or using your Notes app) to capture thoughts before they disappear.
  • Beginning each writing session by free-writing for five minutes about anything that‚Äôs on your mind.
  • Reading a poem, essay, or a page of a favorite bookto spark rhythm and language.
  • Taking a short walk to reset your energy and let ideas rise to the surface.
  • Creating an ‚Äúinspiration box‚Äù: a collection of quotes, images, or snippets of writing that fuel you.

Reflection Prompt

What practices make me feel most energized to create? Am I more inspired after reading, walking, or spending quiet time alone? Experiment with one practice for a week and see how it shifts your writing energy.

2. Habit Stack Your Writing

It‚Äôs no secret‚Äîwe love habit stacking. By pairing a desired habit with one you already practice, the behavioral technique makes it easier for you to incorporate and build new rituals into your life. And spoiler: writing can be one of them.

title: 5 Pitch Deck FAILS That Make Industry Pros Say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Out‚Äô
excerpt: I‚Äôve seen a LOT of pitch deck fails in my time as a script editor here at B2W . And whether it‚Äôs film funds, script labs or co-production markets, the same problems show up again and again.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Pitch Deck FAILS

I‚Äôve seen a LOT of pitch deck fails in my time as a script editor here at B2W. And whether it‚Äôs film funds, script labs or co-production markets, the same problems show up again and again.

Here are 5 red flags that make professionals quietly close your deck before you‚Äôve even got to the good bits. Ready? Let‚Äôs go!

1) Opening with a bloody quote

Look, I get it: you love storytelling. You‚Äôre deep, poetic, meaningful. Maybe even a bit mystical.

But that‚Äôs not what your pitch deck is for!! Agents, investors, broadcasters, producers want clarity and story. Don‚Äôt open with a quote from Marcus Aurelius, Charlie Kaufmann or Aaron Sorkin.

Instead, open with a dilemma. What‚Äôs broken in your storyworld? Who‚Äôs in pain? What‚Äôs the central conflict? What do your characters NEED?

Lead with that, not something that sounds like it belongs on a Pinterest board. MORE: A Foolproof Guide to Writing A Killer Pitch Deck

2) Your logline is whack

If I have to read your logline twice to figure out what the story is? It‚Äôs not ready.

You need to be able to say your logline in one breath. It should make people lean in, not zone out.

If it starts sounding like a synopsis or makes me ask ‚ÄúWait, who‚Äôs the protagonist again?‚Äù, rewrite it.

Litmus test: Ask your mate who‚Äôs not in film to read or listen to it. If they go, ‚ÄúOh yeah, I get it,‚Äù you‚Äôre good.

But if they just nod politely? You‚Äôre not, you‚Äôve got a pitch deck fail on your hands . Simple as that!

3) Trendy Moodboards (ugh)

NEWSFLASH: Twelve moody stills from Under The Skin and The Lobster do not a moodboard make.

Your visuals need to do more than look cool. They need to show us how the film feels. That means atmosphere, emotion, vibe ‚Äî not just what‚Äôs fashionable right now.

Try this: one great image per act that captures your world and tone. That‚Äôs more effective than a random collection of screenshots that scream ‚ÄúI watched A24‚Äôs or Blumhouse‚Äôs entire back catalogue this weekend‚Äù.

3) The team is all vibes (nooooo!)

This is when the team section says ‚Äúemerging‚Äù or ‚Äúpassionate‚Äù ‚Ä¶ and nothing else.

I see this all the time. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a team of emerging voices.‚Äù Cool ‚Ä¶ emerging from where? Into what? Have you made shorts? Been selected for a lab? Directed community work? Shadowed on a set? Got a mentor? Back it up!

If you‚Äôre new, that‚Äôs fine, but give us something real. Otherwise, it reads like filler.

5) No clue who the audience is ‚Äî or how the hell they‚Äôll see it

Saying, ‚ÄúThis story needs to be told,‚Äù is nice. But who‚Äôs going to watch it? Where? Why?

You need a clear sense of audience, platforms, festivals, partners ‚Äî whatever route you see this project taking.

Even if it‚Äôs a best guess, that‚Äôs better than a shrug.

Remember, this isn‚Äôt just about making a beautiful film. It‚Äôs about making something that connects AND travels.

BONUS PITCH DECK FAIL!

6) Your Director‚Äôs Statement sounds like a film studies essay

Cut the waffle. Start with this: Why YOU? Why now? Why this story?

Then build out from there.

No one wants to read 500 words on magical realism unless it tells them who you are and what drives you. Get to the heart of it all and fast!!

TL;DR?

Your pitch deck shouldn‚Äôt be mysterious, poetic or vague. Avoid these pitch deck fails by ensuring it is ‚Ä¶

  • Clear
  • Character-driven
  • Audience-aware
  • Rooted in your voice and experience

Avoid these pitch deck fails and you‚Äôll be miles ahead of the pack. Seriously.

Have you fallen into any of these mega fails?

Don‚Äôt be shy ‚Äî we all have. Come chat to me about it over on Telegram this August, where we‚Äôll be workshopping the HOOK in your novel or screenplay (and how to actually sell the damn thing). Click below to join us ‚Äì best of all, it‚Äôs FREE!

title: How NOT To Write at Home (Unless You Enjoy Back Pain and Meltdowns)
excerpt: Ah, the dream: pyjama-clad brilliance, coffee in hand, your genius pouring out between bites of leftover takeout. Writing from home sounds idyllic ‚Ä¶ until it isn‚Äôt.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The Truth About Writing At Home

Ah, the dream: pyjama-clad brilliance, coffee in hand, your genius pouring out between bites of leftover takeout. Writing from home sounds idyllic ‚Ä¶ until it isn‚Äôt.

The truth? ‚ÄúFreedom‚Äù becomes flailing, the couch becomes a chiropractor‚Äôs nightmare, and somehow your word count is still zero after three hours of ‚Äúgetting in the zone.‚Äù

Let‚Äôs bust the myth of the home-writing utopia and talk about the chaos it actually breeds. Because unless you enjoy back pain, creative paralysis, and emotionally bonding with your cat more than your screenplay, it‚Äôs time for some real talk.

1) The Ergonomic Horror Show

You: hunched over a laptop, shoulders tight, neck bent like a wilted daisy. Your writing ‚Äúdesk‚Äù is a coffee table. Or worse, it‚Äôs your bed. Unless you‚Äôre cosplaying a broken puppet, this is a one-way ticket to chronic pain.

Improper ergonomics is a one-way ticket to chronic pain. Not only is it uncomfortable, yes, but it also messes up your health long-term. We‚Äôre talking repetitive strain injuries, nerve compression, and back issues that could outlive your plotline.

And let‚Äôs not pretend you‚Äôre immune because you‚Äôre ‚Äústill young.‚Äù Your spine doesn‚Äôt care.

HOW TO WORK FROM HOME: Invest in a real chair. Get a desk. Raise that screen.

2) Clutter Causes Creative Death Spirals

You might think that scattered papers and half-empty mugs give your desk a lived-in charm, but let‚Äôs call it what it is: a distraction swamp. That pile of sticky notes is not ‚Äúcontrolled chaos.‚Äù It‚Äôs a focus-killer.

Visual clutter saps your attention span. Every out-of-place item is an attention hook pulling you away from your scene, character, or outline. And no, you‚Äôre not quirky for keeping five empty LaCroix cans. You‚Äôre just dehydrated and surrounded by junk.

HOW TO WORK FROM HOME: Organising your office is one of the best things you can do for yourself. Design your setup to support your process, not derail it. If you‚Äôre digging under books to find your pen, you‚Äôre wasting time. A clean and functional workspace maintains clarity.

3) The Procrastination Olympics

Nothing like a blank page to remind you that your baseboards haven‚Äôt been cleaned since 2020. Suddenly, folding laundry feels urgent. You snack. You scroll. You decide now is the time to research the complete history of medieval goat armor. Anything but writing.

You tell yourself you‚Äôre ‚Äúwaiting for inspiration.‚Äù Sure. Just like Netflix waits for you to finish one episode before autoplaying five more. Inspiration isn‚Äôt always reliable. Routine is what gets words on the page.

HOW TO WORK FROM HOME: There are ways to beat procrastination and self-sabotage. Create goals. Use timers. Reward yourself like you‚Äôre training a golden retriever. But don‚Äôt pretend procrastination is part of your ‚Äúprocess.‚Äù It‚Äôs part of your problem.

4) Isolation Station

You haven‚Äôt spoken aloud in eight hours. Your social skills are rusting. Your pet now has a producer credit because you keep pitching scenes to them. Welcome to the isolation spiral.

Writing is a solo sport, but that doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre meant to be a hermit. Prolonged isolation tanks your mood, dulls your thinking, and makes every bad writing day feel like a personal crisis. It‚Äôs less ‚Äúreclusive genius‚Äù and more ‚Äúslightly feral screenwriter.‚Äù

HOW TO WORK FROM HOME: Fighting that loneliness starts with community. Join a critique group or schedule co-working sessions. Talk to actual humans who can remind you that your screenplay isn‚Äôt garbage and your personality still exists outside your Word doc.

5) The ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Just Write When I Feel Like It‚Äù LIE

You feel like writing until you don‚Äôt. And guess what? You won‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel like it‚Äù most days. If your writing strategy is based on vibes, your output will be a disaster. Sure, you absolutely can rely on inspiration when you‚Äôve got plenty of experience under your belt, but until then, stick to a routine.

Unstructured time is seductive. It lures you in with promises of flexibility, but in reality, it‚Äôs a productivity graveyard. Real writers don‚Äôt wait for a muse. They build routines and show up anyway. It‚Äôs neither glamorous nor romantic. But it works.

title: 6 Top Tips For Writing About Controversial Topics
excerpt: Writing about controversial topics can feel like walking through a minefield. One wrong step and the internet might explode.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
All About Writing Controversial Topics

Writing about controversial topics can feel like walking through a minefield. One wrong step and the internet might explode.

These 6 tips on writing controversial topics don‚Äôt guarantee that the internet won‚Äôt explode. However, the points below gave me the confidence to write about it and even publish the book,¬† Until the Walls Come Down.

My novel is a story about a Jewish Israeli woman who discovers her childhood home in Jaffa used to belong to her Palestinian husband‚Äôs family. Here‚Äôs what I learned navigating the very real ‚Äì and potentially controversial ‚Äì elements of my story.

1) Do the research

This sounds obvious, but when you write about controversial topics, research is especially important. For Until the Walls Come Down, I talked to Israeli Arabs, Palestinians living in Israel, and activists in Jaffa, as well as to people who became ultra-orthodox.

In Israel we call these people khozrim betshuva (literally ‚Äúreturning in answer‚Äù). It is a kind of repentance and ‚Äúgoing back‚Äù to religion, even for people who grew up in secular communities). I read lots of books, particularly studies that feature interviews with different people, so that I can get a feel for the personalities and motivations.

2) Keep it human

While I wrote characters who represent particular populations, it was important to me not to have a token character. That‚Äôs why I have several characters from each ‚Äúidentity group‚Äù. They disagree on fundamental things, just like in life.

For instance, Barak and Tammar are siblings and represent secular Jewish Israelis. However, their views of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict are very different. Ali, his father, Muhammad, and Sara, the activist, represent Palestinians, but again with very different political views.

3) Use sensitivity readers (even if you don‚Äôt call them that)

This is crucial to get the details of the life right. I learned this from being an immigrant. It took me a couple of years of living in London to develop an understanding of which brands are considered ‚Äòposh‚Äô, for instance. The easiest way to get more details right is to have someone with lived experience read through your descriptions.

You don‚Äôt even have to call them sensitivity readers (as long as you pay them for their time ‚Äì in money or cupcakes, whatever they choose). I was very reluctant to ask any ultra-orthodox person to read through the book because I have an explicit sex scene. However, I have a friend who worked as a family physician for years in an ultra-orthodox community. She was instrumental in helping me get the flavour of life there.

MORE: Why Should Writers Work With A Sensitivity Reader?

4) Set Boundaries

Writing about difficult topics is emotionally taxing. I was about two-thirds of the way through my almost final draft of the book on October 7th, 2023. My social media feed exploded with painful posts. First, from my Israeli friends and family; then from my Palestinian loved ones.

For a long time, going into my IG account meant holding an immense amount of pain while being able to do almost nothing about it. Right from the get-go, I set firm boundaries for myself. For instance, I never watched videos. I‚Äôm thankful for that luxury: traumatising myself wouldn‚Äôt have helped my traumatised family and friends. Safeguarding my own mental health meant I was able to be there for them.

5) Build (and maintain) your support network

I don‚Äôt know what I would have done without my people. My partner read the book and literally pushed me to publish it. My Israeli friends read versions of the book and gave me their unvarnished opinions.

My writer friends read versions of the book and pointed out plot holes and weird quirks. Besides, you need your network to talk you off the ledge when you feel like this is stupid, and you may as well give up and get a proper job.

title: 3 Ways Anti-Wokists Are Right About Storytelling In The 2020s
excerpt: ‚ÄòAnti-wokists‚Äô are those voices in the culture wars claiming stories have become ‚Äútoo political.‚Äù They complain that writers are prioritising agendas over quality. They may say that entertainment has lost its way altogether.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Let‚Äôs Talk about So-Called ‚ÄòAnti-Wokists‚Äô

‚ÄòAnti-wokists‚Äô are those voices in the culture wars claiming stories have become ‚Äútoo political.‚Äù They complain that writers are prioritising agendas over quality. They may say that entertainment has lost its way altogether.

Let‚Äôs get one thing clear first: no, I have not lost or changed my mind. I believe in inclusion, authentic representation, and thoughtful storytelling. (It would be bonkers if I didn‚Äôt, I literally wrote an entire book on this!).

But I also believe in looking critically at all perspectives ‚Ä¶ Yes, even the ones we fundamentally disagree with. (Because, obviously ‚Äì on BOTH counts).

While a great deal their rhetoric is based in fear, nostalgia, or outright prejudice, here‚Äôs the uncomfortable truth ‚Ä¶ Sometimes, ‚ÄòAnti-wokists‚Äô have a point. Not in the way they think, but in ways that are useful for us ‚Äì as storytellers ‚Äì to reflect on.

So here are just 3 ways anti-wokists may have a point ‚Ä¶ and what we can learn as writers from them. Ready? Let‚Äôs go!

1) Storytelling SHOULDN‚ÄôT Be A Moral Lecture

One of the most frequent complaints from the anti-woke crowd is that stories are becoming too preachy. And to be honest? They‚Äôre not entirely wrong.

Audiences don‚Äôt show up for lectures. They come for compelling characters, emotional stakes, and narrative tension. When a story stops cold to deliver a message ‚Äì however worthy ‚Äì that moment risks alienating viewers or readers.

This is often an issue for writers because they overthink the above. They strive for what I call ‚Äòmoral perfectionism‚Äô in their drafts, rather than a good story. This frequently shows up as writers trying to write about issues ‚Ä¶ without including those issues!

When I ask them why, they may say they‚Äôre worried about replicating the bad things in the world. Yet writing about such bad things does not have to mean endorsing such bad things.

So I am NOT saying writers should avoid meaningful themes. It means we need to *integrate* those themes organically, through character choices and conflict, rather than shoehorn them in as statements of intent.

B2W TAKEAWAY: If it feels like a sermon, it probably won‚Äôt land. As I frequently say to Bang2writers: obsessing over theme will literally ruin your story! Theme is the meaning behind the story, not the top layer.

2) Fiction Is Not the Same as Reality

‚ÄòIt‚Äôs just a story‚Äô is often used to dismiss legitimate critiques. Obviously, that sucks. As I always say on this blog and accompanying B2W social media, writing IS a political act after all!

But the anti-wokists ARE right when they say that fiction and reality are different. There really is no substitute for proper outreach and education.

Most stories ‚Äì especially individual ones ‚Äì do not shift culture single-handedly. Harmful tropes, stereotypes, and prejudices gain their power through long-term, cumulative repetition across thousands of works. They frequently mirror what society already believes rather than create it from scratch.

This isn‚Äôt to say writers have no responsibility. We absolutely do. But it‚Äôs helpful to acknowledge that any single piece of fiction is unlikely to be the tipping point in a cultural conversation.

B2W TAKEAWAY: All stories exist within a larger, societal context. One story won‚Äôt change everything, but patterns across many stories DO. Know the context, and make intentional choices within it. That‚Äôs how we subvert reader and audience expectations, but also how we do our bit in challenging unconscious bias ‚Ä¶ including our own!

MORE: Movies Have Always Been ‚ÄòWoke‚Äô. You Just Didn‚Äôt Notice

3) Entertainment Comes First!

Many anti-wokists claim that modern stories are prioritising messaging over entertainment value. While their definition of ‚Äúmessaging‚Äù is often reactionary or misinformed, their basic critique holds up: if a story doesn‚Äôt engage, people won‚Äôt stick around for that deeper meaning.

It doesn‚Äôt matter how progressive or powerful your themes are. If your characters are flat, your dialogue is clunky, or your pacing drags, your story will fail to connect. Great storytelling doesn‚Äôt just inform; it *moves* people on an emotional level.

title: Top 10 Fillers To Delete From Your Screenplay Or Novel Right Now
excerpt: If you‚Äôre editing your draft right now, then the delete key is your friend ‚Ä¶ especially when it comes to storytelling fillers. But what are these? Well, fillers are those moments in your story that seem like action, but serve no real storytelling purpose .
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Delete Delete Delete!

If you‚Äôre editing your draft right now, then the delete key is your friend ‚Ä¶ especially when it comes to storytelling fillers. But what are these? Well, fillers are those moments in your story that seem like action, but serve no real storytelling purpose.

When it comes to storytelling, actions and behaviour are king (or queen ‚Ä¶ or monarch!). Simply put, every little thing that happens in your story has to do two things ‚Ä¶

  • i) reveal character (WHO are they? WHAT is their role here? WHY are we investing in their journey?)
  • ii) Push the story forward (WHAT is happening? HOW does this add to the conflict or build tension? WHY is this part of )The Story Chain?

Unfortunately, many authors and screenwriters clutter up their stories with incidental, boring and dull fillers instead. Here‚Äôs some of the ones I see most often ‚Ä¶ Ready? Let‚Äôs go!

1) Sipping drinks¬†

This has to be one of my ultimate pet peeves. Coffee and tea are the most ubiquitous, but hot chocolates, frappuccinos, iced drinks, cokes, and cans also make an appearance. All. The. Time.

Another thing that annoys me is when the character spends a ridiculously long amount of time MAKING drinks. Or appreciating their drink and how delicious it is. Seriously??? It adds zilch to the story in terms of revealing character or pushing the story forward.

Look, I‚Äôm NOT saying your characters can *never* drink anything; that would be absurd. What I am talking about is how many times sipping drinks turns up in your story. If the answer is ‚Äòconstantly‚Äô, then you need to get rid.

Also, don‚Äôt have your character drink ‚Äòscalding‚Äô drinks, FFS. Totally ridiculous and another big fat YAWN!

2) Getting Dressed / Picking Out Clothes

Most wardrobe choices are not story-worthy, FACT. This means skipping most scenes or chapters in which characters get dressed. Again, most of us do this daily.

There are some exceptions, sure ‚Ä¶ Superheroes designing their costumes could be one. Or maybe a character who is having to put on armour while having a panic attack. But do you see the difference? Reveal character, push the story forward.

3) Waking Up / Morning Routines

If your story begins with someone waking up (add an alarm clock for double-cheese points), then you need to delete. Same goes for morning routines generally. Rewrite as a matter of urgency.

Sometimes writers tell me they want to play around with massive clich√©s like this. I have sympathy for this idea, but always counsel them with these three counterpoints:

  • Readers and viewers want to join the story at the latest possible moment. This is called ‚Äòhitting the ground running‚Äô.
  • Because that‚Äôs what target audiences want, hitting the ground running is what industry pros prioritise too.
  • Also, how are we meant to know you are ‚Äòplaying around with clich√©s‚Äô? So many unpublished novels and unproduced scripts start this way FOR REAL.

Think on it. If you still decide to go for it, understand it is a considered risk.

4) Looking in the Mirror

If I see or read one more character checking themselves out in a mirror, I am gonna go POSTAL. I‚Äôm not even talking to the male writers here, female writers do this too. Seriously, stop!!

Also, stop having characters crying and looking in a mirror as ‚Äòevidence‚Äô of their inner torment. Again, bonus cheese points if they splash their faces with water first. YARGH!

Want a meaningful mirror scene? Check out Divergent‚Äòs, HERE.

5) Driving / Walking ¬†Without Purpose

Driving or walking is not dramatic. While not all of us can do either of these things, it does not reveal character or push the story forward. It‚Äôs just an everyday action.

Want a walking scene that DOES have purpose? Check out Saturday Night Fever‚Äòs, HERE.

6) Texting Or Scrolling on Phones or Watching TV/ Cinema

There‚Äôs been an absolute explosion of spec screenplays in my pile lately with characters texting or scrolling on phones. While phones *can* be useful and relevant in storytelling, showing them needs careful consideration. Unless it helps the plot in a VERY strong way, delete these moments.

title: How Great Visual Writing Works In Your Screenplay Or Novel
excerpt: Whether you‚Äôre writing a screenplay or a novel, visual storytelling is your secret weapon. Why? Because readers and viewers don‚Äôt connect with lists of facts. They connect with images, action and emotion.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
You‚Äôve Heard It All Before: ‚ÄòShow, Don‚Äôt Tell‚Äô

Whether you‚Äôre writing a screenplay or a novel, visual storytelling is your secret weapon. Why? Because readers and viewers don‚Äôt connect with lists of facts. They connect with images, action and emotion.

But how do we write these three things? Well, I‚Äôm putting them under the microscope in this blog post with 5 top tips to concentrate on. Ready? Let‚Äôs go!

Let‚Äôs explore how to write visually and bring your scenes ‚Äì and your characters ‚Äì to life.

1) Think: Scene Description = Scene Action

In screenplays, scene description *is* what we see on screen. In a visual medium, what you see is what you get! This means character behaviour is everything.

In novels, it‚Äôs the reader‚Äôs thoughts and feelings as well as their behaviour. However, that doesn‚Äôt mean your novel should necessarily be a stream of consciousness. Psychology and behaviour should be balanced.

Either way, your writing should be active, not static ‚Ä¶ and ultimately, VISUAL!

  • Bad:The living room is messy AF.
  • Better:Pizza boxes overflow all over the coffee table. A lone sock clings to the ceiling fan.

This small shift makes your world feel real, vivid, and immediate. Doris Lessing talked of ‚Äòword pictures‚Äô in her novels, which I think is a great way of describing it.

So: think in pictures, NOT summaries!

2) Nail Your Opening Image

Your opening sets the tone, whether it‚Äôs the first frame of your screenplay or the first sentence of your novel. It tells us:

  • What kind of world we‚Äôre in
  • Who the characters are
  • What kind of story we‚Äôre about to experience

Instead of opening with backstory or ‚Äúinfo-dumping,‚Äù start with action or a striking image. Consider:

  • A man sprinting barefoot across a frozen lake
  • A woman polishing a gun while singing to her cat
  • Or a child playing sedately while the adults behind them fall to the ground, convulsing

These visuals instantly provoke questions ‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs what hooks an audience or reader! MORE: How To Write Great Openers That Grab The Reader

3) Characters Are What They *Do*

Yes, yes it‚Äôs an old-fashioned writing adage but it‚Äôs TRUE. Too many stories fall down the rabbit hole of thoughts and feelings and forget about character behaviour.

So, forget the yawnsome intros. We don‚Äôt need to be told your character is ‚Äòsmart,‚Äô ‚Äòsad,‚Äô or ‚Äòsassy.‚Äô SHOW us instead.

  • For screenplays:CLARA (30s) traipses inside in full hiking gear, dragging a broken sled behind her.
  • For novels:Clara didn‚Äôt knock. She kicked the door open with a snow-caked boot, ice fragments melting on her shoulders.

Action, setting, and character behaviour tell us more than any personality label ever could.

4) Avoid Lazy, Reductive Descriptions

This is especially for female characters, but true for *everyone* ‚Ä¶ stop leading with looks!!!

  • Bad:JENNY, 25, beautiful but doesn‚Äôt know it. (ACK!)
  • Better:Jenny adjusts the strap of her stained apron, fingers blistered from a double shift.

As actor Amber Heard once said, the word ‚Äòenigmatic‚Äô often means, ‚ÄòHer backstory doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äô So, let‚Äôs NOT do that either!

Whether you‚Äôre writing screenplays or prose fiction, characters are most compelling when we understand who they are through what they do and how they move through the world ‚Ä¶ NOT through how attractive they are. (By the way, that doesn‚Äôt mean talking about how unattractive they are either. Eesh).

5) Make the Reader SEE It!

Whether your audience is an agent, or a producer, filmmaker, publisher, or reader, your job is to make them *see* what you‚Äôre writing. If you‚Äôre stuck, ask:

  • Could this scene be drawn as a storyboard?
  • What‚Äôs the dominant image here?
  • Would this make a script reader or book editor lean in, or skip ahead?

If you can‚Äôt answer these questions, that‚Äôs a big red flag!

Lastly: remember, visual writing isn‚Äôt about camera angles or describing every little thing. It‚Äôs about clarity, energy, and emotional impact. You‚Äôre not just telling a story ‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre building a *world we can feel*.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Fall is easily my favorite time of year. By early September, everything feels tinged with that ‚Äújust-right‚Äù kind of cozy‚Äîone that invites you to press pause, pull out your favorite sweater, and savor the little things. There‚Äôs something about September‚Äôs golden light that quietly whispers: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs slow down.‚Äù If you‚Äôre looking for things to do in September, trust me: you‚Äôve come to the right place.

September always feels like an opening‚Äîan invitation to step into new rhythms without the weight of expectation. I‚Äôve been noticing how easy it is for me to lean on discipline as a way of control, but the truth is, the moments I‚Äôve felt most grounded lately have come from softening‚Äîletting myself rest, saying no without guilt, or choosing presence over productivity. I‚Äôm realizing the changes that last aren‚Äôt forced, they‚Äôre allowed. With that in mind, here are a few ways to stay energized and inspired this month.

A gentle nudge

Maybe it‚Äôs asking yourself, What‚Äôs one small thing I can do today to invite a little ease into my morning?

Journal prompt

Write two tiny rituals that would make your mornings feel softer. Maybe it‚Äôs lighting a candle before your coffee or reading three pages of something beautiful before your to-do list steals your attention.

Editor recommendation of the month

‚ÄúThe best part of my morning is spritzing this all over my face. I‚Äôm a big believer in niacinamide for minimizing breakouts and dark spots. This delivers my daily dose in the best way.‚Äù ‚Äì Langa Chinyoka, Beauty Editor

SOFIE PAVITT FACE

From Breathing Space

In a world that moves fast, Camille‚Äôs Substack post The (Feminine) Energy for July reminded me that creativity blooms when we pause, when we rest. That feels like a lovely place to begin our September.

Ahead, 30 gentle invitations to savor the season‚Äîno pressure, just simple joys to linger with.

30 Things to Do in September to Stay Inspired This Month

September 1-7

1. Celebrate the unofficial last day of summer. Lounge on the lake, hang out at a BBQ, or just enjoy your own company. (Personally, I love giving my house a good deep clean.) Do whatever makes you feel best‚Äîthis is your day off!

2. Make your inbox glow. One of the best ways I‚Äôve found to combat email anxiety is to infuse my inbox with a little more joy. Subscribe to an inspiring newsletter‚Äîwho knows, you might even look forward to your email power hour.

3. Switch up your lunchtime routine. Get inspired with these intentional lunch break ideas for an *actual* reset. Oh, and if you‚Äôre looking for something new to munch on midday, Camille‚Äôs Mediterranean-inspired tuna salad recipe is it.

4. Read a beautiful book. Sometimes, you‚Äôre in it for the plot. And sometimes, it‚Äôs the words themselves that keep you captivated. These are the most awe-inspiring books we‚Äôve ever read.

5. Join (or start!) a supper club. As someone who loves to eat and socialize, a supper club is one of the perfect ways to chat over your favorite dishes. Learn everything about starting your own supper club.

6. Visit a flower market. Trust me, there are plenty of blooms to find in the fall. It‚Äôs one of the most inspiring things to do in September! Alternative: Stop by your local Trader Joe‚Äôs and browse the blooms‚Äîthe grocer stocks an endless array of floral options.

7. Romanticize your Sunday. Light a candle, turn on a cozy playlist, and take an hour to set yourself up for the week ahead. That might mean planning a few simple meals, tidying the house, or jotting down your top three priorities for Monday. A little intention goes a long way in creating space for calm. Follow Camille‚Äôs tips to make Sunday your favorite day of the week.

September 8-14

8. Learn to knit. While knitting is a year-round delight, it‚Äôs also one of my favorite things to do in September with reckless in abandon. YouTube videos are in abundance or you can visit your local knitting store and take a peek at their class schedule (many offer in-person and virtual options).

body:
I used to treat my life like a spreadsheet‚Äîcolor-coded, optimized, and every hour accounted for. If I could just find the right ratio of work to rest, ambition to stillness, I thought I‚Äôd arrive at some mythical version of balance. But the harder I tried to control it, the more elusive it became.

For years, I believed balance meant perfect proportion: work and rest, ambition and stillness, discipline and ease. But lately, I‚Äôve realized that balance isn‚Äôt the tightrope walk we‚Äôve been told it is. It‚Äôs more of a softened discipline‚Äîan intentional equilibrium that holds space for both structure and surrender. It‚Äôs choosing what matters, while letting go of the illusion that everything should weigh the same.

Featured image from our interview with Claire Zinnecker by Michelle Nash.

How 30 Days of Soft Mornings Transformed the Way I View My Routine

In practice, that‚Äôs looked like aligning my days with my values rather than arbitrary benchmarks. Annie Dillard was right: ‚ÄúHow we spend our days is, of course, how we spend our lives.‚Äù A walk counts as much as an email sent. Time with a book matters as much as time in a meeting.

The life I want isn‚Äôt built in giant leaps but in the quiet accumulation of these choices‚Äîthe ones that make my hours feel like my own.

For years, I bought into the myth that mornings had to be rigid, productive, and relentlessly optimized. But when I gave myself permission to slow down, I discovered something far more nourishing: space to actually feel awake before the world demanded anything of me.

This story isn‚Äôt just about what shifted in my own life‚Äîit‚Äôs about how you can reshape your mornings, too. Ahead, I‚Äôll share what soft mornings are, why I abandoned my 5 a.m. alarm, and how 30 days of this practice transformed the way I move through my day.

What are soft mornings?

Soft mornings are about beginning the day with gentleness rather than urgency. They‚Äôre not about hitting snooze until noon or tossing discipline out the window, but about creating space to arrive and orient yourself to the day.

Instead of rushing to check notifications or diving straight into productivity mode, a soft morning prioritizes sensory rituals‚Äîthe smell of coffee, a few quiet minutes on the porch, or the feel of a blanket pulled around your shoulders. It‚Äôs a conscious rejection of control in favor of presence.

When you let softness lead, your mornings become less about achieving and more about attuning. You move from ‚ÄúHow much can I get done before 9 a.m.?‚Äù to ‚ÄúWhat do I need to feel grounded as I begin?‚Äù For me, that shift changed everything.

Why I Gave Up My 5 A.M. Routine

For years, I bought into the idea that the earlier I woke up, the more successful I‚Äôd be. The 5 a.m. club promised productivity and a head start on the rest of the world. And while it did give me more hours, those hours often felt hollow‚Äîspent checking boxes rather than nourishing myself.

I began to notice that rigidity was making me brittle. My mornings were efficient, yes, but they left little room for the messiness of being human. A bad night‚Äôs sleep meant the entire day felt like a failure. And if I didn‚Äôt follow my routine perfectly, the guilt would creep in.

Instead, soft mornings helped me invite presence into my life. To see my mornings not as a race against the clock but as an invitation to slow down. And in doing so, I discovered that discipline doesn‚Äôt always mean pushing harder. Sometimes, it looks like loosening your grip.

What Changed

After 30 days, the most immediate shift was in my energy. Ironically, when I stopped forcing myself to get up at 5 a.m., I actually felt more awake. Giving myself permission to sleep until my body was ready meant I began my days rested rather than depleted.

My focus also sharpened. Without the frantic scramble to make mornings ‚Äúproductive,‚Äù I entered work with a clearer mind. Those first slow moments‚Äîstretching, journaling, sipping tea‚Äîacted like a buffer, softening the transition from rest to responsibility.

Summer has been all about embracing spontaneity and making the most of the long, sun-soaked days. It was filled with unforgettable family trips, time spent at our Malibu house, and diving deep into projects and passions of all sorts. As these summer days come to an end, there‚Äôs a certain bittersweet feeling that sweeps in with the cooler temps. On one hand, I‚Äôm saying goodbye to carefree afternoons by the pool. On the other, there‚Äôs something so satisfying about getting back into a routine. Autumn is a natural refresh, and it‚Äôs one of my favorite times of year to recommit to healthy habits, rituals, and fall routines that help me thrive.

Back to school (work, social obligations, and the need for structure‚Ä¶ ) marks the transition from summer‚Äôs ease to a busy season. My answer? I prioritize simplicity. Instead of saying yes to everything, paring back is my secret to success. And though it‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve graduated, I love leaning hard into the back-to-school vibes.

Fall Routines to Inspire a Seasonal Refresh

I know you can relate when I say I‚Äôm craving a reset. Let‚Äôs be real: for those of us juggling work, family, and personal aspirations, the lazy days of summer have their charm, but there‚Äôs a certain satisfaction in reclaiming our schedules and getting things done.

That‚Äôs where my fall routines come in‚Äîand my favorite products that inspire every area of my life. Across work, family, the home, and my personal time, there are endless opportunities to incorporate beautiful, productivity-boosting essentials into my every day. And because I like to pair my favorite products with intention, I‚Äôm going to show you how to reap the stress-free, joy-sparking benefits of a total fall refresh. Let‚Äôs dive in.

Getting Organized at Work

With the start of fall comes the official goodbye to summer Fridays and an easing back into a more structured work routine. But if you‚Äôre like me, the shift from beach vibes to business mode can feel a bit jarring. However, as with all of my fall routines, I like to see this as an opportunity to reset and refocus. Discover my fall routines for work that keep me focused and on-task.

Start with a fresh to-do list

One of my favorite strategies for boosting productivity is to start with a fresh to-do list, prioritizing tasks that will have the most impact. Think of it as your personal game plan for making the most of your day. And while you‚Äôre at it, carve out dedicated blocks of time for deep work, free from the ping of notifications. This has been game-changing for my workflow‚Äîyour future self will thank you when you‚Äôre breezing through projects instead of scrambling at the last minute.

Prioritize a clean space

Messy space, chaotic mind‚Äîor however the saying goes. It‚Äôs so true though: how many times have you tried to step into productivity mode only to be distracted by the clutter all around you? While I like to do a deep clean of my office every few weeks, there are days when I just don‚Äôt have the time.

When that‚Äôs the case, prioritize getting rid of visual clutter. All those sticky notes with outdated info? Recycle ‚Äôem. Is your pen holder filled with useless writing utensils? Get rid of them. Pro tip: I also like to use pretty storage boxes to contain the clutter. From there, keep out only what you need, with one or two beautiful and inspiring things thrown into the mix. (A vision board and vase with fresh blooms are my go-to‚Äôs.)

Here is my take on this exercise from a previous series of posts ‚Äî How To Read A Screenplay:

After a first pass, it‚Äôs time to crack open the script for a deeper analysis and you can do that by creating a scene-by-scene breakdown. It is precisely what it sounds like: A list of all the scenes in the script accompanied by a brief description of the events that transpire.

For purposes of this exercise, I have a slightly different take on scene. Here I am looking not just for individual scenes per se, but a scene or set of scenes that comprise one event or a continuous piece of action. Admittedly this is subjective and there is no right or wrong, the point is simply to break down the script into a series of parts which you then can use dig into the script‚Äôs structure and themes.

The value of this exercise:

  • We pare down the story to its most constituent parts: Scenes.
  • By doing this, we consciously explore the structure of the narrative.
  • A scene-by-scene breakdown creates a foundation for even deeper analysis of the story.

title: ‚ÄòThis Story Defies Genre!‚Äô Why That‚Äôs NOT The Flex You Think It Is
excerpt: Bangers we need to talk: some writers seem to think that being ‚Äúgenre-defying‚Äù is something to aspire to. That if you‚Äôre working within genre conventions, somehow your story‚Äôs less intelligent, less original, less‚Ä¶ special.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
There‚Äôs A Weird Snobbery Around Genre ‚Ä¶

Bangers we need to talk: some writers seem to think that being ‚Äúgenre-defying‚Äù is something to aspire to. That if you‚Äôre working within genre conventions, somehow your story‚Äôs less intelligent, less original, less‚Ä¶ special.

Let me be clear: that attitude is killing your script or novel. I‚Äôm not kidding.

Let‚Äôs unpack the biggest myths I hear (daily!) from writers about genre ‚Äî and why sticking your nose up at it is a mistake.

1) ‚ÄúMy story defies genre!‚Äù

Oh dear. Where do I even start? When a writer says this, what they usually mean is:

  • They don‚Äôt know what their story is really about
  • They‚Äôre trying to do everything at once, hoping something sticks
  • They‚Äôre terrified of being seen as ‚Äúformulaic‚Äù
  • They think ‚Äúgenre‚Äù means ‚Äúcheap, clich√©, or commercial‚Äù

But here‚Äôs the truth: all stories exist within genre. Even if you mash up a few ‚Äî thriller with sci-fi, horror with romance, etc. ‚Äî you‚Äôre still playing with genre expectations. You‚Äôre still part of a conversation with the audience.

And if you try to ‚Äúdefy‚Äù that conversation completely? The audience just gets confused. Or worse ‚Äî bored.

2) ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to be boxed in.‚Äù

Genre isn‚Äôt a cardboard box. It‚Äôs a toolbox.

It gives you conventions, audience expectations, and a shared language. When you know what the beats are ‚Äî and how readers/viewers anticipate them ‚Äî then you can decide how to twist or subvert them.

But if you ignore the rules before you understand them? You‚Äôre not breaking new ground. You‚Äôre just writing a mess.

3) ‚ÄúI‚Äôm writing it intuitively, I don‚Äôt want to follow a formula.‚Äù

This one really grinds my gears. You can absolutely write with instinct after you‚Äôve absorbed the craft. Just like musicians improvise after they‚Äôve learned scales, writers ‚Äúintuit‚Äù after they‚Äôve read, watched, and studied genre.

Here‚Äôs the kicker: genre is a formula ‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôs NOT a bad thing. (If you don‚Äôt like the word ‚Äòformula‚Äô, then think of genre as having CONVENTIONS).

Genre is comforting. It‚Äôs familiar. It is why audiences show up. Think about it: you wouldn‚Äôt want a murder mystery where there is no Big Reveal. Or a Rom-Com where no one falls in love. So why pretend your audience doesn‚Äôt have expectations of genre conventions?

4) ‚ÄúBut my story has something to say!‚Äù

Fantastic. It should. Genre is not the enemy of theme.

In fact, genre amplifies theme. A dystopian setting can say something about surveillance or state control. A ghost story can explore grief. A revenge thriller can interrogate justice.

Just don‚Äôt mistake vagueness for depth. If you want to be meaningful, you need to be specific ‚Ä¶ and genre helps you do exactly that.

5) ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs horror‚Ä¶ kind of. And a romance. But it‚Äôs got coming-of-age vibes. Also a heist.‚Äù

Right. So what‚Äôs the spine?

When I ask this question, I often get silence. If you can‚Äôt name the primary genre ‚Äî the one that holds the emotional arc, the structure, the engine of the story ‚Äî you‚Äôre not ready to pitch it.

Yes, stories can blend genres. But one needs to take the lead. The rest are there to support and flavour, not fight for dominance.

MORE: Writing & Selling Thriller Screenplays¬†

Stop Saying ‚ÄòGenre-Defying‚Äô!

Genre isn‚Äôt a dirty word. It‚Äôs the structure that lets your audience connect. It‚Äôs the container that holds your wild, personal, original idea and makes it watchable, sellable, shareable.

So if you‚Äôre avoiding genre because you think it‚Äôs beneath you? It‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs beneath your feet, holding your story up.

Stop saying ‚Äògenre-defying‚Äô. Learn genre instead. Use it. Then bend the rules when you know exactly what you‚Äôre doing.

And for God‚Äôs sake ‚Äî stop saying your script is ‚Äúgenre-defying‚Äù in your pitch. It‚Äôs not a flex. It‚Äôs a big fat red flag!

title: ‚ÄòNo One Will Read My Script! Access & Getting Past Industry Gatekeeping
excerpt: Let‚Äôs talk about the elephant in the writers‚Äô room: access. Or rather, the lack of it. Every single time I work with writers ‚Äì whether they‚Äôre total beginners or seasoned creatives trying to level up ‚Äì these familiar laments come up:
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
All About Industry Access

Let‚Äôs talk about the elephant in the writers‚Äô room: access. Or rather, the lack of it. Every single time I work with writers ‚Äì whether they‚Äôre total beginners or seasoned creatives trying to level up ‚Äì these familiar laments come up:

  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have access to industry professionals.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúNo one will respond to my queries.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do with a finished script.‚Äù

Sound familiar? Let‚Äôs break it down. Because yes, gatekeeping is real, but it‚Äôs also beatable. And you don‚Äôt need to be ‚Äúin the club‚Äù to make progress. Let‚Äôs go ‚Ä¶

1) The Truth About Gatekeeping

Let‚Äôs be blunt: the film and TV world is full of cliques. There‚Äôs nepotism. There‚Äôs elitism. People do get opportunities because of who they know.

But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs also true: if you‚Äôre good, consistent, and strategic, you can build access. Slowly, yes. But definitely.

Know this: the gate is REAL ‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs not locked.

MORE: 5 Unusual Things I Did To Create My Dream Writing Career

2) Why You‚Äôre Not Hearing Back

If people aren‚Äôt replying to your emails or DMs, it‚Äôs usually for one of these reasons:

  • You‚Äôre pitching cold with no context or connection
  • Your message is too long, too vague, or too ‚Äúme, me, me‚Äù
  • You‚Äôre asking too much, too soon
  • You‚Äôre not offering value or showing that you understand their role

This is not about being ‚Äúnot good enough‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs about strategy and empathy.

Want someone to read your work? Start by building a relationship, not sending a ten-page attachment to someone who didn‚Äôt ask for it.

3) The Relationship-First Rule

The industry is built on relationships. Not fake networking. Real ones. That means:

  • Follow people doing what you want to do
  • Share their work. Engage. Ask thoughtful questions
  • Be a human being, not a desperate sales pitch
  • Show up BEFORE you ask for anything

You don‚Äôt need a famous uncle. You need to become known and trusted in your niche ‚Äî even just a little.

4) No Agent? No Problem (Really!)

You do not need an agent or a producer to get read. Try this instead:

  • Enter selected competitions and labs (not all are worth it, but many are)
  • Make a short film ‚Äî it opens more doors than a dozen cold emails
  • Connect with the writing community online. Writers talk. And they refer
  • Take part in courses or mentoring schemes ‚Äî many offer bursaries or payment plans
  • Build a peer network of writers and trade reads

You are not shouting into a void. You‚Äôre building a path. One contact, one script, one ‚Äúyes‚Äù at a time.

MORE: 10 Tips On Getting An Agent (Or Doing Without One!) by Julian Friedmann from Blake Friedmann

5) When You Think ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the Point?‚Äù

If you‚Äôve ever thought:

  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what to do with a finished script.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúNo one will ever read this.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point if I don‚Äôt have connections?‚Äù

Then you‚Äôre not alone. But here‚Äôs what I tell Bang2writers:

You are already doing more than 90% of people who say they want to write. You‚Äôre building the work and the mindset that creates opportunity. No one can stop you from improving. Literally no one can stop you from writing.

And in time, the right person will say yes ‚Äî but only if you keep showing up.

Final Thoughts

You don‚Äôt need to break in. You build your way in. One contact, script, relationship at a time.

Stop waiting to be invited. Start showing up as if you already belong ‚Äì because you do.

title: The Prescient Politics of Nancy Buchanan‚Äôs Art
excerpt: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Truthfully, Nancy Buchanan: A Retrospective at the Brick, a comprehensive survey of the LA-based artist‚Äôs work, is as sprawling and diverse as the city she calls home. Buchanan studied art at the University of California, Irvine, from 1965 to 1971, along with fel‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Truthfully, Nancy Buchanan: A Retrospective at the Brick, a comprehensive survey of the LA-based artist‚Äôs work, is as sprawling and diverse as the city she calls home. Buchanan studied art at the University of California, Irvine, from 1965 to 1971, along with fellow classmates (and single mothers) Barbara T. Smith and Marcia Hafif, who would become her longtime friends and collaborators. Soon, LA peers Chris Burden, Ulysses Jenkins, and Michael Zinzun, among many others, would also work with Buchanan, together helping to define the 1970s Southern California art scene. As core faculty at the California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) for more than 30 years, as well as a founding member of the experimental F Space Gallery, and an integral part of

the Woman‚Äôs Building, Buchanan has remained deeply engaged with the city‚Äôs artistic community for more than five decades.

The exhibition‚Äôs curators draw from an expansive body of work spanning video, performance, drawing, painting, sculpture, collage, and installation. Each of the space‚Äôs nine galleries focuses on a theme that runs through Buchanan‚Äôs oeuvre, such as hair, interiors, and consumption. Early works reveal her eager engagement with both feminist politics and consumer culture; in the mock video advertisement ‚ÄúThese Creatures‚Äù (1979), images of young women with ghoulishly applied makeup are paired with a male voiceover that asks ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it amazing that we allow them to live among us, these creatures that we can and do control?‚Äù

Equally unsettling are a number of pieces that deal with military intervention and weapons technology. The installations ‚ÄúFallout from the Nuclear Family‚Äù (1980) and ‚ÄúSecurity‚Äù (1985) incorporate documents from Buchanan‚Äôs father‚Äôs career as a nuclear physicist and the artist‚Äôs own research into his complicated involvement in the development of atomic weapons. In the same gallery, ‚Äú‚Ä¶And Babies?‚Äù (2003‚Äì6) presents a large glass jar, like one might see in a laboratory setting, containing a video projection of malformed fetuses and deceased babies that Buchanan witnessed in a hospital in Vietnam, preserved to document the effects of the US use of Agent Orange in that country in the 1960s. Perhaps more horrifying is that Buchanan‚Äôs work could easily be replicated to reference the birth defects caused by depleted uranium used in the US invasion of Iraq in 2004, and other untold military conflicts.

Indeed, the main takeaway from this retrospective is that the issues Buchanan began grappling with in the 1970s ‚Äî misogyny, racism, the climate crisis, government secrecy, warfare, gentrification, and unbridled capitalist consumption ‚Äî are not past threats but hauntingly present ones. In the video sculpture ‚ÄúAmerican Dreams #7: The Price is Wrong‚Äù (1991), a miniature model of a living room, lavishly decorated with fine art paintings and gilded furnishings, holds a small television set broadcasting part of a speech by Oakland‚Äôs progressive mayor, Ron Dellums, along with attorney Mary Lee and writer Mike Davis, discussing LA‚Äôs speculative real estate market and the communities being overlooked. Nearly 30 years later, the number of California‚Äôs unhoused residents is at an all-time high. If this all feels a bit dispiriting, let hope be found in Buchanan‚Äôs artistic practice itself. Hers is an enduring legacy of creating communal strength amid forces that seek to divide.

title: An Impressionist‚Äôs Ode to Male Sensuality
excerpt: CHICAGO ‚Äî The Impressionist artists working in France in the 1800s clearly liked women. While landscapes and still lifes studded their oeuvres, they turned repeatedly to the subjects of dancers, opera singers, boaters, bathers, strollers, book readers, barmaids, and picturesqu‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
CHICAGO ‚Äî The Impressionist artists working in France in the 1800s clearly liked women. While landscapes and still lifes studded their oeuvres, they turned repeatedly to the subjects of dancers, opera singers, boaters, bathers, strollers, book readers, barmaids, and picturesque, rosy-cheeked gals in fashionable gowns and big hats. Male painters found the female form not only tantalizing but a symbol of modernity, as women explored new social access and fashions. They felt that being artists gave them license to peer (or leer).

Only recently have art historians shed light on another, lesser-known Impressionist artist, Gustave Caillebotte, whose contrarian gaze primarily focused on men and the male body. A major exhibition of his work that originated at the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay in Paris is now on view at the Art Institute of Chicago. The midwestern museum choose to change the show‚Äôs title from the original Gustave Caillebotte: Painting Men to the less definitive Gustave Calllibotte: Painting His World. Both are apt.

The show, to its credit, does not speculate on Caillebotte‚Äôs sexuality, but rather floats intrigue: Why did this artist choose to focus on the male body? The question teases the viewer by way of wall labels that identify his models as bachelors and note that he lived out of wedlock with a woman, with little known about the nature of their relationship. She is listed as ‚Äúfriend‚Äù in census data. The show charts Caillebotte‚Äôs path from Paris haute bourgeois life to a country home along the Seine where a coterie of male friends frequently visited. Here, plein-air painting, yachting, and gardening occupied him until his death at age 45. These facts function to keep the audience scrutinizing the paintings like detectives searching for evidence of homoerotic desire (or not). The AIC‚Äôs Gloria Groom, who co-curated the show, stated declaratively in the French newspaper Le Figaro, ‚ÄúHis subject matter is radical during the time because men were not supposed to stare at men, and he‚Äôs staring at men.‚Äù¬†

The most riveting painting in the exhibition, ‚ÄúMan at his Bath‚Äù (1884), portrays a well-built, naked man from the back as he towels his upper torso. His pale buttocks are tinged with pink after the hot soak. The masculine stance of splayed feet allows for the painterly definition of each leg. A night shirt or towel occupies the floor in the foreground with his shoes near a chair holding folded clothing. Wet footprints mark his trail, bringing an immediacy to the scene. Compare this to Edgar Degas‚Äôs many female bathers, who bend, turn, and scrub in awkward poses that are far less sexy. The composition suggests that someone is watching ‚Äî it‚Äôs the lingering gaze of the artist. Caillebotte was a friend and collector of Pierre-Auguste Renoir; one wonders if this is a ‚Äúcheeky‚Äù response to paintings in Caillebotte‚Äôs collection, such as ‚ÄúThe Swing‚Äù (1876), that depict pink-cheeked maidens. In the same room, his only female nude, ‚ÄúNude on a Couch‚Äù (c. 1880), shows an unidealized, thin woman reclining, with clothes piled around. Everything except her face is carefully rendered, including pubic hair and pale skin. The light is specific, from a nearby window. The painting‚Äôs unembellished, private immediacy feels unique to the time period.

A less-finished painting nearby, ‚ÄúMan Drying his Leg‚Äù (1884), reveals a greater Degas influence. Here, the same model sits naked in a chair, his leg resting on the edge of the bath as he towels himself. While the beauty of the body has classical echoes, the intimate domestic scene feels voyeuristic. There is no distanced allegorical or mythological overlay, nor any type of Jacques-Louis David ‚ÄúDeath of Marat‚Äù (1793) heroism.

title: The Rise of Contemporary Art Puzzles
excerpt: When Rami Metal walks through the scores of booths at the Armory Show, he looks not only for attention-grabbing paintings but also those that would make great puzzles.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When Rami Metal walks through the scores of booths at the Armory Show, he looks not only for attention-grabbing paintings but also those that would make great puzzles.

‚ÄúI try to find things that are more detailed and have more variance of color,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf you have 1,000 pieces and 200 of them are pieces of sky, it‚Äôs not fun. You‚Äôll get through 80 percent of the puzzle and say, ‚ÄòUgh, the sky.‚Äô‚Äù

Museum gift shops have sold puzzle sets of Impressionist and abstract masterworks for years, but there have been few options on the market featuring works by living artists who haven‚Äôt yet had their MoMA retrospective.

That‚Äôs starting to change. A handful of independent jigsaw companies, including Metal‚Äôs Kinstler Puzzles and Apostrophe Puzzles, have been licensing the work of painters virtually unknown outside the art world for their brainteasers.¬†

Apostrophe founder Mandi Masden was inspired to launch her Brooklyn-based puzzle company in 2019 after she came across a portrait by artist Charly Palmer that was outside her budget. Her friend gave her a custom puzzle of the artwork instead, prompting her to think about how puzzles could make contemporary art more accessible to the public.

‚ÄúI was really into puzzles as a kid, and I knew a lot of us had memories of them from our childhoods, but the industry itself felt stuck in the past,‚Äù Masden said. ‚ÄúI wanted to make puzzles that focused on celebrating the talent, creativity, and perspective of artists of color, while catering to a segment of the market largely ignored by the industry.‚Äù

Metal, also a passionate puzzler, found himself fitting together tiny cardboard pieces of Pieter Bruegel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Tower of Babel‚Äù (c. 1563) and Hieronymus Bosch‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Garden of Earthly Delights‚Äù (c. 1490‚Äì1510) for hours at a time well into adulthood. It was while he gallery-hopped in Chelsea and breezed through art fairs that he realized that the worlds of art puzzles and contemporary art rarely overlapped, and became inspired to combine them.

Pitching the idea of producing puzzles out of contemporary art to galleries and artists before he actually launched his business was harder. But Washington-based artist Andrea Joyce Heimer liked the concept, and licensed a rendition of her 2019 painting, ‚ÄúIn The Summer We Started Drinking During The Hot Of The Day And By Night Time We Were Monsters.‚Äù He launched Kinstler in 2021 with two additional puzzles by artists Simone Johnson and Rusudan Khizanishvili.

This month, Kinstler is releasing a new puzzle of Korean artist Ken Gun Min‚Äôs 2023 painting ‚ÄúStranger by the Lake (Bare Ass Creek),‚Äù an homage to a nude sunbathing spot in Los Angeles that was destroyed in a 2009 fire. Min, too, has loved playing with puzzles since he was a child. He was fascinated by the fact that individual fragments didn‚Äôt make visual sense until he fitted them together. Now he sees comparisons between the visual riddles and his current practice.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a mix of abstraction and spontaneity ‚Äî gestural brushstrokes, layers of pigment meeting embroidery ‚Äî but when you step back, they come together to form a story,‚Äù Min said.

For Masden, a good puzzle starts with a compelling image that tells a story and has a strong point of view. She also loves discovering nuances of brushwork and the layers of depth in a mixed media piece.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something really poetic about the image that emerges from 1,000 tiny pieces of someone‚Äôs curiosity and exploration, and I love being surprised by where that journey takes me,‚Äù she said.

Both Kinstler and Apostrophe have recruited a diverse stable of artists who earn a commission for every purchase, and their games are available for purchase in museums and bookstores across the country. The latter also donates a portion of each sale to a nonprofit organization working to expand arts education for communities of color.

Lately, Metal has been drawn to work with subtle shifting color gradients and lots of visual activity. Umar Rashid‚Äôs ‚ÄúBattle of Malibu‚Äù (2020) portrays a fictitious uprising of Los Angeles-area Indigenous tribes against a European imperial force.

title: The Fetishistic Fiction of Museum ‚ÄúTibetan‚Äù Shrines
excerpt: If American museums were the only source of information about Tibetan Buddhist shrines, one would come away with the impression that shrines are elaborate, pristine environments layered with thangka paintings and silken finery amidst rows of statuary and ritual objects organiz‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
If American museums were the only source of information about Tibetan Buddhist shrines, one would come away with the impression that shrines are elaborate, pristine environments layered with thangka paintings and silken finery amidst rows of statuary and ritual objects organized atop beautifully crafted wooden furniture. Enveloped by recordings of soft Buddhist chanting and illuminated by flickering LED butter lamps, the shrine rooms of the former Rubin Museum of Himalayan Art in New York and the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Museum of Asian Art in Washington, DC suspend visitors in a sumptuous, carefully curated environment. To this end, curators have intentionally omitted labels or didactics, ostensibly to preserve the viewer‚Äôs contemplative experience. Touted as ‚Äúmagnificent‚Äù and seen as a ‚Äúrefuge in uncertain times,‚Äù these immersive spaces have long captivated the public and media alike. But what if these beloved spaces, attracting thousands of visitors each year, are just sites of appropriation ‚Äî of both tangible and intangible cultural heritage? In light of the Brooklyn Museum of Art‚Äôs recent opening of its six-year loan of the Rubin Museum‚Äôs Tibetan Buddhist Shrine Room, I think the question is worth reexamining.

The sensory-immersive ‚ÄúTibetan Buddhist Shrine Rooms‚Äù popular in American museums since 2010 differ markedly from their predecessors of the 1930s and ‚Äô40s, when institutions such as the Newark Museum of Art in New Jersey and the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art in Staten Island displayed modest altars featuring Tibetan Buddhist devotional objects. Collector Alice Kandell first promoted the immersive shrine experience when she gifted a collection of over 220 Tibetan Buddhist objects to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery of the Smithsonian. In a 2013 essay in Art of Merit, Kandell writes about this gift and her collecting practices, claiming that she ‚Äúwanted the shrine to be as authentic as it would have been in Tibet.‚Äù A quotation from Smithsonian curator Debra Diamond notes the restrictions that came with Kandell‚Äôs gift, such as the ‚Äúlong-term display of the objects within a

liturgically appropriateand distinctly separate shrine room gallery‚Äù (emphasis added), which the Smithsonian obliged. In 2010, the Rubin Museum of Art (RMA) accepted a loan of Kandell‚Äôs ‚Äúshrine‚Äù; in 2013, it created its own version and kept it on view until 2024. Kandell shrines have also been displayed at the Michael C. Carlos Museum at Emory University (2016) and gifted to the

Minneapolis Institute of Art.

In these aforementioned displays, the ‚Äúshrines‚Äù are similarly constructed, with a shared palette of dark blues and reds accented with yellow and gold. Thangkas (paintings) often hang on the central wall, and gilt metal statuary is placed along a pyramid-like organization spilling down from the intricately carved cabinetry. All examples have embroidered banners, and some have a silk baldaquin that hangs over the central area of the shrine, often with sculptures of a wheel and two deer. By regurgitating what is largely the same shrine, however, museums are both negating the limitless variations of actual shrines and peddling a Western aesthetic of a ‚Äútraditional‚Äù or ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù Tibetan shrine that is without any scholarly or historical backing.¬†

For example, in January 2025, SmartHistory released an episode misleadingly titled ‚ÄúTibetan Buddhist Shrine Room,‚Äù which in fact only documents the RMA‚Äôs installation. As Elena Pakhoutova, curator of the RMA‚Äôs ‚Äúshrine room‚Äù explains, the display is a ‚Äúcurated installation that presented the objects how they may have been displayed and used in a traditional Tibetan Buddhist household.‚Äù Museum installations lean problematically on the language of ‚Äútradition‚Äù and ‚Äúauthenticity‚Äù without scholarly backing for these claims. One is left asking: What time periods and regions inform these museum constructions? As it stands, the installations are largely ahistorical, apart from the fact that the individual objects themselves are well dated and researched. This is precisely the problem: Such curated constructions function more as a vehicle for displaying a collection than as documentation of actual shrines. Without knowledge of the lived ritual practices and historic moments that give rise to shrine environs, and without historical, ethnographic, or archival evidence to ground claims, these museum reconstructions largely remain unfounded fabrications.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Script Analysis: ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù ‚Äî Scene-By-Scene Breakdown

Here is my take on this exercise from a previous series of posts ‚Äî How To Read A Screenplay:

After a first pass, it‚Äôs time to crack open the script for a deeper analysis and you can do that by creating a scene-by-scene breakdown. It is precisely what it sounds like: A list of all the scenes in the script accompanied by a brief description of the events that transpire.

For purposes of this exercise, I have a slightly different take on scene. Here I am looking not just for individual scenes per se, but a scene or set of scenes that comprise one event or a continuous piece of action. Admittedly this is subjective and there is no right or wrong, the point is simply to break down the script into a series of parts which you then can use dig into the script‚Äôs structure and themes.

The value of this exercise:

  • We pare down the story to its most constituent parts: Scenes.
  • By doing this, we consciously explore the structure of the narrative.
  • A scene-by-scene breakdown creates a foundation for even deeper analysis of the story.

title: The eerie beauty of Estonia's silent swamps
excerpt: Once feared as homes to spirits, Estonia's bogs cover a fifth of the country and are vital to its culture and ecology. Today, travellers can explore them on guided bog-shoe treks.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Once feared as homes to spirits, Estonia's bogs cover a fifth of the country and are vital to its culture and ecology. Today, travellers can explore them on guided bog-shoe treks.

At first, the heathery ground simply felt springy underfoot. But as we moved deeper into the K√µnnu Suursoo bog, it grew wetter and softer until my guide, Marilin Pehka, stopped and handed me a pair of curiously oversized plastic frames.‚Ä®

"We must put on the bog shoes now," she said. "They spread your weight so you won't sink."

I strapped them on and stepped forward, feeling the earth shift beneath my feet. Black pools rippled between hummocks of russet moss as I moved around their perimeters ‚Äì no longer on solid ground, but on spongy layers of peat. Spindly pines stood in silhouette against a deepening sky.

"Stop. Listen. Breathe," Pehka said, pausing on a grassy tussock. I expected a bird call or the rustle of wind. There was only silence and a rich earthy smell perfumed with rosemary. She bent to pluck a sprig of greenery. "Labrador tea," she said, pointing to clusters of white flowers renowned for their hallucinogenic properties, growing alongside blueberries and cloudberries. "Estonians have always foraged in the bogs. They are a place of rich pickings."

To understand Estonia, you must understand its bogs. For centuries, bogs have been seen as bleak and forbidding, yet in Estonia they are central to national identity. They shape the landscape, sustain biodiversity and are now a focus of both conservation and tourism.

K√µnnu Suursoo is one of Estonia's largest, covering around 25 sq km. I was walking here in summer, when dragonflies skimmed the dark, mirror-like pools and cotton grass swayed above clumps of peat moss. "In autumn the moss turns crimson," said Pehka. "In winter the land sleeps under snow and ice, and in spring the bog breathes again with green shoots as cranes, storks and swallows begin to nest."

As we walked deeper, Pehka pointed out elk tracks and told me that wolves and bears also roam these reed-lined meadows, "though they tend to avoid humans". I was grateful for the reassurance. Walking marshy ground was already pushing me out of my comfort zone. But 2km on, through open bog, we reached a boardwalk leading to a wooden watchtower: the perfect place to watch the setting Sun turn the area into a quilt of golden mosses separated by black water threads and pale green islands. "This," Pehka said quietly, "is the real Estonia."

Many English-language phrases associated with bogs have negative connotations: bog-standard; bogged down with work; mired in controversy. So Estonians are used to visitors who think they are places to be avoided.

Set Out

Set Out is a BBC Travel series that celebrates slow, self-propelled travel and invites readers to get outside and reconnect with the world in a safe and sustainable way.

"I think the most positive interpretation of bogland is in Shrek," joked Marika Kose, who researches recreation management at the Estonian University of Life Sciences. "But here in Estonia, bogs are part of the national identity and a source of livelihood. For generations people have foraged for berries, hunted and caught fish in bogs."

Over time bogs also became a place of refuge. "People have fled into the mires to escape wars, cruel landlords and outbreaks of plague," Kose added.

The value of peat came to the forefront in the late 19th Century, when it began to be used industrially as fuel and bedding for livestock. As a result, many European countries drained their bogs for farming and industry, losing vast areas of natural peatland. But in Estonia, bogs remain a defining feature, covering more than a fifth of the countryside ‚Äì around 340,000 hectares ‚Äì and playing a vital role in both local ecology and global climate.

"Bogs are ecosystems where organic matter produced by plants does not decompose completely but is deposited as peat, which binds carbon and helps to mitigate climate change," explained Raimo Pajula from the Ecology Department at Tallinn University. "If drained, the peat begins to decompose and the carbon is released back into the atmosphere."
